They don't know that they should be in school or that they should be playing."<ref name="childlabor1">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/09/23/commonwealth.games.child.labor/|title=Hard evidence of child labor at 2010 Commonwealth Games|publisher=CNN|date=24 September 2010|accessdate=29 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="childlabor2">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1314976/COMMONWEALTH-GAMES-2010-Child-labourers-pictured-working-construction-sites.html|title=After Delhi's disgrace, the shame: Child labourers pictured working on construction sites in frantic effort to get Commonwealth Games stadiums ready|work=Daily Mail|date=29 September 2010|accessdate=29 September 2010|location=London|first=Jonathan|last=McEvoy}}</ref>
Even though the [[New Delhi]] [[chief minister]] [[Sheila Dikshit]] claimed that nobody had approached her, according to CNN, they had tried to contact her as far back as 23 July 2010. In spite of repeated attempts, according to them, no official reply was ever made.<ref name="childlabor1"/>
===Urban change===
Mitu Sengupta, a professor of politics at [[Ryerson University]], Canada, points out that there is a "tradition of using 'urban spectacles' such as the Olympics and World’s Fairs to enhance a city’s global recognition, image and status, and to push through controversial policy reforms that might otherwise linger in the pending file for years (it is easier to undercut local opposition under the pressure of a fixed deadline and the international spotlight).” She writes that the reforms involved are often "the invention of an affluent, globally connected minority that is relatively detached from local conditions and the local population". The 2010 Commonwealth Games, she says, are being used to invigorate an elite-driven program of urban transformation" that centers on privatization, securitization, and the construction of "monuments to vanity".<ref name=CounterPunch>{{cite web|url= http://www.counterpunch.org/sengupta07302010.html |title= The Price of Being World Class |last= Sengupta |first= Mitu |date= 1 August 2010 |accessdate= 22 September 2010 |publisher=[[CounterPunch]]}}</ref> Sengupta expands upon this argument in a subsequent article in [[Z Magazine]]<ref>http://zcommunications.org/indias-games-of-shame-by-mitu-sengupta</ref> Amita Baviskar, a professor of sociology at the Institute of Economic Growth, [[University of Delhi]], makes a similar argument, on how mega-events, like the [[Olympics]] and Commonwealth Games, are used to advance narrow agendas of urban reform that cater to the middle class and rich. She focuses on how, in preparation for the Commonwealth Games, the city's slums were bulldozed in order to make room for shopping malls and expensive real estate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metamute.org/en/Demolishing-Delhi |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070906123108/http://www.metamute.org/en/Demolishing-Delhi |archivedate=6 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Sex slavery and prostitution boom=== There has been a boom in the number of young girls, mostly from impoverished parts of India, coming to Delhi after being offered jobs by disguised criminals, only to be taken prisoner and forced into sex slavery. The number of victims is believed to be in the hundreds. Many brothels have been running English courses for sex workers and upgrading their facilities in anticipation of a business upturn during the games.<ref>Hodge, Amanda. "Girls lured to games for work being sold to brothels". ''The Australian''. p. 1. 30 September 2010.</ref> Overseas prostitutes are also expected to come as tourists and ply their trade.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-09-17/gurgaon/28230691_1_escort-services-social-networking-gurgaon | work=The Times of India | first1=Yogesh | last1=Kumar | title=Escort services network on sites to score big at Commonwealth Games | date=17 September 2010}}</ref> One anti-trafficking NGO has claimed that there are reports of 40,000 women being brought in from northeastern India alone. A spokesperson said that recruits from that part of India were favoured because of their lighter skin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sify.com/news/concern-over-40-000-northeast-women-hired-for-cwg-services-news-national-kj2s4eedhcj.html|title=Concern over 40,000 northeast women hired for CWG services|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> It has been reported that over 3,000 bar girls in Mumbai have stopped going to work; this has been blamed on an exodus to Delhi for the Commonwealth Games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2010/sep/190910-mumbai-bar-girls-cwg-delhi-escort.htm|title=Bar girls answer CWG call in Delhi|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
==Organisational failure==
===Vigilance-related irregularities and Over-Invoicing=== On 28 July 2010, the [[Central Vigilance Commission]], an Indian government body created to address governmental corruption, released a report showing irregularities in up to 14 CWG projects.<ref>{{cite news| author=The Economic Times | title=CVC finds irregularities in several CWG projects | url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/et-cetera/CVC-finds-irregularities-in-several-CWG-projects/articleshow/6229429.cms | date=28 July 2010 | accessdate=1 August 2010 | work=The Times of India}}</ref> As per official reports, in total 129 works in 71 organisations have been inspected.<ref>''Clarification–regarding inspection of works relating to Common Wealth Games.'', report issued by CVC. [http://www.cvc.nic.in/cwgclrf3072010.pdf Download pdf]</ref> The detailed preliminary findings included the award of work contracts at higher prices, poor quality assurance and management, and work contracts awarded to ineligible agencies.<ref>''INSPECTION OF WORKS RELATED TO COMMON WEALTH GAMES'', report by the CVC, [http://www.cvc.nic.in/cwgpress2972010.pdf Download PDF]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
There are also allegations of widespread corruption in various aspects of organising the games including procurement and awarding contracts for constructing the game venues.<ref>{{cite web| author=NDTV India | title=Corruption scandal hits 2010 Games, organisers deny charges | url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/corruption-scandal-hits-2010-games-organisers-deny-charges-40991 | date=31 July 2010 | accessdate=2 August 2010}}</ref> The Commonwealth Games Organising Committee on 5 August 2010 suspended joint director T S Darbari and M Jayachandran following the report of the three-member panel which was probing the financial irregularities related to the Queen's Baton Relay.<ref>{{cite web| author=ibnlive | title=3 Kalmadi aides sacked from games panel | url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/senior-cwg-official-darbari-sacked/128262-5-23.html?from=tn | date=5 August 2010 | accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref>
Also, Organising Committee treasurer Anil Khanna resigned from the post in the wake of allegations that his son's firm had secured a contract for laying synthetic courts at a tennis stadium.<ref>{{cite news| author=timesofindia | title=Games scam: Kalmadi aide T S Darbari sacked | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/events-tournaments/commonwealth-games/top-stories/Games-scam-Kalmadi-aides-Darbari-Mohindroo-sacked/articleshow/6261909.cms | date=5 August 2010 | accessdate=5 August 2010 | work=The Times of India}}</ref> The [[GlobalPost]] news agency reports that scandals have come to light, such as "shadowy off-shore firms, forged emails, inexplicable payments to bogus companies and inflated bills – for every purchase from toilet paper to treadmills."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/india/100812/new-delhi-commonwealth-games-corruption |title=Commonwealth Games | New Delhi | India Corruption |publisher=Globalpost.com |accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Among the alleged corruption and defrauding of the games budget, toilet paper rolls valued at $2 were costed at $80, $2 soap dispensers at $60, $98 mirrors at $220, $11,830 altitude training simulators at $250,190.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-08-19/toilet-paper-scandal-in-india-shames-commonwealth-games-host.html |title=Toilet-Paper Scandal in India 'Shames' Commonwealth Games Host |publisher=BusinessWeek |date=19 August 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref>
===Preparation delays=== In September 2009, CGF chief Mike Fennell reported that the games were at risk of falling behind schedule and that it was "reasonable to conclude that the current situation poses a serious risk to the Commonwealth Games in 2010". A report by the [[Indian Government]] released several months prior found that construction work on 13 out of the 19 sports venues was behind schedule.<ref name="bbc_cg">{{Cite news|title=India admits 2010 Games problems|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8256127.stm|publisher=BBC | date=15 September 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref>
The Chief of the Indian Olympic Association shri Narendra Modi has also expressed his concerns regarding the current state of affairs. Singh has called for the revamp of the Organising Committee commenting that India now has to "retrieve the games".<ref name="reuters_cg">{{Cite news|title=Olympic official calls for revamp of Delhi Games committee|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/topNews/idINIndia-42471320090915|publisher=Reuters | date=15 September 2009}}</ref> Other Indian officials have also expressed dismay at the ongoing delays but they have stated that they are confident that India will successfully host the games and do so on time.<ref name="telegraph_cg">{{Cite news|title=Delhi Commonwealth Games 'at grave risk of collapse'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/6190118/Delhi-Commonwealth-Games-at-grave-risk-of-collapse.html|author=Dean Nelson|work=Telegraph| location=London | date=15 September 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref><ref name="guardian_cg">{{Cite news|title=Only a year to run – and Delhi is losing race to host Commonwealth Games|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6834446.ece|author=Jeremy Page|publisher=Times Online | location=London | date=15 September 2009 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref>
As the [[Times of India]] reports, all CWG projects were to be completed by May 2009 and the last year should have been kept for trial runs. The newspaper further reports that the first stadium was handed over for trial runs in July 2010 only.<ref>{{cite news| author=Times of India | title=14 Commonwealth Games projects under CBI, CVC scanner | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-29/india/28291275_1_cvc-scanner-cwg-projects-commonwealth-games | date=29 July 2010 | accessdate=1 August 2010 | work=The Times of India}}</ref> To put the delays in perspective, [[Beijing National Stadium]] was completed much ahead of schedule for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]],<ref>{{Cite news|title=Milestones in the construction of the Bird's Nest|url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/cptvenues/venues/nst/headlines/n214423642.shtml|publisher=Beijing 2008 Official Site|location=Beijing|date=28 June 2008|accessdate=2 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080824180648/http://en.beijing2008.cn/cptvenues/venues/nst/headlines/n214423642.shtml|archivedate=24 August 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> while the venues for [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London are scheduled to be delivered one year before the games and the construction of the venues is on track.<ref>{{Cite news|title=London 2012 progress report: Will Britain deliver on Olympic promises?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/jul/27/london-2012-progress-report-deliver-promises|author=Owen Gibson|publisher=Guardian UK| location=London| date=27 July 2010 | accessdate=2 August 2010}}</ref>
In August 2010, the Cabinet Secretariat took a decision to appoint 10 officers of the rank of Joint and Additional Secretaries to oversee the progress of the construction of stadiums.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Kalmadi's wings clipped, Government takes control of Games panel|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/kalmadis-wings-clipped-government-takes-control-of-games-panel-45705|author=NDTV|publisher=NDTV|date=19 August 2010|accessdate=19 August 2010}}</ref> Each officer is allocated a stadium and given the responsibility to ensure that the work completes in time for the games.
===Mass volunteer walkout=== Around 10,000 of the 22,000 selected volunteers quit, less than a week before the event. This has been blamed on a lack of training for personnel, or dissatisfaction with assignments. There are reports that some who have quit have not returned their uniforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/30/3025846.htm?site=commonwealthgames/2010|title=Thousands of Games volunteers quit: report|date=30 September 2010|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===Poor ticket sales and attendance=== The start of the Games saw extremely poor ticket sales, with many venues near empty.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/commonwealthgames/8042933/Commonwealth-Games-2010-ticket-queues-a-mile-long-claim-organisers-in-Delhi.html |title=Commonwealth Games 2010: ticket queues 'a mile long', claim organisers in Delhi |work=Telegraph|date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2010 |location=London |first=Jacquelin |last=Magnay}}</ref> In a press conference, organising chairman [[Suresh Kalmadi]] admitted that there were problems, and blamed empty venues on ticket booths not being set up outside stadiums.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-10-05/news/27608988_1_tickets-kalmadi-venues |title=CWG: Organisers admit ticket sales blunder |work=The Economic Times|date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> Commonwealth Games chief Mike Fennell admitted that many venues had been nearly empty on the opening day of the Games, saying "A number of venues do not have lots of spectators [...] one area which causes us concern".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11474371 |title=Crowds giving Delhi Commonwealth Games a miss |publisher=BBC News |date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref> On the second day of competition, less than 100 people filled the hockey venue–the 19,000-seat MDC Stadium. Less than 20 people watched the first tennis match of the tournament in the 5,000-seat tennis stadium, and just 58 fans watched the netball opening match.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/10/05/ap/world/main6929789.shtml |title=Empty Seats Plague Commonwealth Games In India |publisher=CBS News |date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=6 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009045019/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/10/05/ap/world/main6929789.shtml |archivedate=9 October 2010 }}</ref>
One Indian competitor tried to buy tickets for relatives online, only to be informed by the website that tickets were sold out. When he arrived to compete, he found the venue to be empty.<ref name=crad/>
The streets of Delhi were deserted for the cycling road races and walking event. {{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
===Spectators' response at opening ceremony=== At the opening ceremony, the chairman of the organising committee, Suresh Kalmadi, faced embarrassment, when he was booed by spectators at the start of his welcome speech to 60,000 spectators.<ref>http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/sport/games-spectators-boo-delhi-chief-organiser-at-opening-ceremony-jd-03</ref> Kalmadi came under further strain when he "thanked" the late [[Princess Diana]] for attending the opening ceremony of the games. The chairman made the blunder at a press conference saying 'Yes, Princess Diana was there,’ after which he immediately corrected himself by saying 'Prince Charles and (Camilla) the Duchess of Cornwall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/58752/princess-diana-was-there-kalmadi/|title=Princess Diana was there: Kalmadi - The Express Tribune|date=5 October 2010|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===Opening ceremony=== The [[Australia at the 2010 Commonwealth Games|Australian Commonwealth contingent]] expressed frustration over the opening ceremony, in which there were claims that the athletes and delegation support staff were "treated like cattle" and subjected to "disgraceful" and unbearable conditions.<ref name="Opening ceremony">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/commonwealth-games-2010/comm-games-news/athletes-treated-like-cattle-before-opening-parade-20101005-166dy.html|title=Athletes 'treated like cattle' before opening parade|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=6 October 2010|first1=Jake|last1=Niall|first2=New|last2=Delhi}}</ref> Australia's chef de mission [[Steve Moneghetti]] complained about the athletes being trapped in "absolute cauldron conditions" under the main stadium before marching for the opening ceremony. The Australians were stuck in a tunnel, where Moneghetti described the temperature as exceeding {{convert|40|C}} due to a lack of airconditioning and ventilation. When attempting to move out, the Australian delegation was stopped by staff. When the contestants were finally able to move out into the arena, they were described as being emotionally affected.
==Racism allegations==
African countries have complained that they are getting second-class treatment from the Games organisers, in spite of them offering India a hand in the preparation of the Games.<ref name="racism1">{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/cwg-aus-scotland-arrive-africa-cries-racism/131766-5-23.html|title=CWG: Aus, Scotland arrive, Africa cries racism|publisher=CNN-IBN|date=26 September 2010|accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref> They have alleged that accommodation given to them was inferior compared to the accommodation provided to the Australian and New Zealand teams. They went on to state that India was complaining about being victims of racial bias in the reporting of the Games; while simultaneously perpetrating the same kind of racism against the African countries.<ref name="racism1" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-09-27/india/28218834_1_african-countries-african-nations-commonwealth-games|title=Racism at Commonwealth Games? Africans upset|work=The Times of India|date=27 September 2010|accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref>
==Infrastructure issues==
===Transport infrastructure===
The [[Delhi Airport Metro Express]] built by [[Reliance Infrastructure]] and [[CAF Beasain]] missed its deadline of 31 July 2010 and the private consortium was fined Rs 112.5 million.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-10-01/delhi/28268221_1_dmrc-civil-structures-metro-rail-corporation | work=The Times of India | title=IGI line delay: Reliance subsidiary fined | date=1 October 2010}}</ref>
===Venues=== Less than two weeks before the opening ceremony, Fennell wrote to the Indian cabinet secretary, urging action in response to the village being "seriously compromised." He said that though team officials were impressed with the international zone and main dining area, they were "shocked" by the state of the accommodation. "The village is the cornerstone of any Games and the athletes deserve the best possible environment to prepare for their competition."<ref>{{Cite news|author=Sanjoy Majumder |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11379020 |title=Delhi Games village 'unfit for athletes' |publisher=BBC News |date= 21 September 2010|accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> The BBC published photographs of the village taken two days before 23 September showing unfinished living quarters.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Commonwealth Games: Athletes' village photos |newspaper=[[BBC]] |date=23 September 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/9025907.stm |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref>
New Zealand, Canada, Scotland and Northern Ireland have expressed concern about unliveable conditions.<ref>{{cite news|first=Rumu| last=Banerjee|agency=TNN |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/news/Commonwealth-Games-Village-unliveable-complain-four-countries/articleshow/6595540.cms |title=Commonwealth Games Village unliveable, complain four countries|work=The Times of India|date= 21 September 2010|accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> The [[Times of India]] newspaper reports that the Scottish delegation apparently submitted a photograph of a dog defecating on a bed in the games village.<ref>{{cite news|agency=TNN |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/news/Now-smaller-teams-consider-withdrawal-from-Commonwealth-Games/articleshow/6605483.cms |title=Now, smaller teams consider withdrawal from Commonwealth Games|work=The Times of India|date= 22 September 2010|accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Hooper said that there was "excrement in places it shouldn't be" in the athletes' quarters and that members of visiting delegations had to help clean up the unsanitary things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/22/3018287.htm |title=Filth, bridge collapse add to Delhi's woes - Delhi 2010 Commonwealth Games News |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> The BBC released images of bathrooms with brown-coloured [[paan]] stains on the walls and floor, liquids on the floor, and brown paw prints on athletes' beds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/9025907.stm |title=BBC Sport - Commonwealth Games: Athletes' village photos |publisher=BBC News |date=23 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> Lalit Bhanot, the secretary general of the Organising Committee, rejected the complaint that sanitation was poor by saying that, due to cultural differences, there are different standards about cleanliness in India and the [[western world]], a statement for which he was widely ridiculed in Indian and international media.<ref name="abcsanitation">{{cite web |url=http://abclive.in/abclive_sports/cwg/sanitation_standard_cwg_2010.html |title=Indian Sanitation Standard Vs Western Sanitation @ Commonwealth Games 2010 |author=Ramesh Kapoor |date=21 September 2010 |publisher=[[ABC Live]] |accessdate=22 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923084804/http://abclive.in/abclive_sports/cwg/sanitation_standard_cwg_2010.html |archivedate=23 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Bhanot went on to say of the athletes' village that, "This is a world-class village, probably one of the best ever."<ref name="abcsanitation"/>
Meanwhile, Pakistan also made reservations over the condition of the athletes' village and asked for an alternate accommodation to be made available to its contingent while preparation was still in progress. The [[Pakistan Olympic Association]] president [[Syed Arif Hasan]] remarked: "We want the CGF to ensure that the athletes' village is in good condition. Athletes cannot stay at a substandard place." Hasan however added that there were no doubts over Pakistan’s participation and the contingent would leave as planned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/55385/pakistan-%e2%80%98concerned%e2%80%99-over-athletes%e2%80%99-village/|title=Pakistan ‘concerned’ over athletes’ village|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=28 September 2010}}</ref>
On the other hand, England's [[Chef de mission]] [[Craig Hunter]] praised the Games Village, remarking that "the Commonwealth Games Village here [in New Delhi] is better than the [[2008 Summer Olympic|Beijing Olympics]]". He added that the arrangements at the Games Village is much better than that at the 2008 Summer Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Delhi-Games-Village-better-than-Beijing-English-Chef-de-mission/Article1-600985.aspx |title=Hindustan Times - Archive News |accessdate=20 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021070232/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Delhi-Games-Village-better-than-Beijing-English-Chef-de-mission/Article1-600985.aspx |archivedate=21 October 2010 }}</ref>
Canada's sports minister also supported the Games, saying that big events always face issues, and the media often exaggerates them, as Canada found during the [[2010 Winter Olympics|Vancouver Winter Olympics]]. He added that "We are coming in full force."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/commonwealth-games-2010/news/After-delay-in-sending-athletes-Canada-minister-supports-CWG/articleshow/6632480.cms|date=26 September 2010|work=[[Times of India]] | title=After delay in sending athletes, Canada minister supports CWG}}</ref>
===Problems with functionality of equipment and infrastructure during events=== On the first night of swimming, debris landed in the swimming pool, causing delays ahead of a race. It is believed that part of the ceiling or its paint had fallen off.
Before the last night of swimming finals, the filtration system broke down and the pool was turbid and murky during the warmup session and the finals; it was described as the least clear ever seen for a swimming competition. A disproportionate number of swimmers fell ill with intestinal complaints, leading to concerns over the cleanliness and sanitation of the pool.<ref name=pool>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/commonwealthgames/8053551/Commonwealth-Games-2010-shambles-continue-as-swimming-pool-filtration-system-fails.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Jacquelin | last1=Magnay | first2=Rod | last2=Gilmour | title=Commonwealth Games 2010: shambles continue as swimming pool filtration system fails | date=10 October 2010}}</ref> Early suspicions rested on the quality of water in the swimming pools of the [[SPM Swimming Pool Complex|SPM Complex]], but other competing teams, including South Africa, reported no such illness.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecr.co.za/kagiso/content/en/east-coast-radio/east-coast-radio-news?oid=938225&sn=Detail&pid=490476&SA-swimming-team-healthy-and-well |title=SA swimming team healthy and well |publisher=[[East Coast Radio (South Africa)]] |accessdate=14 October 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Daily water quality tests were being carried out on the water of the pools, as mandated by the event standards. Additional tests were ordered after news of the illnesses, but they also did not find anything amiss. The Australian team's chief doctor, Peter Harcourt, ruled that the "chances of the [Delhi] pool being the cause of the problem is very remote" and praised the hygiene and food quality in the Delhi Games Village.<ref name="Illness">{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/commonwealth-games-2010/comm-games-news/malaysia-camp-blamed-for-swimmers-bug-20101008-16bj1.html | work=Sydney Morning Herald | title=Malaysia camp blamed for swimmers' bug| date=8 October 2010}}</ref> He suggested that it could be a common case of [[Traveler's diarrhea]] (locally called Delhi belly), or the Australian swimmers could have contracted the stomach virus during their training camp in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.<ref name="Illness"/> English Olympic and Commonwealth gold-medalist swimmer [[Rebecca Adlington]] said that the water quality was absolutely fine.<ref name="Did Delhi live up to expectations">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/jamespearce/2010/10/did_delhi_live_up_to_expectati.html |title=Did Delhi live up to expectations? |publisher=[[BBC]] Sport |date=14 October 2010|accessdate=15 October 2010}}</ref>
After the opening ceremony, the ground at the athletics arena was damaged, and the grass infield and the track was still being re-laid two hours before competition started.
==Vandalism of Games Village by Athletes==
===Condoms and toilet blockages=== An Indian newspaper during the games reported that used [[condom]]s flushed down the toilets in the athlete's village had caused some drains to become blocked, necessitating action by plumbers to clear the pipes.<ref name="Condoms">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/used-condoms-clog-village-toilets/story-fn66fst6-1225935545518|title=Used condoms clog athletes' village toilets in Delhi|work=The Australian|date=7 October 2010|first1=Robert|last1=Craddock|first2=Jess|last2=Halloran}}</ref>
===Athletes under investigation for trashing apartments=== Australian athletes have been accused of vandalizing the towers of the athletes' village they were staying in by breaking furniture and electrical fittings.<ref name="ToICricketLoss">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/news/cricket-loss-makes-oz-athletes-take-it-out-on-washing-machine/cwgarticleshow/6750851.cms|title=Cricket loss makes Oz athletes take it out on washing machine|work=TOI|date=15 October 2010|first1=Rahul|last1=Tripathi}}</ref> Delhi Police did not press the case after the Organizing Committee refused to file a complaint while Indian external affairs minister SM Krishna dismissed it as a one-off incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/news/no-aussie-involved-in-village-hooliganism-crosswhite/cwgarticleshow/6752348.cms|title=Australia slams vandalism charges|work=TOI|date=15 October 2010}}</ref>
A washing machine was hurled from the eighth floor of the same tower. Nobody on the ground was hit, but it is unclear who the culprit was. Indian newspapers have reported that the Australian Commonwealth Games Authority agreed to pay for the damages<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.rediff.com/report/2010/oct/15/cwg-2010-delhi-australia-apologise-vandalism.htm|title=Aussies apologise for damaging washing machine|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> and have apologised for the incident.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://cwg.ndtv.com/commonwealth/article/id/spoen20100156718/type/latest/cwg-australian-team-asked-to-pay-for-damages-60010.html |title=Aussies agree to pay damages |work=NDTV |date=15 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101018052945/http://cwg.ndtv.com/commonwealth/article/id/spoen20100156718/type/latest/cwg-australian-team-asked-to-pay-for-damages-60010.html |archivedate=18 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.rediff.com/report/2010/oct/15/cwg-2010-delhi-australia-apologise-vandalism.htm|title=Aussies apologise for damaging washing machine|work=TOI|date=15 October 2010}}</ref> The Australian High Commissioner rejected the claim, stating that the incident was the result of partying and celebrations.<ref name="ToICricketLoss" /><ref>http://cwg.ndtv.com/commonwealth/article/id/spoen20100156699/type/latest/Vandalism-Games-Village-Australian-High-Commissioners-59965.html{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}?</ref> Later comments by Australian officials have contradicted claims by Lalit Bhanot that they had admitted responsibility. Perry Crosswhite said that it was still unclear if athletes from other nations present in the tower at the time had been responsible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/16/3040128.htm?site=commonwealthgames/2010|title=Officials deny athlete threw washing machine|date=16 October 2010|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
==Safety and security concerns== Small monkeys roam Delhi's streets and prefer heavily urbanized areas with plenty of living space among buildings.<ref>{{cite news|title=Delhi ropes in monkeys for Commonwealth Games security |publisher=BBC|date=29 September 2010|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11433539}}</ref> They cannot be killed because many Indians see them as sacred so instead a larger, domesticated monkey, the [[langur]], is brought in to scare away the smaller monkeys.
On the second day of the games, three Ugandan officials were injured by a malfunctioning security barrier at the games' village, and a senior official from that country raised allegations of discrimination by Indian officials. Uganda's sports minister lashed out at Indian officials and demanded an apology for the accident. The officials had cuts and bruises and were hospitalized overnight for observation.<ref name="Problems still mar Commonwealth Games in India">{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101007/ap_on_sp_ot/com_commonwealth_games_problems|title=Problems still mar Commonwealth Games in India|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=7 October 2010}}</ref> The chairman of the Games' Organising Committee, Suresh Kalmadi, apologized to the Ugandan High Commissioner to India for the freak car accident.<ref>{{cite news|author=PTI |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/commonwealth-games-2010/news/Kalmadi-apologises-to-Ugandan-officials/articleshow/6711890.cms |title=Kalmadi apologises to Ugandan officials - The Times of India | publisher=Times of India |date=8 October 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref>
===Infrastructural compromise=== On 21 September 2010, a footbridge under construction for the Games near the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium collapsed, injuring at least 23 people,<ref>{{Cite news| title = CWG: Bridge collapses near JLN stadium | date = 21 September 2010| url = http://www.zeenews.com/news656584.html | work = [[Zeenews.com]]| accessdate = 21 September 2010}}</ref> mainly workers, underscoring fears of poor workmanship. Commenting on the incident, [[Chief Minister of Delhi]] [[Sheila Dikshit]] controversially remarked that the footbridge was only meant for spectators and not for athletes.<ref>{{Cite news|title= Commonwealth Games 2010 mess: Foot over-bridge at Nehru stadium collapses|url= http://cwg.ndtv.com/commonwealth/article/id/spoen20100153970/type/latest/Commonwealth-Games-2010-mess-Foot-over-bridge-Nehru-stadium-collapses-53751.html|agency= [[NDTV]]|work= NDTV India|date= 21 September 2010|accessdate= 21 September 2010|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100924023819/http://cwg.ndtv.com/commonwealth/article/id/spoen20100153970/type/latest/Commonwealth-Games-2010-mess-Foot-over-bridge-Nehru-stadium-collapses-53751.html#|archive-date= 24 September 2010|dead-url= yes|df= dmy-all}}</ref> Following the collapse, Fennell expressed concern that conditions at the Games Village, which had "shocked the majority", would seriously compromise the entire event.<ref name="Vancouver Sun">{{Cite news|title=Scandals, filth give Commonwealth Games sinking feeling|date=21 September 2010 |url=https://vancouversun.com/sports/Scandals+filth+give+Commonwealth+Games+sinking+feeling/3555038/story.html|work=[[Vancouver Sun]]|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref> The company that was building the foot bridge, P&R Infraprojects, was subsequently blacklisted by the Delhi Government and was not allowed to get government contracts.<ref name=the_age>{{Cite news|date= 23 September 2010 |title= Safety cloud over Games venues| accessdate=23 September 2010|url=http://www.theage.com.au/sport/safety-cloud-over-games-venues-20100922-15mye.html?from=age_sb|work= [[The Age]] |author= Wade, Matt |author2=Ker, Peter | location=Melbourne}}</ref>
Reportedly, progress was still slow and four or five accommodation towers built by [[Emaar]] at the Games village were unfinished, lacking facilities such as wireless internet, fitted toilets and plumbing. In addition, rubble, unused masonry and discarded bricks littered the unfinished gardens. According to sports historian Boria Majumdar, author of the ''Sellotape Legacy: Delhi and the Commonwealth Games'', India "may have to pull a miracle."<ref name="Vancouver Sun"/> The father of Australian track cyclist [[Kaarle McCulloch]] visited his daughter at the Olympic village. A builder in Australia, Grahame McCulloch criticised the structural soundness of the village; he said "those buildings are the dodgiest things I have ever seen...so substandard".<ref name=crad/> He told his daughter not to use the balcony, fearing that it was collapsible.<ref name=crad>Craddock, Robert (7 October 2010). "What games? We just won the cricket". ''The Advertiser''. p. 77.</ref>
On 22 September 2010, part of the drop ceiling of the new Commonwealth Games weightlifting venue in New Delhi collapsed.<ref name=Aust_2010_Sept_22>{{Cite news| url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/games-roof-collapse-report/story-fn3dxity-1225928001831 | title= Games roof collapse - report | date= 22 September 2010 | accessdate= 22 September 2010 |publisher=[[The Australian]]}}</ref>
Indian bantamweight boxer [[Akhil Kumar]]'s bed in the Games village collapsed when he sat on it. "I sat down on my bed to rest but suddenly it gave way. After that I noticed that part of it has no plywood", he said<ref name="Express">{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/54986/commonwealth-games-troubles-continue/|title=India tries to put modern face forward for Games|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=27 September 2010}}</ref>
On 27 September 2010, a South African athlete reported that a snake was present in his room in the Games Village. A day earlier, animal authorities had to be called in to evacuate a [[king cobra]] from the tennis venue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/27/3022745.htm |title=Snake found in Games athlete's room - Delhi 2010 Commonwealth Games News |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=19 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref>
On 7 October, a large scoreboard crashed to the ground at the rugby venue when a supporting chain snapped. The games however were due to start a week later so no major repercussions were experienced.<ref name="Problems still mar Commonwealth Games in India"/>
===Terror threats=== Following the [[2008 Mumbai attacks]], some athletes and their representative bodies expressed security fears during the games. In April 2010, during the [[Indian Premier League]], two low intensity bombs went off outside the [[M. Chinnaswamy Stadium]] in [[Bangalore]]. Although there were no casualties, this postponed the start of the game by an hour. Following this attack, foreign cricketers like [[Kevin Pietersen]] expressed fears for their safety and questions were raised regarding the safety of athletes during the Commonwealth Games [http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/cricket/3594506/Bombs-hit-Indian-Premier-League-match]. The UK and Canada also warned about potential attacks on commercial targets in Delhi ahead of the games.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article7105608.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Attack alerts in Delhi hit plans to stage Commonwealth Games | accessdate=23 April 2010 | first=Jeremy | last=Page | date=23 April 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ndtv.com/news/sports/commonwealth-games-security-lagging-behind-20603.php Commonwealth Games security lagging behind]. Ndtv.com. Retrieved on 6 July 2010.</ref>
====Jama Masjid incident==== {{Main|2010 Jama Masjid attack}}
On 19 September 2010, unknown gunmen on a motorbike opened fire with an automatic pistol on a tourist bus outside the [[Jama Masjid, Delhi|Jama Masjid]] mosque in Delhi. The attacks, which came a fortnight before the start of the games, injured two Taiwanese tourists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/world/03-gunmen-open-fire-at-tourist-bus-in-new-delhi-ss-02 |title=Gunmen open fire at tourist bus in New Delhi |publisher=Dawn |accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Two hours later, a [[Maruti Suzuki|Maruti]] car exploded in the vicinity, reportedly from a deliberate low-intensity [[pressure cooker bomb]] which had been assembled inside. No fatalities or major damages were reported. The incidents, which were purportedly claimed by the [[Indian Mujahideen]], provoked fears about lack of security in the city for the upcoming games. However, police in Delhi initially denied the role of any organised terror group and instead blamed the attacks on "disgruntled youths and local criminal gangs."<ref>{{cite news|author=PTI, 19 September 2010, 07.45pm IST |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-09-19/india/28266145_1_jama-masjid-taiwanese-nationals-pressure-cooker |title=No terror angle in Jama Masjid incidents: Police (The Times of India) |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date= 19 September 2010|accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Officials suggested that a possible motive of the strike was to instill fear in people ahead of the Commonwealth Games.
===Fear of dengue outbreak===
The heaviest monsoon rains in 15 years, along with large quantities of standing water on CWG construction sites as well as in tanks and ponds, raised concerns over increased levels of mosquito-borne disease in Delhi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Delhi's Richest Areas Hit By Dengue as City Prepares for Games|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=12 September 2010|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-12/delhi-s-wealthiest-areas-hit-by-dengue-outbreak-as-city-prepares-for-games.html|first=Mehul|last=Srivastava}}</ref> In the run-up to the games it was reported that 65-70 cases of [[dengue fever]] were being diagnosed each day in the city, with the number of cases "likely to hit the 3,000 mark" by the opening on 3 October.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dengue cases on the rise |work=The Hindu|date=19 September 2010|url=http://hindu.com/2010/09/19/stories/2010091965210300.htm|location=Chennai, India}}</ref>
===Illness=== Many swimmers were reported to have fallen ill. Initially, concerns were raised over the quality of water in the swimming pools of the [[SPM Swimming Pool Complex|SPM Complex]]. It was said that more than 20 percent of the English team's swimmers – about eight to 10 competitors – had been struck down with a stomach virus. The Australian team also reported that at least six of its swimmers had been sick, including [[Andrew Lauterstein]], who had to withdraw from the 50-meter butterfly. Commonwealth Games Federation president Mike Fennell said officials would conduct tests to make sure the pools were not the source of the illness. "If there is something unsafe, you cannot swim in that water. It is a matter we have to deal with a great deal of urgency," he said.<ref name="Problems still mar Commonwealth Games in India"/>
However, other competing teams, including South Africa, reported no such illness.<ref>http://www.ecr.co.za/kagiso/content/en/east-coast-radio/east-coast-radio-news?oid=938225&sn=Detail&pid=490476&SA-swimming-team-healthy-and-well{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Daily water quality tests were being carried out on the water of the pools, as mandated by the event standards. Additional tests were ordered after news of the illnesses, but they also did not find anything amiss. The Australian team's chief doctor, Peter Harcourt, ruled that the "chances of the [Delhi] pool being the cause of the problem is very remote" and praised the hygiene and food quality in the Delhi Games Village.<ref name="Illness"/> He suggested that it could be a common case of [[Traveler's diarhoea]] (locally called Delhi belly), or the Australian swimmers could have contracted the stomach virus during their training camp in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.<ref name="Illness"/> English Olympic and Commonwealth gold-medalist swimmer [[Rebecca Adlington]] said that the water quality was absolutely fine.<ref name="Did Delhi live up to expectations"/>
==Boycott== Following the withdrawal of [[Dani Samuels]], the women's world discus champion,<ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.smh.com.au/sport/australian-discus-thrower-bows-out-of-delhi-games-20100921-15l6r.html?from=smh_sb| title= Australian discus thrower bows out of Delhi Games |last= Lane| first= Daniel| date= 21 September 2010| accessdate= 22 September 2010| work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]}}</ref> because "[her] safety [was] more important to them than a medal," [[Minister for Sport (Australia)|Australia's Minister for Sport]], [[Mark Arbib]], said CWG officials expected more competitors to follow suit.
The Scottish team's departure of its first 41 boxers, rugby players, wrestlers and support staff was delayed for 48 hours, and the Welsh team set a deadline of 22 September to receive reassurances that the venues would be fit for purpose. The first batch of English athletes, which included a lawn bowls team and a men's hockey squad, said the organisers were not making nearly enough progress just a day before they were to leave. ''[[The Guardian]]'' suggested a mass walkout remained an option with the "point of no return" less than a week before the scheduled start; they claimed the "main competing countries would be likely to act in concert." They also suggested the games were on the verge of "descending into farce."
Michael Cavanagh, the chairman of Commonwealth Games Scotland, said a decision to stay away would be a joint one, as he insisted a possible knock on effects for the [[2014 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Glasgow]] would not be a factor. He said "In terms of withdrawal we don't see this as simply a Team Scotland decision, any decision to withdraw we would see as being a collective decision amongst the countries who are already there and already concerned. We can't allow ourselves to be influenced by thoughts of how it may impact on 2014, not when we have something as important as the safety of our athletes to consider."<ref name="guardian"/> [[Phillips Idowu]], the world triple jump champion, also withdrew from the Games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report_world-champion-phillips-idowu-pulls-out-of-games-due-to-safety-concerns_1441367|title=World champion Phillips Idowu pulls out of Games due to safety concerns|publisher=Daily News and Analysis|date=22 September 2010|accessdate=24 September 2010}}</ref>
===Calls for boycott=== Amidst allegations of blatant corruption, shoddy construction work at venues and security concerns for participating athletes, the 2010 Commonwealth Games have faced numerous [[boycott]] calls from individuals in India, England and Australia.<ref name="Bhagat" /><ref name="DawnF" />
Within India, there were calls for boycott. Other celebrities who followed Aiyar's comments in expressing a call for boycott include former Indian cricket captain and [[spin bowler]] [[Bishan Singh Bedi]] and bestselling Indian author [[Chetan Bhagat]]. Bedi said the "CWG organisers have taken the country for a ride" and urged international athletes to boycott the "embarrassing" Delhi games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/events-tournaments/commonwealth-games/top-stories/Wonder-how-CWG-OC-slept-for-so-long-Bishen-Singh-Bedi/articleshow/6324637.cms |title=Wonder how CWG OC slept for so long: Bishen Singh Bedi |work=[[Times of India]] |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cricket.yahoo.com/cricket/news/article?id=item/2.0/-/story/cricket.ani.com/bishen-bedi-urges-athletes-boycott-embarrassing-delhi-commonwealth-games-20100817/ |title=Bishen Bedi urges athletes to boycott 'embarrassing' Delhi Commonwealth Games |publisher=Cricket.yahoo.com |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717004245/http://cricket.yahoo.com/cricket/news/article?id=item%2F2.0%2F-%2Fstory%2Fcricket.ani.com%2Fbishen-bedi-urges-athletes-boycott-embarrassing-delhi-commonwealth-games-20100817%2F# |archive-date=17 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Bhagat, who is considered a youth icon in India with a huge fan following, called the Commonwealth games the "biggest and most blatant exercise in mass corruption since the country won independence six decades ago."<ref name="Bhagat">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/indian-author-blasts-corrupt-games-20100829-13xpb.html |title=Indian author blasts 'corrupt' Games |publisher=Smh.com.au |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010 | first=Matt | last=Wade}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/indian-paperback-king-slams-delhi-games-bribery-20100829-13xmk.html |title=Indian paperback king slams Delhi Games 'bribery' |publisher=Theage.com.au |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010 | location=Melbourne | first1=Matt | last1=Wade}}</ref> Bhagat, who has sold more than 4 million books in India, also urged his readers to boycott the games event and not to watch them on TV, thereby using the "golden chance" to "put the corrupt and insensitive government to shame."<ref name="Bhagat"/>
The [[Jat people|Jat]] community seeking [[Reservation in India|reservation]] under the [[Other Backward Class|OBC]] quota have also planned to use the Commonwealth games as a platform and force the Indian government to relent to their needs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-09-16/chandigarh/28236417_1_cwg-venues-jats-black-flags |title=Quota-seeking Jats to 'flood' CWG venues, disrupt games |work=timesofindia|date=16 September 2010 |accessdate=20 September 2010 |first1=Manveer |last1=Saini}}</ref>
Other countries also threatened to boycott the games. Considering the potential impact of a terror threat and other security concerns, rumors arose about a boycott of the Delhi Commonwealth Games by major participating nations including Scotland, England and New Zealand.<ref name="Dailyrec1">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2009/12/31/scotland-will-not-boycott-commonwealth-games-over-security-fears-86908-21933164/ |title=Scotland will not boycott Commonwealth Games over security fears |publisher=The Daily Record |accessdate=7 September 2010|date=2009-12-31 }}</ref><ref name="NZherald1">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10666732 |title=Call for athletes to boycott Games |publisher=[[Nzherald.co.nz]] |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref> However, the rumors were soon put to rest by Commonwealth games committees in each of these countries who expressed a general level of satisfaction with the security arrangements.<ref name="Dailyrec1"/><ref name="NZherald1"/>
Australian quadruple Olympic gold medal winning swimmer [[Dawn Fraser]] called for Australia to boycott the games event, citing fears of a tragedy similar to that which unfolded in the [[Munich massacre|Munich Olympics of 1972]].<ref name="DawnF">{{Cite news|author=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/aug/19/australia-commonwealth-games-boycott-fraser |title=Dawn Fraser: Australia must consider Commonwealth Games boycott |work=The Guardian|date= 19 August 2010|accessdate=7 September 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Fraser pronounced that reports of missed construction deadlines and other irregularities in games planning meant Indian authorities' "word for providing security should not be taken at its face value."<ref name="DawnF"/> However, the Australian Commonwealth Games Organising Committee was quick to dismiss Fraser's fears with ACGA chief executive, Perry Crosswhite saying he believed there will be no security issues during the games event.<ref name="DawnF"/> [[John Coates (sports administrator)|John Coates]], Australia's Olympic chief, came down hard on the organisers, alleging teams were being forced to temporary accommodation at hotels. "I don't think it is a cultural thing. When you agree to host [the Games], you are required to provide the basics in terms of health and hygiene for the athletes. The Games shouldn't have been awarded to Delhi in hindsight."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2010/09/201092465930139915.html |title=Delhi games controversy continues - Central & South Asia |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=24 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref>
===Other withdrawals=== A number of athletes withdrew from the Games, for reasons related and non-related to the state of affairs in the days leading up to the event. Jamaican world record holder [[Usain Bolt]] and his predecessor [[Asafa Powell]] pulled out of the event citing the timing of the Games as a major reason for their decisions to stay away.<ref name="Bolt Powell snub">{{Cite news| last=Stafford | first=Ian | title=Asafa Powell joins Usain Bolt in Commonwealth Games snub | date=2 September 2010 | url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1305067/Asafa-Powell-joins-Usain-Bolt-Commonwealth-Games-snub.html | newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] | accessdate=27 September 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Olympic cyclist champion [[Geraint Thomas]] pulled out for fear of contracting dengue fever.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/8825573.stm |title=BBC Sport - Geraint Thomas pulls out of Commonwealth Games in Delhi |publisher=BBC News |date=23 September 2010 |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref> Other notable athletes who have announced their non-attendance include [[Paula Radcliffe]], [[Jessica Ennis]], [[Jennifer Meadows]], [[Natasha Danvers]], [[Chris Hoy]], [[Bradley Wiggins]], [[Victoria Pendleton]] and [[Beth Tweddle]].<ref name="Bolt Powell snub" />
==Sporting controversies==
===Doping=== Prior to the Games, four wrestlers, a shot-putter and two swimmers who were all part of India's Games squad tested positive for [[methylhexaneamine]]. Four others, who were not picked for the Games in the Indian capital, also failed drug tests conducted at the various training camps across the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j49d60QFrmIIU4kvlmohXVrGwoOw |title=India stunned by failed dope tests ahead of Games|date=6 September 2010|work=[[Google News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Sport/Story/STIStory_575138.html|title=India's swimmers fail dope test|date=5 September 2010|work=[[The Straits Times]]}}</ref>
[[Oludamola Osayomi]], the winner of the women's [[100-metre sprint]] event, was reported to have tested positive for a "banned substance" which was later revealed to be the stimulant [[methylhexaneamine]].<ref name=abc_test_fail>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/11/3035197.htm?site=sport&section=all |title= Winner of Pearson's 100m tests positive |accessdate=11 October 2010 |date= 11 October 2010 |publisher= [[ABC Grandstand]]}}</ref> Another Nigerian athlete, hurdler [[Samuel Okon]] who placed sixth in the 110 metres hurdles, was reported to have tested positive for the same drug.<ref name=2nd_test_fail>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/10/another-nigerian-athlete-fails-dope-test/|title= Another Nigerian athlete fails dope test |accessdate=12 October 2010 |date= 12 October 2010 |publisher= The Vanguard}}</ref>
In July 2011, three of the four women from India's gold-medal winning 400-metre-relay team tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. Two of the racers, [[Sini Jose]] and [[Jauna Murmu]], tested positive for the anabolic steroid [[methandienone]], and [[Tiana Mary Thomas]] tested positive for [[epi-methandienone]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Westhead|first=Rick|title=Storybook win at Commonwealth Games. Now, a doping scandal|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/1021548--india-rocked-by-olympic-doping-scandal|accessdate=16 July 2011|newspaper=thestar.com|date=7 July 2011|location=Toronto}}</ref>
===Archery=== While the audience's behaviour at the archery event provoked criticism from the English team, the silver medallist, [[Alison Williamson]], praised it on the other hand.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/9077602.stm | work=BBC News | title=Williamson secures archery silver | date=10 October 2010}}</ref> Earlier reports held that the English team was upset because the loud chant of the crowd during the women's recurve event had distracted the archers. In an action condemned in the [[Indian media]], an English archery official allegedly abused an Indian coach, telling him to "f*** off." The comment came after the Indian team registered a one-point win over England to claim the gold medal. The Indian archery head coach, [[Limba Ram]], walked over to shake hands with officials of the rival team. In response, an English official showed his elbow in a gesture before uttering the remarks. Britain's archery team leader said she was unaware of the incident and added, "[the Indian coach] must find out whether the person was one among us. If he was not wearing a red jersey, he would not be part of the side. I will speak to the Indian coach about it." [[Limba Ram]] said that he failed to identify the person as he had chosen to ignore the one-off incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sify.com/sports/english-official-abuses-indian-archery-coach-news-others-kkisVJbcdci.html|title=English official abuses Indian archery coach|work=Sify Sports|date=8 October 2010}}</ref> There have also been accusations that Ram was called a monkey on two different occasions by an English official.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/Racism-slur-now-hits-Commonwealth-Games/694899|title=Racism slur now hits Commonwealth Games - Indian Express|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===Athletics=== [[File:Sally Pearson-cropped.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Pearson won the 100m sprint before being disqualified.]] During the Final of the Women’s 100m sprint final, a controversy was caused by the eventual disqualification of [[Sally Pearson]] of Australia. She had won the race on the third attempted start after one start was delayed because of excessive crowd noise and the second due to a false start by [[Laura Turner]] of England. Pearson was disqualified because she was deemed to have false-started in the second attempted restart along with Turner. This was as a direct result of a protest lodged by Team England. The controversy was caused as only Turner was disqualified from the race during the race because of a false start and not Pearson. Turner ran the race under protest. Pearson and other athletes were not informed of the protest until four hours after the race, as they were waiting to begin the medal presentation for the race. Commonwealth Games Federation president Mike Fennell called Pearson's treatment "unsatisfactory" and that the whole situation was caused by an "unacceptable communications blunder".<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/9073167.stm | title='Communication blunder' sees Pearson stripped of gold | publisher=BBC News| date=8 October 2010 | accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref>
===Boxing=== During the weigh-in for the boxing competition, the scales were giving inaccurate readings with athletes recording higher body weights on the official scales. The scales were deemed to be broken and the weigh-in was delayed 24 hours to find and calibrate new scales. The initial wrong measurements led to angry shouting between coaches, athletes and organisers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2010/s3029100.htm|title=Boxing row breaks out at the Commonwealth Games|date=4 October 2010|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> During the boxing competition there have been claims made by various teams including England and [[Botswana at the 2010 Commonwealth Games|Botswana]] that jabs were not being scored by judges. This was attributed to the removal of a white scoring zone placed on the boxers gloves which is usually present in amateur boxing events. The BBC commentating team also claimed there to be a bias in judges scores towards Indian competitors.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/commonwealth_games/delhi_2010/9073167.stm | title=Boxing: latest fiasco in troubled Games | publisher=Reuters| date=4 October 2010 | accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref>
===Cycling=== During the final of the Men’s [[Keirin]], Malaysian [[Azizulhasni Awang]] was disqualified for aggressive interference when he forced his way past two competitors. Race winner [[Josiah Ng]] said he was "mystified" over Awang's disqualification. In the semi-final round of the [[keirin]], Australia's [[Shane Perkins]] was disqualified for dangerous riding with the official reason not being made clear. Perkins subsequently won the classification race and was described by [[Chris Boardman]] from the BBC to "have aimed an angry V-sign at officials"; he gestured to the judges with his index and middle finger held together. No subsequent action was taken against Perkins who later said, "the officials need to go back to school", referencing poor decisions he felt had been made in the sprint and keirin events.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/commonwealthgames/8045839/Commonwealth-Games-2010-David-Daniell-wins-silver-medal-following-keirin-controversy.html| title=Commonwealth Games 2010: David Daniell wins silver medal following keirin controversy | work=The Telegraph| date=6 October 2010 | accessdate=8 October 2010| location=London| first=Brendan| last=Gallagher}}</ref>
===Swimming=== On another occasion, South African swimmer [[Roland Schoeman]] came under criticism when he referred to the crowd at the swimming as "going on like monkeys" in a post-race poolside interview. Schoeman's remarks came after he narrowly avoided being disqualified as he and England's [[Simon Burnett]] fell in at the start of the 50m freestyle when distracted by the crowd noise. The swimming has been persistently affected by Indian spectators ignoring etiquette and shouting out while the competitors were preparing for the start.<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/swimmer-roland-schoeman-in-deep-end-for-monkeys-comment/story-fn66fst6-1225936234884 Swimmer Roland Schoeman in deep end for 'monkeys' comment: The Australian]</ref> His comment was regarded as possibly being a racial ethnic slur, although he later said that the word was commonly used in South Africa to refer to mischievous behaviour. At an official press conference, organising committee secretary-general Lalit Bhanot took the complaints about monkeys literally. Not being aware of the complaints, Bhanot felt Delhi's wildlife was at issue: "We know especially at the swimming pool there are a lot of monkeys and we have made efforts to keep them away from the swimming pool."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/schoeman/story-fn66fst6-1225936210819|title=Swimmer Roland Schoeman slams Aussies over 'monkeys' slur incident|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===Wrestling=== Australian wrestler Hassene Fkiri was ejected from the 96 kg Greco-Roman competition and stripped of the silver medal after making an obscene gesture at the international [[International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles|FILA]] judges during the final. According to an Australian official, Fkiri was furious at his Indian rival Anil Kumar, who he accused of breaking the rules a number of times in the first period by holding Fkiri around the neck and head with two hands. The Australian received his first warning after he made a comment to the referee as he walked off the mat at the end of the two-minute period; when Kumar repeated the same move in the next round, Fkiri headbutted him and was issued a second warning. He then proceeded to swing his arms uncontrollably afterwards, which resulted in his third warning and eventual disqualification. After losing, Fkiri refused to shake hands with the victor.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/commonwealth-games-2010/comm-games-news/bird-brain-how-happy-fkiri-got-leaner-and-meaner--then-stripped-of-silver-20101006-167b2.html|title=Bird brain: how 'happy' Fkiri got leaner and meaner ... then stripped of silver|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=6 October 2010|first=Georgina|last=Robinson}}</ref>
==Reactions and responses== Responding to media concerns, the organisers said there were 48 hours to save the Games after warnings of a pull out.<ref name="guardian">{{Cite news|author1=Jason Burke in Delhi |author2=Owen Gibson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/sep/22/commonwealth-games-crisis-48-hours |title=Commonwealth Games given 48 hours to save itself | Sport |work=The Guardian|date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=23 September 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
Numerous [[Bollywood]] actors also expressed their dismay at the state of the Games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/commonwealth%20games/now-bollywood-brickbats-for-commonwealth-games-54047 |title=Now, Bollywood brickbats for Commonwealth Games |publisher=Ndtv.com |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref>
Four days before the start of the games, tickets for the opening, closing ceremonies, and the 100 m athletics were still not sold out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/29/3025464.htm|title=Thousands of tickets unsold in Delhi|date=29 September 2010|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] wrote that despite Kalmadi's "blind optimism", the games were not going to be the best ever. Instead, it wrote that it was "probably the most interesting."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/most-interesting-games-ever-20101014-16lly.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | first=Paul | last=Mulvey | title=Most interesting Games ever | date=14 October 2010}}</ref>
The [[2010 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] played a key role in improving the image of the Games. As athletes arrived and competitions started, many earlier critics changed their view. The Australian Sports Minister said that India could now aim for the [[Olympics]], and the President of the [[International Olympic Committee]], [[Jacques Rogge]], said that India had made a good foundation for a future Olympics bid.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/commonwealth%20games/india-should-aim-for-olympics-australian-sports-minister-57139|title=India should aim for Olympics: Australian Sports Minister|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=5 October 2010|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/commonwealth-games-2010/news/Games-good-foundation-for-Olympic-bid-by-India-Rogge/articleshow/6680736.cms|title=Games good foundation for Olympic bid by India: Rogge|work=[[Times of India]] | date=4 October 2010|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref> As the Games concluded, many observers remarked that they began on an apprehensive note, but were an exceptional experience with a largely positive ending.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/101015/sports/cgames2010_aus |title=Australia praises India's 'exceptional' Games |date=15 October 2010 |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/jamespearce/2010/10/did_delhi_live_up_to_expectati.html|title=Did Delhi live up to expectations?|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=14 October 2010}}</ref> Some observers accused sections of the media of bias, unfair expectations, and negative reporting.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/commonwealth-games-2010/comm-games-news/its-time-to-reflect-on-how-delhi-got-it-right-20101014-16ltt.html|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=15 October 2010|accessdate=16 October 2010|first=Peter|last=Hanlon|title=It's time to reflect on how Delhi got it right}}</ref>
Within India, the Games saw criticism due to the Games' origins as a celebration of the British Empire, with [[Arindam Chaudhuri]] arguing for India's disassociation from the "slavish games" which he viewed as a "celebration of racial discrimination, colonialism [and] imperialism".<ref>{{Cite web | last = Chaudhuri | first = Arindam | title =Instead of creating such hype around commonwealth games, India should have long ago stopped participating in these slavish games | work = The Sunday Indian | date = 26 September 2010 | url = http://thesundayindian.com/article.php?article_id=9555 | accessdate = 14 November 2010 }}</ref>
===Criticism by Mani Shankar Aiyar=== [[Mani Shankar Aiyar]], a senior member of the ruling [[Indian National Congress]] party and former [[Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports (India)|Minister of Youth and Sports Affairs]] was an early [[whistleblower]] from the [[Union Council of Ministers of India|Indian Union Cabinet]] who expressed concern over extensive delays in preparation leading to unplanned expenses which he said, could have been utilized for "ensuring a better sporting future for Indian children by providing them sports training".<ref name="ECOtimes1">{{cite news|author=, 02.27PM IST,IANS |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/BJP-Mani-Shankar-Aiyar-embarrass-government-on-Commonwealth-Games/articleshow/6223040.cms |title=BJP, Mani Shankar Aiyar embarrass government on Commonwealth Games |work=The Economic Times|date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref> Aiyar also said that he would be "unhappy" if the Games were a success and wished for the "Commonwealth Games to be spoiled."<ref name="ECOtimes1"/>
Aiyar's frank media admission proved a public embarrassment for Commonwealth Games Organising Committee chairman [[Suresh Kalmadi]] who labelled him "anti national" for wishing that the Commonwealth Games are "spoilt."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Suresh-Kalmadi-dubs-Mani-Shankar-Aiyar-anti-national/Article1-578503.aspx |title=Suresh Kalmadi dubs Mani Shankar Aiyar anti-national |work=Hindustan Times|date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref> Kalmadi's remark received extensive criticism in [[Media in India|Indian media]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Rajesh Kalra |url=http://blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/randomaccess/entry/patriotism-is-the-last-refuge |title='Patriotism is the last refuge of scoundrels' is no longer a mere quote : Sports : Rajesh Kalra : TOI Blogs |publisher=Blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |accessdate=7 September 2010}}</ref>
Aiyar also told an Australian TV channel that India is "probably the poorest country of the Commonwealth".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2010/s3023269.htm |title=The 7.30 Report |publisher=ABC |date=27 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> Bangladesh, among other countries, has a lower GDP per capita/purchasing power parity.
==Allegations of corruption and financial irregularities== The day after the conclusion of the Games, the Indian Government announced formation of a special committee to probe the allegations of corruption and mismanagement against the Organizing Committee (OC). The probe committee was led by former [[Comptroller and Auditor General of India]] VK Shunglu. This probe was in addition to the [[Directorate General of Income Tax Investigation]], [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI), [[Enforcement Directorate]], and [[Central Vigilance Commission]] (CVC) investigations already underway. The [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]], [[Manmohan Singh|Dr. Manmohan Singh]], had promised in mid-August, when reports of the bungling first surfaced, that corrupt officials will be given ''"severe and exemplary" punishment'' after the Games. The committee was given three months time to submit its report.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-10-16/india/28259235_1_probe-panel-oc-bosses-alleged-misappropriation|title=CWG: Probe panel to report in 3 months | work=[[Times of India]] |date=16 October 2010 |accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article832511.ece|title=Centre orders probe into CWG issues|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=16 October 2010|accessdate=16 October 2010|location=Chennai, India|first=J.|last=Balaji}}</ref>
A total of 53 corruption cases were being examined by the CVC. As of September 2012, 28 of them were still in different stages of investigation, 13 were referred to CBI for further investigation and 12 were closed.<ref name="CVC Okays Closure of 12 CWG Graft Related Cases">{{cite news|title=CVC Okays Closure of 12 CWG Graft Related Cases|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=775433|accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=The Outlook India|date=17 September 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Al6iAKJy?url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=775433|archivedate=18 September 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Timing-Scoring-Result (TSR) case=== This case relates to allegations of corruption in awarding TSR system contract to a Swiss firm <ref name="Kalmadi arrested by CBI in CWG scam case">{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/current-affairs/kalmadi-arrested-by-cbicwg-scam-case_538069.html|title=Kalmadi arrested by CBI in CWG scam case|date=25 April 2011|publisher= CNBC|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
====CBI investigation and chargesheet==== {{See also|First Information Report|Chargesheet}}
On 25 April 2011, CBI arrested former CWG Organising Committee (OC) chairman [[Suresh Kalmadi]] in the Timing-Scoring-Result (TSR) case. He was arrested under Sections 120 B (criminal conspiracy) and 420 (cheating) of the [[Indian Penal Code]].<ref name="Kalmadi arrested by CBI in CWG scam case"/>
On 20 May 2011, CBI filed the first [[chargesheet]] in a special CBI court against Kalmadi. The CBI alleged that he was the ''main accused'' in awarding TSR system contract to a Swiss firm. The chargesheet said, "Kalmadi is the main accused as he was the person with all supreme powers. He had the supreme over-riding powers in the Organising Committee of the CWG, 2010." In addition to Kalmadi, the CBI named two companies and eight persons including OC former Secretary General Lalit Bhanot and former Director General VK Verma as accused.<ref name="CWG: Court takes cognisance of chargesheet against Kalmadi">{{cite news|title=CWG: Court takes cognisance of chargesheet against Kalmadi|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/163568/content/216700/beauty-mathematics.html|accessdate=17 August 2012|newspaper=Deccan Herald|date=23 May 2011}}</ref><ref name="CWG scam: Kalmadi named 'main accused' in first CBI charge sheet">{{cite news|title=CWG scam: Kalmadi named ‘main accused' in first CBI charge sheet|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2035048.ece|accessdate=17 August 2012|newspaper=The Hindu|date=20 May 2011}}</ref>
The accused were charged under various provisions of the [[Indian Penal Code]] sections dealing with criminal conspiracy, forging documents and using fake documents as genuine, Section 13 (1) (d) of the [[Prevention of Corruption Act (India)|Prevention of Corruption Act]].<ref name="CWG scam: Kalmadi named 'main accused' in first CBI charge sheet"/><ref name="CWG scam: CBI files first chargesheet against Suresh Kalmadi, 8 others">{{cite news|title=CWG scam: CBI files first chargesheet against Suresh Kalmadi, 8 others|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/cwg-scam-cbi-files-first-chargesheet-against-suresh-kalmadi-8-others-107198|accessdate=17 August 2012|newspaper=NDTV|date=20 May 2011}}</ref>
According to the charge sheet, the accused allegedly awarded the lucrative contract to the Swiss firm to install a TSR system for the Commonwealth Games at an excessive cost, causing a loss of over {{INRConvert|900|m}} to the exchequer. The investigation revealed that officials of the OC had conspired with private persons for awarding the contract at an excessive net cost of about {{INRConvert|1576|m}} as compared to a net bid of Spain-based company for approximately {{INRConvert|620|m}}. This resulted in a loss of about {{INRConvert|956|m}} by wrongly eliminating all competitors of Swiss-based company.<ref name="CWG scam: Kalmadi named 'main accused' in first CBI charge sheet"/><ref name="CWG scam: CBI files first chargesheet against Suresh Kalmadi, 8 others"/> Two bids were received for TSR contract from Swiss Timing and MSL Spain and they were opened on 4 November 2009. However, much before that, on 12 October 2009, Kalmadi and Verma had announced that the contract would be awarded to Swiss Timing.<ref name="CWG: Charge Framing Order Against Kalmadi on 21 Nov">{{cite news|title=CWG: Charge Framing Order Against Kalmadi on Nov 21|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=777627|accessdate=8 October 2012|newspaper=Outlook India|date=8 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306190336/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=777627#|archive-date=6 March 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Trial==== {{See also|Trial}}
On 4 February 2013, the court of special CBI judge Ravinder Kaur found sufficient prima facie evidence and ordered framing of charges against all the accused. The charges framed were: cheating, forgery, criminal conspiracy and causing a loss of over Rs 900 million under the [[Prevention of Corruption Act (India)|Prevention of Corruption Act]]. As the accused pleaded not guilty, the court ordered that daily [[Trial|Criminal trial]] (for 5 days a week) will begin from 20 February.<ref name="Suresh Kalmadi charged with criminal conspiracy">{{cite news|title=Suresh Kalmadi charged with criminal conspiracy|url=http://www.niticentral.com/2013/02/kalmadi-charged-with-criminal-conspiracy.html|accessdate=7 February 2013|newspaper=Niti Central|date=4 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208144426/http://www.niticentral.com/2013/02/kalmadi-charged-with-criminal-conspiracy.html#|archive-date=8 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="CWG: Court Frames Charges Against Kalmadi, 9 Others">{{cite news|title=CWG: Court Frames Charges Against Kalmadi, 9 Others|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=788818|accessdate=7 February 2013|newspaper=Outlook India|date=4 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204234833/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=788818#|archive-date=4 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Queen's Baton Relay (QBR) case=== {{further|Queen's Baton Relay}}
The QBR event was held on 29 October 2009. The allegation was that, the Organising Committee (OC) awarded the work of transportation in QBR event to AM Car and Van Hire Ltd at excessively high rates without following a standard tender process.<ref name="CBI to file chargesheet in Queen’s baton scam">{{cite news|title=CBI to file chargesheet in Queen’s baton scam|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-09/india/29867663_1_standard-tender-process-chargesheet-suresh-kalmadi|accessdate=18 August 2012|newspaper=The Times of India|date=9 August 2011}}</ref>
After completing investigations, CBI filed its second charge-sheet (after the charge-sheet in TSR case) in a special CBI court in Delhi. The CBI named OC officials T S Darbari, Sanjay Mohindroo, Jeychandran and London-based businessman Ashish Patel and his two companies AM Car n Van Hire and AM Films. The chargesheet alleged that OC members conspired to award contracts of local transportation and others to Patel's companies at excessive rates during the event held in London in 2009.<ref name="CBI Chargesheet in One More CWG Scam Case">{{cite news|title=CBI Chargesheet in One More CWG Scam Case|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=772380|accessdate=18 August 2012|newspaper=Outlook India|date=17 August 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818015315/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=772380#|archive-date=18 August 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
