{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} The '''Downing Street memo''' (or the '''Downing Street Minutes'''), sometimes described by critics of the [[Iraq War]] as the '''smoking gun memo''', is the note of a 23 July 2002 secret meeting{{Cite web |url=http://www.iraqinquiry.org.uk/ |title=Iraq Inquiry - Home |website=www.iraqinquiry.org.uk |accessdate=6 July 2016}}{{Cite web |url=http://downingstreetmemo.com/memos.html |title=The Downing Street Memos :: The text |last=citizens |first=concerned |website=downingstreetmemo.com |accessdate=6 July 2016}} of senior British government, defence and intelligence figures discussing the build-up to the war, which included direct reference to classified [[United States]] policy of the time. The name refers to [[10 Downing Street]], the residence of the [[List of Prime Ministers of the United Kingdom|British prime minister]]. The memo, written by Downing Street foreign policy aide [[Matthew Rycroft]], recorded the head of the [[Secret Intelligence Service]] (MI6) as expressing the view following his recent visit to Washington that "[[George W. Bush|[George W.] Bush]] wanted to remove [[Saddam Hussein]], through military action, justified by the conjunction of terrorism and WMD. But the intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy." It quoted [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Jack Straw]] as saying it was clear that Bush had "made up his mind" to take military action but that "the case was thin." Straw also noted that Iraq retained "WMD capability" and that "Saddam would continue to play hard-ball with the UN." The military asked about the consequences "if Saddam used WMD on day one," posing Kuwait or Israel as potential targets. Attorney-General [[Lord Goldsmith]] warned that justifying the invasion on legal grounds would be difficult. However, the meeting took place several months before the adoption of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1441]], the resolution eventually used as the legal basis for the invasion of Iraq. UNR687 also provided a pre-existing basis, as it required Iraq to divest itself of "100%" of all WMD capacity, which the Memo agreed it had not. A copy of the memo was obtained by British journalist [[Michael Smith (newspaper reporter)|Michael Smith]] and published in ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]]'' in May 2005, on the eve of British elections. Smith stated that the memo was equivalent to the [[Pentagon Papers]] which exposed American intentions in the [[Vietnam War]] and alleged the American media did not report more about it due to a perceived bias towards support for the war.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2005/06/14/DI2005061401261.html |title=The Downing Street Memo |author=Michael Smith |publisher=Washington Post |date=16 June 2005 |accessdate=10 August 2014}} Though its authenticity has never been seriously challenged, the British and American governments have stated that the contents do not accurately reflect their official policy positions at the time. == Introduction == The memo was first published in ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]]'' on 1 May 2005, during the last days of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005 |UK general election]] campaign.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article387374.ece|title=The secret Downing Street memo |work=[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]] |location=London |date=1 May 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723222004/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article387374.ece |archivedate=23 July 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2007}} It went largely unremarked in the U.S. press at first, but was heavily covered in progressive [[blog]]s such as those on [[Daily Kos]], because of a remark attributed to [[Richard Dearlove]] (then MI6 head) that "the intelligence and facts were being fixed [by the U.S.] around the policy" of removing [[Saddam Hussein]] from power, which was interpreted to show that US intelligence on Iraq prior to the war was deliberately falsified, rather than simply mistaken.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |title=Why has "Downing Street memo" story been a "dud" in US? |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310182232/http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |archivedate=10 March 2007 |accessdate=17 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} As this issue began to be covered by American media (''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' on 12 May 2005, ''[[Washington Post]]'' on 13 May 2005, two other main allegations stemming from the memo arose: that the UN weapons inspection process was manipulated to provide a legal pretext for the war, and that pre-war air strikes were deliberately ramped up in order to soften Iraqi infrastructure in preparation for war, prior to the October U.S. Senate vote permitting the invasion.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/05/12/AR2005051201857.html |title=British Intelligence Warned of Iraq War:Blair Was Told of White House's Determination to Use Military Against Hussein |work=[[Washington Post]] |date=13 May 2005 |first=Walter |last=Pincus |accessdate=27 March 2007}} Some elements of the U.S. media have portrayed the document as faked or fraudulent, and Dana Perino referred in her daily White House press briefing on 4 December 2008 to the fact that the Bush administration has "debunked" the document previously. The British have tacitly validated its authenticity (as when Tony Blair replied to a press conference question by saying "that memorandum was written before we then went to the United Nations."{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2005/06/20050607-2.html |title=whitehouse.gov |accessdate=4 November 2008}}) A group of 131 [[members of Congress]] led by [[John Conyers]], repeatedly requested that [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] respond to the contents of the document. A resolution of inquiry was filed by Representative [[Barbara Lee]], which would request that the President and the [[State Department]] turn over all relevant information with regard to US policy towards Iraq. The resolution had 70 co-sponsors.{{cite web |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:HE00375:@@@P |title=Thomas Query for current number |accessdate=11 March 2006}} == Outline ==
'''Addressees of the memo'''
Copies of the minutes were sent to: *[[Secretary of State for Defence]] [[Geoff Hoon]], *[[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs]] [[Jack Straw (politician)|Jack Straw]], *[[Attorney General of England and Wales]] [[Peter Goldsmith, Baron Goldsmith|Lord Goldsmith]], *[[Cabinet Secretary]] [[Richard Thomas James Wilson|Sir Richard Wilson]], *Chairman of the [[UK Joint Intelligence Committee|Joint Intelligence Committee]] [[John Scarlett]], *Director of the [[Government Communications Headquarters]] [[Francis Richards (diplomat)|Francis Richards]], *[[Chief of the Defence Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Defence Staff]] [[Michael Boyce, Baron Boyce|Sir Michael Boyce]], *Head of the [[Secret Intelligence Service]] [[Richard Dearlove]], *Prime Minister's Chief of Staff [[Jonathan Powell (chief of staff to Tony Blair)|Jonathan Powell]], *Downing Street Director of Government Relations [[Sally Morgan, Baroness Morgan of Huyton|Sally Morgan]], and *Downing Street Director of Communications and Strategy [[Alastair Campbell]].
The minutes were meant to be kept confidential and were headed "This record is extremely sensitive. No further copies should be made. It should be shown only to those with a genuine need to know its contents." It deals with the lead-up to the 2003 [[Iraq War]], and comes at a point at which it becomes clear to those attending, that US President George W. Bush intended to remove Saddam Hussein from power by force. The minutes run through the military options and then consider the political strategy in which an appeal for support from the international community and from domestic opinion would be most likely to be positively received. It suggests that an [[ultimatum]] for Saddam to allow back [[United Nations]] weapons inspectors be issued, and that this would help to make the use of force legal. Tony Blair is quoted as saying that the British public would support [[regime change]] in the right political context. The most controversial paragraph is a report of a recent visit to Washington by head of the [[Secret Intelligence Service]] Sir Richard Dearlove (known in official terminology as 'C'): {{quote|C reported on his recent talks in Washington. There was a perceptible shift in attitude. Military action was now seen as inevitable. Bush wanted to remove Saddam, through military action, justified by the conjunction of terrorism and [[Weapons of mass destruction|WMD]]. But the intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy. The [[United States National Security Council|NSC]] had no patience with the UN route, and no enthusiasm for publishing material on the Iraqi regime's record. There was little discussion in Washington of the aftermath after military action.}} The British analysis of US policy is also stated elsewhere in the minutes: {{quote|The Defence Secretary said that the US had already begun "spikes of activity" to put pressure on the regime. No decisions had been taken, but he thought the most likely timing in US minds for military action to begin was January, with the timeline beginning 30 days before the US Congressional elections. The Foreign Secretary said he would discuss this with [[Colin Powell]] this week. It seemed clear that Bush had made up his mind to take military action, even if the timing was not yet decided. But the case was thin. Saddam was not threatening his neighbours, and his WMD capability was less than that of Libya, North Korea or Iran. We should work up a plan for an ultimatum to Saddam to allow back in the UN weapons inspectors. This would also help with the legal justification for the use of force. The Attorney-General said that the desire for regime change was not a legal base for military action. There were three possible legal bases: self-defence, humanitarian intervention, or UNSC authorisation. The first and second could not be the base in this case. Relying on [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1205|UNSCR 1205]] of three years ago would be difficult. The situation might of course change.}} The main sections covering the ultimatum are: {{quote|The Prime Minister said that it would make a big difference politically and legally if Saddam refused to allow in the UN inspectors. There were different strategies for dealing with Libya and Iran. Regime change and WMD were linked in the sense that it was the regime that was producing the WMD. If the political context were right, people would support regime change. The two key issues were whether the military plan worked and whether we had the political strategy to give the military plan the space to work. ...John Scarlett assessed that Saddam would allow the inspectors back in only when he thought the threat of military action was real. The Defence Secretary said that if the Prime Minister wanted UK military involvement, he would need to decide this early. He cautioned that many in the US did not think it worth going down the ultimatum route. It would be important for the Prime Minister to set out the political context to Bush.}} The minutes also outlines potential risks of an invasion of Iraq: {{quote|For instance, what were the consequences, if Saddam used WMD on day one, or if Baghdad did not collapse and urban warfighting began? You said that Saddam could also use his WMD on Kuwait. Or on Israel, added the Defence Secretary.}} == Reaction == === Proponents of an inquiry === In the United States, proponents of a formal congressional inquiry say that the minutes, along with testimonies from credible witnesses, shed sufficient doubt on the actions of the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] to warrant a formal inquiry. In particular, they say that the minutes indicate that the Administration was determined to go to war with Iraq prior to considerations of legality, and with full knowledge that, at best, "the case was slim." And furthermore that they [[confirmation bias|selected and exaggerated intelligence so as to confirm]] their policy and developed a plan to manipulate public opinion. Also, proponents say that the contents (such as "Military action was now seen as inevitable.") and the ''date'' of the memo, 23 July 2002, contradicts the official White House position that President Bush did not finally decide to carry out the invasion of March 2003 until after [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Colin L. Powell]] presented the administration's case to the [[United Nations Security Council]], in a speech on 5 February 2003. They also say that the minutes are dated at a time when Bush stated that "we haven't made any decisions on Iraq, but all options are on the table." Another paragraph has been taken to show that [[Geoff Hoon]] believed the timing of the war was intended to influence American elections: {{quote|The Defence Secretary said that the US had already begun "spikes of activity" to put pressure on the regime. No decisions had been taken, but he thought the most likely timing in US minds for military action to begin was January, with the timeline beginning 30 days before the US Congressional elections.}} It has been said that some of those present at the meeting believed that Iraq might possess [[weapons of mass destruction]] (WMD) "capacity". However, the minutes explicitly state that the capability was less than that of Libya, Iran, and North Korea, and that Saddam was not threatening his neighbours. === U.S. Congress === On 5 May 2005, Democratic [[Congressman]] [[John Conyers]] sent [[Wikisource:Letter from Congress regarding Downing Street memo|a letter]] to President Bush signed by 89 of his colleagues demanding an explanation of the "troubling revelations" in the memo. No specific White House response to the letter was ever made publicly. In response to the Bush Administration's refusal to answer the congressional delegation's questions, Conyers et al. considered sending a fact-finding mission to the UK.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-1622378,00.html |title=Blair faces US probe over secret Iraq invasion plan |author1=Tony Allen-Mills |author2=Tom Pattinson |date=22 May 2005 |work=The Sunday Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060107023337/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-1622378,00.html |archivedate=7 January 2006 |location=London}} Conyers initially requested 100,000 signatures from citizens (a petition) to request that President Bush answer the questions in his letter. The letter began accumulating between 20,000 and 25,000 signatures a day, boosted by progressive political action group [[MoveOn.org]], which joined the campaign on 9 June. By 13 June 2005, the letter had received over 540,000 signatures from citizens, and more congressmen had signed on, bringing the total to 94 – three days later, over 100 congressmen had signed the letter, including then-[[Minority Leader of the United States House of Representatives|Minority Leader]] [[Nancy Pelosi]]. On 16 June 2005, Conyers presided over an [[unofficial hearing]] or forum on the Downing Street memo in a basement room in the Capitol where notable opponents of the Iraq War [[Joseph C. Wilson]], [[Ray McGovern]] and [[Cindy Sheehan]], among others, testified.{{cite web |url=http://www.house.gov/conyers |title=Congressman John Conyers, Jr. Home Page |accessdate=11 March 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://www.downingstreetmemo.com/related.html |title=The Downing Street Memos :: Related Info and Documents |accessdate=11 March 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://afterdowningstreet.org |title=AfterDowningstreet.org |accessdate=11 March 2006}} === Internet === Smintheus at [http://www.dailykos.com Daily Kos], a liberal web site,{{cite web| url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2005/4/30/234527/228 |title=Iraq: The Fix was on in July, 2002 |last=smintheus |date=30 April 2005 |work=Daily Kos |accessdate=11 March 2006}} and MYDD{{cite web |url=http://smintheus.mydd.com/story/2005/5/1/12746/88844 |title=Iraq: Fix was on in July, 2002 |last=smintheus| date=1 May 2005 |work=MYDD |accessdate=11 March 2006}} first addressed the memo on the night of 30 April 2005. By the next morning the document was elevated to a major story on the Daily Kos,{{cite web |url=http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2005/5/1/115530/0288 |title=Bush / Iraq Bombshell This Morning |last=smintheus |date=1 May 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006}} where Democratic Congressman John Conyers learned of its existence. A website, www.downingstreetmemo.com,{{cite web |url=http://www.downingstreetmemo.com |title=The Downing Street Memo(s) |accessdate=11 March 2006}} was created on 13 May, "to fill a void left by the American mainstream media," and continues with its primary aim "to provide a resource for anyone who wants to understand the meaning and context of these documents as they relate to the Bush administration's case for war." On 30 May 2005, in a "blogswarm" fueled by the memo,{{cite web |url=http://www.blogpulse.com/trend?query1=%22downing+street+memo%22&label1=downing+street+memo&query2=%22big+brass+alliance%22&label2=big+brass+alliance&query3=%22downing+street+minutes%22&label3=downing+street+minutes&query4=afterdowningstreet.org&label4=afterdowningstreet&query5=blogswarm&label5=blogswarm&days=180&x=23&y=8 |title=Blogpulse Tools Trend Results |accessdate=11 March 2006}} hundreds of blogs joined together to form the Big Brass Alliance in support of After Downing Street. On 1 June 2005 a targeted media campaign called 'Awaken the Mainstream Media' began jointly at Daily Kos{{cite web |url=http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2005/6/1/74549/88811 |title=Awaken the MSM: Downing Street Memo Alert (6/1) |last=smintheus |date=1 June 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006}} and downingstreetmemo.com.{{cite web |url=http://www.downingstreetmemo.com/takeaction.html |title=The Downing Street Memos :: Take Action! |accessdate=11 March 2006}} Every day it listed new contact information for three news outlets, so that readers could contact them to urge them to provide better coverage of the issues around the Downing Street memo and other released documents. === Pundits === On 18 May, conservative pundit and former [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan Administration]] advisor [[Paul Craig Roberts]] wrote an article calling for Bush's [[impeachment in the United States|impeachment]] for lying to Congress about the case for war.{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/roberts/roberts101.html| title= A Reputation in Tatters| first=Paul Craig| last=Roberts| date=17 May 2005| accessdate=11 March 2006}} On 31 May, liberal consumer advocate and former Presidential hopeful [[Ralph Nader]] wrote an article on [[ZNet]] calling for Bush and Cheney’s impeachment under [[Article Two of the United States Constitution#Impeachment|Article II, Section 4]] of the [[United States Constitution]].{{cite web| url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/data/constitution/article02/18.html#1| title=FindLaw: US Constitution: Article II: Annotations pg. 18 of 18|work=Findlaw| accessdate=11 March 2006}} Also on that day, he and [[Kevin Zeese]] authored an [[op-ed]] for the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' to support the call for [[Movement to impeach George W. Bush|impeachment against Bush]], citing the memo as part of the evidence that the possibility of deliberate deception by the administration should be investigated.{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2005/05/31/the_i_word/| title=The 'I' word| author=Ralph Nader and Kevin Zeese| date=31 May 2005|work=The Boston Globe| accessdate=11 March 2006}} On 30 January 2006, an article entitled ''The Impeachment of George W. Bush'',{{cite web| url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20060130/holtzman | title= The Impeachment of George W. Bush| accessdate=17 September 2006}} written by [[Elizabeth Holtzman]] (Rep. NY-D 1973–1981, member of the House Judiciary Committee that held impeachment hearings of President [[Richard Nixon]]) was published by the left-wing periodical ''[[The Nation]]''. The article makes specific references to the Downing Street memo. ===Political groups=== A coalition of American groups known as [[After Downing Street]], co-founded by a group of longtime progressive and/or Democratic Party activists,afterdowningstreet.org, [http://afterdowningstreet.org/cofounders Co-Founders]. Retrieved 28 March 2007 called on Congress to file a '''Resolution of Inquiry''', the first necessary legal step to determine whether President Bush had committed impeachable offences.{{cite web| url=http://rawstory.com/exclusives/alexandrovna/coalition_inquiry_downing_street_memo_526.htm| title= Coalition of citizen groups seek formal inquiry into whether Bush acted illegally in push for Iraq war| first= Larisa| last=Alexandrovna|work=The Raw Story| accessdate=11 March 2006}} The formal Resolution of Inquiry request was written by [[Boston]] constitutional attorney [[John C. Bonifaz]].{{cite web|url=http://rawstory.com/exclusives/alexandrovna/memo_bush_impeachable_offenses_526.htm| title= The memo: Boston constitutional lawyer seeks Resolution of Inquiry on Iraq| accessdate=11 March 2006}} The request states the constitutional grounds for impeachment: {{quote|[The US President] has not given [the Senate] full information, but has concealed important intelligence which he ought to have communicated, and by that means induced them to enter into measures injurious to their country, and which they would not have consented to had the true state of things been disclosed to them.}} Democrats.com raised one thousand dollars, offered as a reward to anyone who could get George Bush to answer the following question "Yes" or "No: {{quote|In July 2002, did you and your administration "fix" the intelligence and facts about non-existent Iraqi WMD's and ties to terrorism — which were disputed by US intelligence officials — to sell your decision to invade Iraq to Congress, the American People, and the world — as quoted in the Downing Street Minutes?}} In addition a number of lesser prizes were offered for lesser responses, down to a $100 for posing the question clearly to Bush.{{cite web| url=http://www.democrats.com/bush-question1| title=$1000 Reward For Getting Bush to Answer Downing Street Minutes| first= Bob| last= Fertik| date=28 May 2005| accessdate=11 March 2006}} == News coverage == The Downing Street Minutes was a major story in the British press during the last few days of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election campaign]] and was also covered in other countries. The story initially had limited coverage in the US but later recently received greater attention in the American press. The organisation [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting]] has been among those that have criticised the US print media, saying they "continue to downplay [the] story." According to [[Media Matters for America]],{{cite web |url=http://mediamatters.org/items/200506160002 |date=16 June 2005|title=Mainstream media cover-up: In five weeks following its disclosure, Downing Street memo drew little attention |accessdate=11 March 2006}} there were some early mentions in ''[[The New York Times]]'', the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', the ''[[New York Sun]]'', and the ''[[Washington Post]]'', though coverage was slight (the ''Post'''s first article appeared in the "Style" section) and primarily aimed at the impact it would have on the British elections, rather than how it affected the Bush administration. The [[Knight-Ridder]] news service produced some reportage at the time, but independent articles were limited. The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' and ''[[Star Tribune]]'' put local reporters on the story, and produced early articles on 12 May and 13 May, respectively. At the ''Star Tribune'', initial interest had been piqued after a reader e-mailed information he had seen on the Internet to the paper's [[ombudsman]], who forwarded it to others in the news department. Being quite a distance from London, editors first waited for articles to come across on wire services. Undoubtedly, many other newspapers across the country reacted similarly. After a few days of no news, however, a local reporter was assigned. The article was initially scheduled to run on 11 May, but was pushed back so that it could have greater prominence on a slower news day later in the week.{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/stories/1519/5451062.html |title=404 error |accessdate=11 March 2006}} Since that time, much of the coverage about the memo has discussed the lack of coverage. One of the first reports include that topic was a 17 May article in the ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]''. The report was one of the most extensive for a nationwide publication up until that time.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |title=Why has 'Downing Street memo' story been a 'dud' in US? |first=Matthew |last=Clark |work=Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=11 March 2006 |date=17 May 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060207140057/http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |archivedate=7 February 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 20 May 2005, [[Daniel Okrent]], the Public Editor at the time for ''The New York Times'', publicly assessed the coverage of the minutes in the paper in a forum on the NYT's website. He also stated that, due to continuing reader interest, the paper intends to give fuller coverage to the memo.{{cite news |url=http://forums.nytimes.com/top/opinion/readersopinions/forums/thepubliceditor/danielokrent/index.html?offset=47&fid=.f555e99/47 |title=Registration required for access|work=The New York Times |accessdate=11 March 2006}} Although Okrent stepped down at the end of May (the routine end of his term), on ''NewsHour'' on 8 June he suggested some possible reasons that the US media had been so slow to cover what he considered a very important story. He said it may have been assigned to 'foreign news' correspondents and wasn't seen as a Bush story, or it may be the US media was still working on researching it (although he then admitted he had no reason to believe that).{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/media/jan-june05/ombuds_6-8.html |title=NewsHour transcript, audio and video |accessdate=11 March 2006}} Also on 8 June, ''[[USA Today]]'' printed an article by their senior assignment editor for foreign news, Jim Cox, saying with respect to the memo, "We could not obtain the memo or a copy of it from a reliable source. … There was no explicit confirmation of its authenticity from (Blair's office). And it was disclosed four days before the British elections, raising concerns about the timing." The ''Star Tribune'' revisited the Downing Street Minutes as part of the evidence in a [[Memorial Day]] editorial.{{cite web |url=http://www.startribune.com/stories/1519/5427823.html |title=Editorial: Memorial Day/Praise bravery, seek forgiveness|date=30 May 2005|work=Star Tribune|accessdate=19 March 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050531234547/http://www.startribune.com/stories/1519/5427823.html |archivedate = 31 May 2005}} It stated explicitly, {{quote|President Bush and those around him lied, and the rest of us let them. Harsh? Yes. True? Also yes. Perhaps it happened because Americans, understandably, don't expect untruths from those in power. But that works better as an explanation than as an excuse.... It turns out that former counterterrorism chief [[Richard A. Clarke|Richard Clarke]] and former Treasury Secretary [[Paul O'Neill (businessman)|Paul O'Neill]] were right. Both have been pilloried for writing that by summer 2002 Bush had already decided to invade.}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported on the memos on 27 March 2006.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/27/international/europe/27memo.html?_r=1&oref=slogin |title=Bush Was Set on Path to War, British Memo Says |first=Don |last=Van Natta Jr. |date=27 March 2006 |accessdate=29 March 2006|work=New York Times}} [[MSNBC]] reported on the memos on 28 March 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12051310/ |title=Author says Bush war bound from beginning|publisher=MSNBC |date=28 March 2006 |accessdate=29 March 2006}} MSNBC has an article and a video clip from ''[[NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams]]''.{{cite web |url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/8207731/ |title=More British memos on prewar concerns Officials deny intelligence that facts were fixed to invade Iraq |first=Andrea |last=Mitchell|publisher=NBC News |date=14 June 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006}} The Columbian newspaper ''El Tiempo'' implicated the Prime Minister's role in the [[Iraq War]] on 9 May 2007 – and the Downing Street memo specifically – as "the principal reason for the UK's disillusionment with Tony Blair."[http://www.eltiempo.com/opinion/columnistas/otroscolumnistas/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR-3550290.html ''El Tiempo'' 9 May 2007] The Chilean newspaper ''[[La Segunda]]'' on 11 May 2007 called the Downing Street memo "one of the best-kept secrets in [[Tony Blair|Tony Blair's]] ten years as prime minister." One of the first articles on the memo to appear in the US media quoted "a former senior US official", who, speaking on condition of anonymity, called the memo's account "an absolutely accurate description of what transpired" during the senior British intelligence officer's visit to Washington. UK [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Tony Blair]] denied that anything in the memo demonstrated misconduct and said that it added little to what was already known about how British policy on Iraq developed, also commenting that "that memorandum was written before we went to the United Nations".{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2005/06/07/national/w152752D27.DTL |title=Text of Bush, Blair News Conference |agency=The Associated Press |date=7 June 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050915140748/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2005%2F06%2F07%2Fnational%2Fw152752D27.DTL |archivedate=15 September 2005 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy}} *White House spokesman [[Scott McClellan]], US Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] and UK Foreign Secretary [[Jack Straw (politician)|Jack Straw]] did not confirm or deny the accuracy of the memo when questioned about it.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} *George W. Bush has not responded to questions from Congress regarding the memo's accuracy. *When asked about the contents of the memo by [[Plaid Cymru]] MP Adam Price in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] on 29 June 2005, Blair again refrained from disputing the document's authenticity, saying only "[…]that memo and other documents of the time were covered by the Butler review. In addition, that was before we went to the United Nations and secured the second resolution, [[Resolution 1441|1441]], which had unanimous support."{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/cm050629/debtext/50629-02.htm#50629-02_dpthd0 |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 29 Jun 2005 (pt 2) |accessdate=11 March 2006}} *According to CNN, currently classified documents which were dated at the same month as the Downing Street memo, March 2002, were uncovered in Iraq, and contained evidence that Russian intelligence notified Iraq about the "determination of the United States and Britain to launch military action."{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/meast/04/13/sprj.irq.russia.spy/index.html |title=Russia spied for Iraq – paper |date=13 April 2003|publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=11 March 2006}} === US President George W. Bush === On 7 June 2005, at a joint George W. Bush-Tony Blair press briefing in the [[White House]], [[Reuters]] correspondent Steve Holland asked, "On Iraq, the so-called Downing Street memo from July 2002 says intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy of removing Saddam through military action. Is this an accurate reflection of what happened? Could both of you respond?" President Bush did not address the issue of the intelligence and facts being "fixed" around a decision to go to war, but he did deny that he had, at the time of the memo, already decided to use military force against Saddam Hussein, saying "There's nothing farther from the truth." Bush also questioned the motives of whoever leaked the memo during the British election, saying "Well, I—you know, I read kind of the characterisations of the memo, particularly when they dropped it out in the middle of his race. … I'm not sure who 'they dropped it out' is, but—I'm not suggesting that you all dropped it out there."{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/p/eur/rls/rm/47330.htm |title=President Welcomes British Prime Minister Blair to the White House |date=7 May 2005 |accessdate=19 March 2007 |publisher=U.S. Department of State |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315012654/http://www.state.gov/p/eur/rls/rm/47330.htm |archivedate=15 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} === UK Prime Minister Tony Blair === When the document was published, UK Prime Minister Tony Blair denied that anything in the memo demonstrated misconduct and said that it added little to what was already known about how British policy on Iraq developed. Blair's response to Steve Holland at the joint news conference with Bush was "No, the facts were not being fixed in any shape or form at all". He also reiterated that he and Bush had continued to try to find a way to avert war, "As it happened, we weren't able to do that because – as I think was very clear – there was no way that Saddam Hussein was ever going to change the way that he worked, or the way that he acted,". He said the same thing in a 7 June 2005 interview with [[Gwen Ifill]] on ''[[The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/international/jan-june05/blair_6-07.html |work=Online NewsHour: |title=Tony Blair Discusses US Aid to Africa, the EU Constitution and the Downing Street Memo |date=7 June 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006}} === White House spokesman Scott McClellan === On 16 May, presidential spokesman [[Scott McClellan]] said that the memo's statement that intelligence was "being fixed" to support a decision to invade Iraq was "flat out wrong". However, McClellan admitted that he has not read the memo, but has only received reports of what it contains.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/US/05/16/iraq.memo/ |title=White House challenges UK Iraq memo |date=17 May 2005|publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=11 March 2006}} On 17 May, McClellan told reporters that the White House saw "no need" to respond to the letter from Congress.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/20/politics/20weapons.html |title=British Memo on US Plans for Iraq War Fuels Critics |first=Douglas |last=Jehl |date=20 May 2005 |accessdate=11 March 2006 |work=The New York Times}} On 23 May, when BTC News reporter Eric Brewer asked him about his 16 May statement,{{cite web |url=http://www.btcnews.com/btcnews/index.php?p=964 |title=BTC News White House writer Eric Brewer on "The Brad Show" |accessdate=11 March 2006}} McClellan said: {{quote|Let me correct you... let me correct you on the characterisation of the quote you attributed to me. I’m referring to some of the allegations that were made referring to a report. In terms of the intelligence, the – if anyone wants to know how the intelligence was used by the administration, all they have to do is go back and look at all the public comments over the course of the lead-up to the war in Iraq, and that's all very public information. Everybody who was there could see how we used that intelligence.{{cite web |url=http://www.btcnews.com/btcnews/index.php?p=953 |title=White House does not dispute substance of Downing Street Memo |accessdate=11 March 2006}}}} The following day, a popular political blog, [[ThinkProgress]], posted a response titled "[https://web.archive.org/web/20080221073216/http://thinkprogress.org/index.php?p=951 Take the McClellan Challenge]", comparing what the intelligence was with how it was used by the administration.{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/index.php?p=951 |title=Take the McClellan Challenge |accessdate=6 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429094859/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article527701.ece |archivedate=29 April 2011 |df=dmy}} === US Secretary of State Rice and UK Foreign Secretary Straw === On 1 May 2005, US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and UK Foreign Secretary Jack Straw were questioned on the memo, although neither was able to give a detailed answer. Straw stated that he had not expected the question to come up.{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2005/46412.htm |title=Remarks with British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw After Meeting |publisher=US Department of State |accessdate=11 March 2006 |date=17 May 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060307115041/http://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2005/46412.htm |archivedate=7 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} ==Veracity of the memo== Following the advice of company lawyers, [[Michael Smith (newspaper reporter)|Michael Smith]], the journalist who first reported on the Downing Street Memo, has said that he protected the identity of his source by reproducing all documents and returning the 'originals' back to the source. In some cases, a document was retyped from a photocopy, and the photocopy destroyed.[http://www.downingstreetmemo.com/msmith-interview.html Interview with Michael Smith] [[DowningStreetMemo.com]] 27 June 2005 This has led some to question the document's authenticity, but no official source has questioned it, and it has been unofficially confirmed to various news organisations, including the Washington Post, NBC, The Sunday Times, and the LA Times. Several other documents obtained by Smith, and treated similarly (see below), were confirmed as genuine by the UK Foreign Office.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/guardianpolitics/story/0,,1308223,00.html| title=Leaks cast doubt on PM's motive| author=Ewen MacAskill and Michael White| date= 20 September 2004|work=The Guardian | accessdate=11 March 2006 | location=London}} == Additional documents == {{Main article|Iraq document leak 18 September 2004}} Previous to the appearance of the Downing Street Memo, six other British (Blair) Cabinet papers originating around March 2002 were obtained by [[Michael Smith (newspaper reporter)|Michael Smith]] and used in two ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' stories{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2004/09/18/nwar118.xml| title=Failure is not an option, but it doesn't mean they will avoid it| first=Michael|last=Smith| date=18 September 2004| accessdate=11 March 2006|work=Telegraph | location=London}}{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2004/09/18/nwar18.xml| title=Secret papers show Blair was warned of Iraq chaos| first=Michael| last=Smith| date=18 September 2004| accessdate=11 March 2006 | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London}} published on 18 September 2004. The documents describe issues relating to the meetings held between Bush and Blair at Bush's Crawford, Texas, ranch in April 2002. They are: #Iraq: Options Paper, prepared by the Overseas & Defence Secretariat in the Cabinet Office, dated 8 March 2002, describing options available for pursuing regime change in Iraq # Iraq: Legal Background, prepared by the Foreign & Commonwealth Office Legal Department, dated 8 March 2002 # a report from [[David Manning]] to Tony Blair on his meeting with Condoleezza Rice, dated 14 March 2002 # a report from [[Christopher Meyer]] to [[David Manning]] on his meeting with [[Paul Wolfowitz]], dated 18 March 2002 # a memo from [[Peter Ricketts]], Political Director, Foreign & Commonwealth Office, to the Foreign Secretary, [[Jack Straw (politician)|Jack Straw]], dated 22 March 2002, with background and opinion for Straw's advice to Tony Blair ahead of his meeting with [[George W. Bush|George Bush]] in April # a memo from Jack Straw to Tony Blair, 25 March 2002 containing advice ahead of Blair's meeting with George Bush in April. On receipt of the documents, in September 2004, acting on the advice of lawyers, Smith says he photocopied them and returned the originals to his source, then, after the ''Telegraph'''s legal desk secretary typed transcripts on an "old fashioned typewriter", the ''Telegraph'' destroyed their copies of the originals, in order to frustrate any future police investigation of the leaks.{{cite web|url=http://rawstory.com/news/2005/Backstory_Confirming_the_Downing_Street_0614.html |title=Confirming the Downing Street documents |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050617033709/http://rawstory.com/news/2005/Backstory_Confirming_the_Downing_Street_0614.html |archivedate=17 June 2005 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=21 September 2016 |df=dmy }} The documents were widely quoted in the British press immediately following the ''Telegraph'''s story, for example in ''[[The Guardian]]''{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,2763,1308368,00.html |title=Leaks cast doubt on PM's motive |author1=Ewen MacAskill |author2=Michael White |date=20 September 2004|work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=11 March 2006}} and ''[[The Sunday Herald]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.sundayherald.com/44911 |title=Bush and Blair: Secrets and Lies |work=Sunday Herald |date=19 September 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060213073626/http://www.sundayherald.com/44911 |archivedate=13 February 2006 |accessdate=11 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 5 October 2004, facsimiles of these documents appeared online,{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/1472044/Secret-papers-show-Blair-was-warned-of-Iraq-chaos.html |title=Secret papers show Blair was warned of Iraq chaos}} provided by Professor Michael Lewis of [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], who had also housed the file at Iraq expert [[Glen Rangwala]]'s Middle East Reference website.{{cite web |url=http://www.middleeastreference.org.uk |title=Middle East Reference: Chronologies and Biographies |accessdate=11 March 2006}} The file derives ultimately from the typed transcript of the documents made by Smith and the ''Telegraph''. Interest in these documents was revived around 8 June 2005, following their appearance in a discussion thread at [[Democratic Underground]]{{cite web| url=http://www.democraticunderground.com/discuss/duboard.php?az=view_all&address=104x3809302| title=An earlier leaked memo to Downing Street ... |accessdate=11 March 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/HL0506/S00116.htm |title=Scoop: Another Downing St Memo – Wrongfooting Saddam |accessdate=4 November 2008}} and subsequently they began to be quoted in US media, after Rawstory and [[NBC]] verified their authenticity with Smith and British government sources. The ''Los Angeles Times'' published an article on 15 June 2005, describing several of the "new" documents; the article says that "[[Michael Smith (newspaper reporter)|Michael Smith]], the defense writer for ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' who revealed the Downing Street minutes in a story 1 May, provided a full text of the six new documents to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''."{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-britmemos15jun15,0,7241602,full.story |title=New Memos Detail Early Plans for Invading Iraq |first=John |last=Daniszewski |date=15 June 2005 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=11 March 2006}} The six documents are available in PDF form from the Think Progress web site.{{cite web| url=http://thinkprogress.org/index.php?p=1078| title= FULL TEXT OF BRITISH BRIEFING PAPERS REVEALED: More Evidence Intel Was Fixed|work=Think Progress| accessdate=11 March 2006}} A further document, a 21 July 2002, cabinet office paper titled "Conditions for Military Action", which is a briefing paper for the meeting of which the Downing Street Memo is the minutes, was published (with the last page missing) by ''The Sunday Times'' on 12 June 2005.{{cite news |work=The Sunday Times |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2089-1648758,00.html |date=12 June 2005 |title=Cabinet Office paper: Conditions for military action |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718133829/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article531957.ece |archivedate=18 July 2011 |location=London |first=Ben |last=Hoyle}} Another document was the Rycroft email, showing the author of the Downing Street Memo actually believed that Saddam should be removed because of a threat by Iraq getting WMDs into the hands of terrorists.{{cite web |url=http://img301.imageshack.us/img301/5055/rycroft5br.jpg |title=Matthew Rycroft email 11 September 2002 11:59 |format=JPG |accessdate=11 March 2006}}{{cite news |title=Matthew Rycroft email 11 September 2002 11:59 |format=PDF |url=http://image.guardian.co.uk/sys-files/Politics/documents/2003/08/21/DOSSIER_mad.pdf |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=11 March 2006}} The 18 September 2004 ''Daily Telegraph'' article contains the only known reproductions of the original memos (scanned from a photocopy). That article is called "Failure is not an option, but it doesn't mean they will avoid it". On Thursday, 16 June 2005 Reuters mislabelled a photograph of what it claimed was "a copy of the Downing Street Memo".{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/050616/ids_photos_wl/r876363090.jpg |title=404 error |accessdate=11 March 2006}} It turned out to actually be a picture of a document found in a 28 April 2005 Guardian Unlimited story. (At this link, view this PDF: 07.03.03: Attorney general's full advice on Iraq war (pdf)) This PDF detailed Lord Goldsmith’s confidential advice on the legality of the Iraq war and does not match the text of any of the alleged Downing Street Memos. It's an entirely different document that describes legal authorisation for the invasion of Iraq under standing UN resolutions.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,2763,1472115,00.html |title=Full Iraq legal advice released |author=Simon Jeffery and Tom Happold |date=28 April 2005 |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=11 March 2006}} ==Criticism of the memo== Journalists such as [[Fred Kaplan (journalist)|Fred Kaplan]] point out that the later section of the memo that discusses potential consequences of an invasion, including Saddam's use of WMD against Kuwait or Israel, directly contradicts interpretations of the memo as a "smoking gun" about WMD fabrication. {{quote|For instance, what were the consequences, if Saddam used WMD on day one, or if Baghdad did not collapse and urban warfighting began? You said that Saddam could also use his WMD on Kuwait. Or on Israel, added the Defence Secretary.{{cite web |url=http://www.downingstreetmemo.com/docs/memotext.pdf |title=Downing street memo text |accessdate=16 March 2007 |format=PDF}}}} As mentioned above, shortly after the appearance of the memo, Tony Blair was asked: {{quote|The so-called Downing Street memo from July 2002 says intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy of removing Saddam through military action. Is this an accurate reflection of what happened?}} Blair responded: {{quote|No, the facts were not being fixed in any shape or form at all.}} It is not clear whether this is a criticism of the assessment of his own head of foreign intelligence (Dearlove) or a criticism of a particular interpretation of Dearlove's phrase "fixed around". === "Fixed" === The interpretation of the sentence: "But the intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy." has caused debate. [[Robin Niblett]], a member of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank, has said it would be easy for Americans to misunderstand the reference to intelligence being "fixed around" Iraq policy. " 'Fixed around' in British English means 'bolted on' rather than altered to fit the policy," he says. This view was seconded by [[Christopher Hitchens]] and [[Fred Kaplan (journalist)|Fred Kaplan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2120886 |title=What's really in the downing street memo? |year=2007 |accessdate=16 March 2007}} Others have suggested various British English usages of the phrase "were being fixed" (for example as a colloquialism meaning "to agree upon,"{{cite web |url=http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/fixed |title= fixed-in Compact Oxford English Dictionary |accessdate=8 June 2006}}) which are distinct from the usage (both American and British) derived from criminal [[argot]], meaning "fraudulently altered or changed."{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fixed |title= fix-See 7b in Merriam-Webster |accessdate=8 June 2006}} The author of the memo, [[Matthew Rycroft]], employed the former usage in an e-mail when talking about an appointment, ''This is now fixed for 0800''.{{cite web |url=http://www.the-hutton-inquiry.org.uk/content/isc/isc_3_0004.pdf |title=Email from Matthew Rycroft, 18 September 2002 17 52 |format=PDF |accessdate=11 March 2006}} Some detractors from the memo have appeared to make the argument or give the impression that the "fraudulently altered" sense of "fix" is uniquely American and does not exist in British English,{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} but this is false.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2006/jan/08/features.sport13 |title=The Guardian January 2006 'Match Fixing: a history' Webster |location=London |date=8 January 2006 |accessdate=21 October 2008}} Other commentaters have dismissed this, saying that context makes it clear that "being fixed around" used "fix" in the sense of "fraudulently arrange the result",{{cite web |url=http://mediamatters.org/items/200506170003| title=British sources confirm that meaning of "fixed" — as in "manipulated" or "cooked" — is the same in Britain and America |year=2005 |accessdate=21 March 2006}} a common British usage (sense 12(b) of "fix" in the printed Concise Oxford English Dictionary, given as sense 7, "deviously influence the outcome of" in the Compact OED online version.{{cite web |url=http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/fix?view=uk |title=fix as "fraudulently arrange" in British English, see sense 7 of the verb |accessdate=8 June 2006}}) The argument has also been made that this view is supported by negative qualification implied by the presence of the word "But" at the start of the relevant sentence: "But the intelligence and facts were being (innocently) ''agreed upon'' around the policy" is, it is said, an implausible reading because there is nothing negative, per se, about agreement, whereas "But the intelligence and facts were being ''fraudulently arranged'' ...", it is argued, appears to make perfect sense, because it fulfills the negative expectation set up by the word "but". Fred Kaplan noted that "Either way—'fixed' or 'fixed around'—Bush and his aides had decided to let policy shape intelligence, not the other way around; they were explicitly politicising intelligence." When asked about the memo's implication that Iraq intelligence was being "fixed", White House spokesman Scott McClellan said, "The suggestion is just flat-out wrong." But McClellan would later admit that intelligence was suited to fit the policy in a tell-all book.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |title=Why has "Downing Street memo" story been a "dud" in US? |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406142502/http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0517/dailyUpdate.html |archivedate=6 April 2007 |accessdate=22 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} An Iraq "options paper", dated 8 March 2002, stated: "Despite sanctions, Iraq continues to develop WMD" (though it adds that intelligence on the matter is "poor").{{cite web |url=http://thinkprogress.org/wp-images/upload/iraqoptionspaper.pdf |title=options paper |year=2006 |format=PDF |accessdate=9 February 2007}} == See also == Inquiry]] *[[Niger uranium forgeries]] *[[Office of Special Plans]] *[[Operation Rockingham]] *[[Plame affair]] *[[September Dossier]] – UK government report on Iraq threat pre-war *[[United Nations Security Council and the Iraq War]] == References == {{Reflist|35em}} == External links == {{Wikisource-multi|Downing Street memo|Letter from Congress regarding Downing Street memo}} }} {{Campaignbox 2011–present Libyan factional fighting}} {{Campaignbox Libyan Crisis (2011–present)}} Since the end of the [[2011 Libyan Civil War]], which overthrew [[Muammar Gaddafi]], there has been violence involving various militias and the new state security forces. The violence has escalated into the current [[2014 Libyan Civil War]]. The militias include guerrillas, [[Islamism|Islamists]], and militias who fought against Gaddafi but refused to lay down their arms when the war ended in October 2011. According to some civilian leaders, these latter militias shifted from merely delaying the surrender of their weapons to actively asserting a continuing political role as "guardians of the revolution". Some of the largest, and most well-equipped militias are associated with Islamist groups now forming political parties.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/02/world/africa/in-libya-the-fighting-may-outlast-the-revolution.html|title=In Libya, Fighting May Outlast the Revolution|date=1 November 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick|accessdate=16 November 2011|location=Tripoli}} Before the official end of hostilities between loyalist and opposition forces, there were reports of sporadic clashes between rival militias, and vigilante revenge killings.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8860684/Libya-revolutionaries-turn-on-each-other-as-fears-grow-for-law-and-order.html|title=Libya: revolutionaries turn on each other as fears grow for law and order|newspaper=The Telegraph|first=Nick|last=Meo|location=Tripoli|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011}} In September 2012, Islamists [[2012 Benghazi attack|attacked]] the [[United States]] consulate building in [[Benghazi]], killing the US ambassador and three others. This prompted a popular outcry against semi-legal militias that were still operating and resulted in the storming of several Islamist militia bases by protesters.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/libya-militia-leader-heat-seeking-missiles-other-weapons-stolen-during-firefight/2012/09/24/8ab6f992-0675-11e2-afff-d6c7f20a83bf_story.html|title=Libya militia leader: Heat-seeking missiles, other weapons stolen during firefight|work=Washington Post|date=24 September 2012|accessdate=25 September 2012|first=Abigail|last=Hauslohner}}{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/09/21/239416.html|title=Libyan demonstrators wreck militia compound in Benghazi|newspaper=Al Arabiya|date=21 September 2012|accessdate=24 September 2012}} A large-scale government crackdown followed on non-government sanctioned militias, with the Libyan Army raiding several now illegal militias' headquarters and ordering them to disband.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/09/2012923221126439787.html|title=Libyan forces raid militia outposts |newspaper=Al Jazeera|date=23 September 2012|accessdate=24 September 2012}} == Events == === 2011 === ==== November 2011==== On 1 November, a group of intoxicated [[Zintan]] fighters stormed a hospital in Tripoli and demanded the hand-over of a fighter who was wounded earlier in the day in a clash that also left another militiaman dead. The doctors refused and a Tripoli militia, in charge of hospital security, forced the Zintanis out, but not before they shot rounds in the hospital. Both groups received reinforcements and the fighting, involving heavy machine guns and anti-aircraft guns, lasted for three hours. There were no direct fatalities from the fighting, but three patients at the hospital died due to stress-related causes linked to the clashes. Three Tripoli fighters were wounded. The fighting reportedly ended after calls from a local imam and senior commanders from both groups talked by phone with their men.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/02/world/africa/libya-infighting/index.html|title=Libyan war over, but fighting continues among regional militias|newspaper=CNN|accessdate=26 January 2012|date=2 November 2011}} On 8 November, it was evident that loyalist remnants were also still active in the country, even more than two weeks after their defeat, when a pro-Gaddafi convoy tried to cross the border into Niger and were intercepted by the Nigerien army. 13 loyalists and one Nigerien soldier were killed.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Nov-10/153554-niger-army-clash-with-libyan-convoy-kills-14.ashx#axzz1dci9bHxS|title=Niger army clash with Libyan convoy kills 14 |newspaper=The Daily Star|date=10 November 2011|accessdate=26 January 2012}} Between 8 and 12 November, large-scale fighting erupted between Zawiya and Tripoli between a Zawiya-based militia and a group from the Wershifanna tribe. The Zawiya group accused their opponents of belonging to loyalist remnants and they reported of seeing tanks and vehicles with the Gaddafi-era green flag and markings that said "Brigade of the Martyr Muammar Gaddafi". The Wershifanna denied this and stated that the men from Zawiya had been misled by a rumor that pro-Gaddafi fighters were in the area. The fighting was centered around the former loyalist Imaya military base and both sides vied for control. Grad rocket launchers were used at times during the clashes. 9–12 Zawiya fighters and nine Wershifanna fighters were killed.{{cite news|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/11/ap-libya-rival-militias-clash-111311/ |title=Rival Libyan militias continue clashes |work=Army Times |accessdate=26 January 2012}}{{cite news|last=Holmes |first=Oliver |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/12/us-libya-clashes-idUSTRE7AB0HU20111112 |title=Fighters clash again near Tripoli, several dead |agency=Reuters |accessdate=26 January 2012 |date=12 November 2011}} On 23 November, a militia force in Bani Walid was ambushed after being sent there to arrest a known Gaddafi supporter. 15 militia members were killed. The survivors reported being shot at and hit with grenades and rockets from houses after they found out all the roads were blocked.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-501713_162-57331665/tunisair-suspends-tripoli-flights-due-to-security/ |title=Tunisair suspends Tripoli flights due to security |work=CBS News |date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Another report stated that the fighting started after a high-speed chase with a suspect vehicle in which a Gaddafi loyalist was killed. One civilian also reportedly died during the fighting.{{cite news |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/23/178863.html |title=Fresh clashes in Libya’s Bani Walid; U.N. says 7,000 held in militia prisons |work=Al Arabiya |date=23 November 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104002523/http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/23/178863.html# |archive-date=4 January 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==== December 2011==== In early December, a group of [[Zintan]]i gunmen attacked the convoy of a top army officer, [[General]] [[Khalifa Haftar]], as it was speeding through a checkpoint set up by the group.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/13/world/africa/libyan-army-clashes-with-militia-near-tripoli-airport.html | work=The New York Times | first=Liam | last=Stack | title=Libyan Army Clashes With Militia Near Tripoli Airport | date=12 December 2011}} In a separate incident, gunfire broke out between the army and the Zintan brigade at the [[Tripoli International Airport]].{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/11/libya-tripoli-airport-militia | title=Libya: Tripoli airport closed after rogue militia attacks garrison |work=The Guardian| date=11 December 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011 | last=Stephen | first=Chris | location=Tripoli}}{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16128837 | title=Gunfight erupts near Tripoli airport in Libya |work=BBC News | date=11 December 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011}} On 16 December, Haftar said an armed group had abducted his son, Belgassim, and detained him at the airport.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-17/libya-s-top-general-says-son-abducted-by-militia-in-capital.html |title=Libya’s Top General Says Son Abducted by Militia in Capital |work=Businessweek |date=16 December 2011 |agency=Bloomberg |accessdate=5 January 2012 |first=Chris |last=Stephen |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109163145/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-17/libya-s-top-general-says-son-abducted-by-militia-in-capital.html |archivedate=9 January 2012 |df=dmy }} On 6 December, Libya's interim government announced that, following consultations with [[Tripoli]]'s local council, it had given militias lingering in the capital until late December to hand over security to the authorities. Officials said residents of Tripoli would convene rallies in support of the initiative to clear the city of weapons and out-of-town fighters. If militias had not withdrawn by 20 December, the authorities and members of the public intended to close the whole city to traffic.{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E7N64R920111206| title=Libyan government promises to disarm Tripoli | work=Reuters Africa | date=6 December 2011 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli|first1=Taha|last1=Zargoun|first2=Ali|last2=Shuaib}} By January 2012, the former rebels had dismantled most of their checkpoints, while some key bases still remained.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidestory/2012/01/2012156215196506.html|work=Al Jazeera|date=8 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012|title=Can Libya's armed groups be disbanded?}} On 11 December, fighting erupted south of Zintan, between the Zintan militia and members of the El-Mashasha tribe. The clashes started when the El-Mashasha attacked the convoy of a Zintan militia commander, killing him, as he tried to pass through the town of Wamis,{{cite news|url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/newshour/20111214/114964.shtml |title=Ceasefire ends faction fighting in Tripoli |work=Xinhua |accessdate=26 January 2012}} around which the tribe was based. The Zintanis retaliated by attacking the town with artillery or rocket fire, hitting houses in residential areas. A mosque and a school were also hit. Over two days of fighting three townspeople were killed.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/1212/libya.html |title=Four killed in tribal fighting in Libya |work=RTÉ |date=12 December 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2012}}{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Tate|url=http://www.warsintheworld.com/index.php/2011/12/15/libya-several-killed-in-fighting-between-el-mashasha-and-zintan-militians-in-south-west-of-tripoli/ |title=Libya: Several killed in fighting between El-Mashasha and Zintan militians in south west of Tripoli |work=Wars in the World |date=15 December 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2012}} By 13 December, a ceasefire was established. Officials from Zintan stated that the fighting was the result of the El-Mashasha killing several residents of Zintan earlier in week.{{cite news |url=http://www.ntn24.com/news/news/faction-fighting-near-zintan-lybia |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120904234230/http://www.ntn24.com/news/news/faction-fighting-near-zintan-lybia |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 September 2012 |title=Faction Fighting near Zintan in Libya |work=NTN24 |date=13 December 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2012 }} === 2012 === ==== January 2012 ==== On 3 January, four fighters were killed in a gun battle in [[Tripoli]] as dozens of fighters from [[Misrata]] were trying to seize a group of prisoners being held in a security compound by Tripoli militias.{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE80212S20120103 | title=Battle between Tripoli, Misrata militias kills 4 | work=Reuters Africa | date=3 January 2012 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=5 January 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Mahmoud|last=Habboush}} Another report stated that there were two separate gun battles and put the number of dead at seven.{{cite news|first=Kim|last=Sengupta |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/libyas-leader-warns-of-civil-war-after-tripoli-gun-battles-6285034.html |title=Libya's leader warns of civil war after Tripoli gun battles |work=Independent|date=5 January 2012|accessdate=1 February 2012 |location=London}} In response to the incident, NTC chairman [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]] warned that Libya risked sliding into civil war if the rival militias were not brought under control.{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL6E8C415A20120104 | title=Militias could drag Libya into civil war-NTC chief | work=Reuters Africa | date=4 January 2012 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=5 January 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Mahmoud|last=Habboush}} On 14 January, two fighters were killed and 36 were injured after clashes between militias from neighbouring towns of [[Gharyan]] and [[Asbi'a]]. It was reported that artillery and rockets were used during the clashes.{{cite news| url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/01/15/libya-militia-idINDEE80E01020120115 | title=Two killed and 36 hurt in Libyan clashes | work=Reuters India| date=15 January 2012 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=15 January 2012|location=Gharyan|first=Mahmoud|last=Habboush}} On 15 January, the rival groups carried out a prisoner swap and agreed to a ceasefire.{{cite news|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/8404106/libya-clashes-end-with-prisoner-swap|work=Nine MSN|accessdate=17 January 2012|date=17 January 2012|title=Libya clashes end with prisoner swap|agency=Agence France-Presse|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404234730/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/8404106/libya-clashes-end-with-prisoner-swap#|archive-date=4 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Officials said 12 people had been killed and around 100 wounded on both sides.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16655046|title=Libya power struggle tears apart Assabia|location=[[Asbi'a]]|work=BBC|accessdate=21 January 2012|date=20 January 2012|first=Gabriel|last=Gatehouse}} In the days leading up to the fighting, the Asbi'a commander assigned to Gharyan, Ezzedine al-Ghool, was detained and tortured to death by members of the Gharyan militia. His body was dropped off anonymously at a hospital in Tripoli.{{cite news|last=Holmes |first=Oliver |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/25/us-libya-lawlessness-idUSTRE80O18P20120125 |title=Torture and lawlessness as Libya "victory high" ends |agency=Reuters |accessdate=26 January 2012 |date=25 January 2012}} On 20 January, Libya's former ambassador to France died less than a day after he was arrested by a Tripoli militia group. ''[[Human Rights Watch]]'' said on 3 February, that marks on Omar Brebesh's body suggested he died as a result of [[torture]] while he was in detention.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16869659 |title=Libyan diplomat Omar Brebesh dies 'under torture' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=3 February 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 22 January, a new clash broke out in Tripoli when NTC fighters attempted to arrest a former prisoner, charged with murder, who was released by the Gaddafi government at the start of the civil war the previous year. He and his brother took shelter in their home and opened fire on the militia with RPGs and automatic weapons. Both brothers and an NTC fighter were killed and five militiamen were wounded.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/2012/Jan-23/160815-at-least-one-dead-in-tripoli-clash.ashx#axzz1kLJ4bJJK |title=At least one dead in Tripoli clash |work=Lebanon Daily Star |accessdate=26 January 2012}} On 26 January, the [[humanitarian aid]] [[non-governmental organization]] [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] (which had been present in Misrata since April 2011, during the Libyan Civil War) announced the suspension of their work in the city detention centres, as detainees were tortured and denied urgent health care.{{cite news|title=Libya: Detainees Tortured and Denied Medical Care|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/press/release.cfm?id=5744&cat=press-release|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131134931/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/press/release.cfm?id=5744&cat=press-release|dead-url=yes|archive-date=31 January 2012|publisher=Doctorswithoutborders.org|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}} MSF General Director Christopher Stokes stated: "Patients were brought to us in the middle of interrogation for medical care, in order to make them fit for more interrogation. This is unacceptable. Our role is to provide medical care to war casualties and sick detainees, not to repeatedly treat the same patients between torture sessions.".{{cite news|title=Doctors refuse to aid Libyan ‘torture’|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/01/26/doctors-without-borders-halts-work-in-libyan-city-of-misrata-over-torture-concerns/|publisher=[[National Post]] (Reuters)|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}} [[Amnesty International]] had described two days ago "widespread torture and ill-treatment of suspected pro-Gadhafi fighters and loyalists.", with several detainees dying across Libya in the precedent weeks.{{cite news|title=Libyan detainees died after torture, human rights group says|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-01-26/africa/world_africa_libya-msf-torture_1_torture-human-rights-group-detainees|publisher=CNN|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ;Bani Walid clashes {{main|2012 Bani Walid uprising}} Uprising started in Bani Walid on 23 January 2012 due to an incident in the city of [[Bani Walid]] in which the "May 28 Brigade" militia wished to arrest local men in unclear circumstances. The May 28 Brigade and their compound were then attacked by local fighters who then took control of the town. ==== February 2012 ==== On 6 February, seven male black Libyan civilians from [[Tawergha]] were killed by militias who raided their makeshift refugee camp at a former naval academy in [[Janzour]], a suburb of Tripoli. The survivors said that they appeared to be from Misrata because of their license plates, though the Misrata militia denied this.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/02/20122622397129438.html |title=Gunmen kill seven at Libyan refugee camp |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} ;Kufra clashes {{main|2012 Kufra conflict}} On 12 February, conflict erupted between [[Zuwayya]] and [[Toubou]] tribesmen in southern town of [[Kufra]]. This conflict lasted several months and led to government military intervention which started uneasy truce between two tribes. On 15 February, [[Amnesty International]] reported that at least 12 detainees had been tortured to death while in militia custody.{{cite news|author=Gabriel Gatehouse |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17053836 |title=Libya militias threatening stability, says Amnesty |work=BBC|date=16 February 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} ==== March 2012 ==== On 2 March, the head of the security committee in [[Derna, Libya|Derna]], [[Colonel]] Mohammed Al-Hassi, was shot and killed outside a petrol station in the town. He had previously survived two earlier assassination attempts and was also the head of Derna’s anti-drugs unit. He cracked down hard on local drug smugglers during and before the civil war.{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/derna-security-chief-assassinated/ |title=Derna security chief assassinated |publisher=Libyaherald.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 6 March, tribal and militia leaders in Benghazi declared unilaterally semi-autonomy for the eastern region of [[Cyrenaica]]. This was met with anger from the NTC government in Tripoli and anti-autonomy demonstrations erupted in the capital and Benghazi.{{cite news|author=Gabriel Gatehouse |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17271431 |title=Libya: Semi-autonomy declared by leaders in east |work=BBC|date=6 March 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 16 March, a pro-autonomy demonstration was held in Benghazi, which was attacked by unknown gunmen, leaving one person dead and five injured.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17411134 |title=Libya rally on Cyrenaica autonomy plan ends in violence|work=BBC|date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 18 March, a clash erupted between the Zintan militia and residents of Tripoli's Abu Salim district, previously loyal to Gaddafi. One militiaman was killed before a cease-fire was brokered by the district's own militia commander.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/clashes-erupt-in-libyan-capital-between-militia-and-residents-of-pro-gadhafi-area-1-killed/2012/03/18/gIQAXpkaKS_story.html Libya ruler says militias should not control government buildings; 1 killed in Tripoli clash]{{dead link|date=September 2012}} ;Sabha clashes {{main|2012 Sabha conflict}} Late on 25 March, clashes erupted in the southern city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]], between Arab and [[Toubou]] tribesmen, after a man from the Abu Seif tribe was killed in a dispute over a car by the Toubou which lasted for one week. ==== April 2012 ==== ;Zuwara clashes On 1 April, 21–34 Zuwara militiamen were detained by members of a neighboring town's militia. The Ragdalein fighters stated that they captured the men after months of abuses by a Zuwara brigade, including the looting of property. For their part, the Zuwara local council head accused Ragdalein to be a hub of Gaddafi loyalists.{{cite news|last=Al |first=Rami |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2017890745_apmllibya.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715154350/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2017890745_apmllibya.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 July 2012 |title=Militias: Clashes near Libya's Tunisia border |publisher=Seattle Times |date=2 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012 }} A third version of the events came from the government Interior Ministry which stated that the trouble started when a Zuwara hunting party near Al-Jumail shot and killed a person from that town by mistake.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/01/libya-clashes-idUSL6E8F10ST20120401 |title=Libyan PM visits scene of tribal clashes in desert |publisher=Reuters|date= 1 April 2012|accessdate=6 August 2012 |first=Marie-Louise |last=Gumuchian}} The hunters were then arrested but released later. Another Zuwara council head claimed that the men were tortured before being released and stated that Zuwara came under mortar and anti-aircraft fire by militias from both Ragdalein and Al-Jumail.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE83109H20120402 |title=Rival militias exchange fire in western Libya |publisher=Reuters |date=2 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 3 April, reports emerged that the fighting in the Zuwara area was still continuing with at least one Zuwara militiaman killed and five wounded. The losses for Ragdalein and Al-Jumail were not known. Clashes were reported at the entrance to Ragdalein while Al-Jumail was shelling Zuwara.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/03/us-libya-zuwara-idUSBRE8320H220120403 |title=Government fails to halt western Libya militia clash |publisher=Reuters |date= 3 April 2012|accessdate=6 August 2012}} At least 14 were killed and 80 injured.{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL6E8F382U20120403 |title=Militia clash in west Libya kills 14 people |publisher=Reuters |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 4 April, the fighting escalated with the use of tanks and artillery. The reported number of dead was said to had risen to 26, eight from Zuwara and 18 from the outlying towns, and another 142 Zuwarans were wounded.{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/04/205432.html |title=Fresh clashes erupt in western Libya between former rebels, killing 26 |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=4 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://m.apnews.com/ap/db_15716/contentdetail.htm?contentguid=6NzaSgJe |title=Clashes in rival towns kill 22 in western Libya |agency=Associated Press |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} Unconfirmed reports rose up the death toll to 48 killed in the clashes.[http://unsmil.unmissions.org/Portals/unsmil/Documents/Briefing10May2012.pdf The situation in Libya] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233801/http://unsmil.unmissions.org/Portals/unsmil/Documents/Briefing10May2012.pdf# |date=2 December 2013 }} UN Security Council, 6768th meeting, 10 May 2012. On 6 April, French leading newspaper ''Le Figaro'' reported that a dozen people were killed near Ghat on 1 and 2 April in fighting between former pro-Gaddafi Tuaregs and the Zintan tribe.{{cite web|language=French|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2012/04/05/01003-20120405ARTFIG00976-en-libye-aussi-les-touaregs-se-battent-pour-leur-territoire.php |title=En Libye aussi, les Touaregs se battent pour leur territoire |publisher=Lefigaro.fr |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 20 April, fighting restarted in Kufra with 12 people being killed and more than 35 wounded when the Tobu fighters were reportedly attacked by units under the command of the Libyan National Army. The fighting began when a Tobu tribesman was killed by members of the Zuwayya tribe. The battles lasted late into 21 April.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/180765/12-killed-in-south-libya-violence-%E2%80%93-tribal-leader |title=12 killed in south Libya violence – tribal leader |publisher=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} ==== May 2012 ==== On 8 May, protests outside prime minister office turned violent when ex-rebels, which protested on the non-payment of the promised cash handout by the government, attacked the office in Tripoli. One Interior Ministry’s Supreme Security Committee (SSC) guard was killed, while four others, one protester and three SSC guards, were injured.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17995427 |title=Libya PM office attacked by gunmen in Tripoli|work=BBC|date=8 May 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/armed-protestors-storm-governmental-headquarters/ |title=Armed protestors try to storm Prime Minister’s headquarters; 1 killed |publisher=Libyaherald.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 15 May, a diplomatic source briefed by Western intelligence officials stated that, beside the tribal rivalries plaguing the country, there was concern about a growing presence of Islamist militants in some areas, specifically the city of Derna.
