The source said that hundreds of Islamist militants were in and around the town, and there were militant training camps where weapons were also provided. He said one official had described the area as "a disaster zone." Tensions had reportedly grown between local people and the militants. According to the source, the previous month, a number of town residents went to a camp on the outskirts of the city and forced militants to leave. One of the indicators of the militant inter-factional were also the recent spate of car-bombings in Derna. One of the attacks targeted Abdel Hakim al Hasadi, a former member of the [[Libyan Islamic Fighting Group]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/05/15/world/africa/libya-militants/index.html |title=Concern grows over jihadist numbers in eastern Libya |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= 15 May 2012|accessdate=6 August 2012}} The same day, two people were killed and a third wounded in intertribal clashes in Sorman.{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/two-killed-in-clashes-in-sorman/ |title=Two killed in clashes in Sorman |publisher=Libyaherald.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 16 May, fighting erupted between Tuareg tribesmen and local militiamen over control of a checkpoint on the edge of [[Ghadames]] on a desert route often used for smuggling, near the Algerian border.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/16/us-libya-clashes-idUSBRE84F0QV20120516|title=Nomads, locals clash in Libya desert town: officials|work=Reuters|date=16 May 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}} Between seven and thirteen people were killed and more than 20 wounded. Per one local official, except one person, all of the dead were Tuaregs.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18095756 |title=Seven die in clashes in Libyan desert town – government|work=BBC|date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/algeriaNews/idAFL5E8GGI8S20120516 |title=Several killed in Libya desert town clash |publisher=Reuters|date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} ==== June 2012 ==== On 5 June, a militia checkpoint in Gwarsha district was attacked and destroyed by the family of a member of the security forces who had been fatally shot earlier by a militiaman at the checkpoint.{{cite news|title=Benghazi checkpoint destroyed in revenge attack|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=8562|author=Maha Ellawati|publisher=Libya Herald|date=5 June 2012|accessdate=16 September 2012}} On 6 June, one person was shot and killed in [[Sirte]], purportedly by anti-Gaddafi gunmen who thought the man was a loyalist.{{cite web|author=Jamie Dettmer |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/07/12/libya-is-still-riven-by-violence-as-loyalists-and-rebels-alike-keep-killing.html |title=Libya Is Still Riven by Violence as Loyalists and Rebels Alike Keep Killing |publisher=Thedailybeast.com |date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} Between 11 and 17 June, clashes raged in the town of Zintan. Zintani militiamen were involved in fighting with members of the El-Mashasha tribe, whom they accuse of being Gaddafi loyalists because they did not join the opposition during the civil war the previous year. The fighting reportedly started when a Zintani militiaman was shot and killed at an El-Mashasha checkpoint.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/06/20126176734750314.html |title=Troops sent to quell clashes in western Libya |publisher=Aljazeera.com |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18529139 |title=Libya's tribal clashes leave 105 dead|work=BBC|date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} At the same time, a security patrol came under fire in Sabha, leaving two dead and 10 wounded. Armed clashes also flared anew in Kufra, leaving one dead and dozens injured.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/06/2012613224738799392.html|title=Deadly clashes in run-up to Libya elections|work=Al Jazeera|date=13 June 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}} After days of clashes, on 17 June, the Libyan government declared the area around Zintan a [[Military exclusion zone|military zone]] and sent troops to stop the fighting.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18474834 |title=Troops sent to quell clashes in western Libya|work=BBC|date=17 June 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} The total casualty toll for the fighting in the Zintan area was ultimately stated to be 105 killed and more than 500 wounded. The majority of the dead were reported to be El-Mashasha. The tribesmen accused the Zintan forces of shelling their town, Sheguiga, with tank and rocket fire.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5it2MqJLdJSr2SFculMVc81MSJOUA?docId=CNG.917b5707976c17134e95893e46cd2f43.951 |title=105 killed in week of clashes in west Libya |work=Google News|agency=Agence France-Presse |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} ==== July 2012 ==== On 6 July, a helicopter carrying election material was shot at south of Benghazi killing an election worker.{{cite web|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=416622 |title=Gunmen hit helicopter carrying Libyan ballots, 1 dead |publisher=Nowlebanon.com |date=6 July 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}} On 28 July, Colonel Bouzyreda Sleiman, a former military intelligence agent who defected to the opposition during the civil war, was shot and killed in Benghazi as he was performing the Taraweeh prayers at the Amer Bin Yas mosque. Other former Benghazi interior security officers, as Abdelhamid Kandouz Ali or [[non-commissioned officer]] Ibrahim Al-Arabi, were killed several days before by car bombs.{{cite news|title=Libye: Un officier des renseignements assassiné à Benghazi|url=http://www.afriquejet.com/libye-un-officier-des-renseignements-assassine-a-benghazi-2012073042484.html|publisher=Afriquejet.com ([[PanaPress|PANA]])|date=30 July 2012|language=French|accessdate=11 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120802053832/http://www.afriquejet.com/libye-un-officier-des-renseignements-assassine-a-benghazi-2012073042484.html|archivedate=2 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} On 29 July, commander of Libyan ground forces Khalifa Hafter escaped an assassination attempt in Benghazi, when his convoy get under fire from unknown assailants. Abdel-Basit Haroun, a Benghazi militia commander, declared that only during the past month thirteen people who had been close to the former government had been killed. Also in Benghazi, a bomb planted at the Tibesti hotel was defused before it could explode.{{cite news|title=Libyan Army General Escapes Assassination Attempt in Benghazi|url=http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8911|publisher=Tripoli Post|date=30 July 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}} ==== August 2012 ==== On 1 August, clashes in Abu Isa (between Zawiya and [[Sorman]]) between armed gangs who were fighting over some vehicles since the day before ended with the intervention of the Libya Shield Force, with a final toll between two and four killed, and five injured.{{cite news|title=Zawia clashes end, but two die|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=12110|publisher=Libya Herald|date=2 August 2012|accessdate=16 September 2012}} On 10 August, another former [[Libyan Army (1951-2011)|Libyan Army]] officer who was among the first defecting to the opposition, [[Brigadier General]] Mohamed Hadia al-Feitouri, was shot and killed in Benghazi. Hadia, then defence ministry official responsible for ammunition and weapons, was returning home from Friday prayers when a group of gunmen pulled up in a car and opened fire on him.{{cite news|title=Libyan general murdered in Benghazi|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/08/2012810222419754353.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=11 August 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=Libyan General Hadia killed in Benghazi shooting|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19220027|publisher=BBC|date=10 August 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}} On 19 August, two people were killed in a two independent car bomb attacks in Tripoli. They are the first fatal bomb attacks since the fall of the Gaddafi regime.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19310528 Libya blasts: Two killed in Tripoli car bombings]. Bbc.co.uk (2012-08-19). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. The Libyan Ministry of Interior accused Gaddafi loyalists of carrying out the attacks, while those loyalists using an instant messaging service [[Paltalk]] were reportedly listening to the Interior Ministry’s communications network.Grant, George (2012-08-19). [http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=12968 Exclusive – Interior Ministry communications system hacked as Qaddafi loyalists overheard discussing Tripoli blasts]. Libya Herald. Retrieved on 2012-09-30. On 23 August, tribal clashes with heavy weapons (between Awlad Al-Shaikh tribesmen and Zlitenis according to some sources, and between Al-Haly and Al-Fawatra tribes according to others) started in [[Zliten]], killing between three and twelve people, and injuring dozens. In a separate development, Interior ministry spokesman Abdelmonem al-Hur stated that more than a hundred tanks and twenty-six rocket launchers were seized from an alleged pro-Gaddafi militia (named ''Katibat Al-Awfiyah'', or Brigade of the Faithful), during a raid on their campsite in Tarhuna. The operation ended with one of the suspects killed, eight wounded and thirteen detainees, accused of being linked with the 19 August Tripoli bombings.{{cite news|title=At least 12 killed in tribal clash in Libya|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/48772032/ns/world_news-africa/t/least-killed-tribal-clash-libya/#.UE81B3kZRO0|work=[[NBC]]|agency=Reuters|date=23 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=Libya seizes tanks from pro-Gaddafi militia|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19364536|publisher=BBC|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=Tanks seized from pro-Gaddafi militia|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/breaking-news/tanks-seized-from-pro-gaddafi-militia/story-e6freoo6-1226457112174|publisher=[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}} In Homs, east of Tripoli, a women's hunger strike over conditions at a migrants camp was suppressed by anti-Gaddafi militia members, leaving three [[Sub-Saharan]] migrants dead, according to [[Eritrea]]n [[Roman Catholic]] priest Moses Zerai.{{cite news|title=Libya militia members accused of killing three sub-Saharan migrants|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/24/libya-militia-accused-killing-migrants|author=Tom Kington|publisher=The Guardian|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012|location=London}} In Sabha, two African migrants were killed and several others wounded when unknown assailants threw an explosive device at the home where they stayed.{{cite news|title=Attack in Sebha kills 2: report|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13265|publisher=Libya Herald|date=25 August 2012|accessdate=16 September 2012}} On 24 August, following the deadly clashes of the day before, the shrine of Sufi scholar [[Sidi]] [[Abd As-Salam Al-Asmar]] in Zliten (which had been target of an earlier attack in March) was destroyed by Salafist groups using a [[bulldozer]] and explosives, according to Zlitan military council official Omar Ali and witnesses.{{cite news|title=Libya Islamists destroy Sufi shrines, library – military|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/25/libya-islamists-idUSL6E8JP0UT20120825|publisher=Reuters|date=25 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}} The attackers have also blown up the mosque attached to it and its library, filmed the events and posted the footage online.{{cite news|title=Extremists demolish Libya’s shrines using bulldozers, explosives|url=http://observers.france24.com/content/20120829-extremists-demolish-libya-shrines-using-bulldozers-explosives-libya-mausoleum-zliten-tripoli-video-salafists|publisher=France 24|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}} On 25 August, the Al-Shaab Al-Dahmani mosque and shrine in central Tripoli was bulldozed in broad daylight by a group of armed Salafists, including members of the security forces. According to witnesses, when the police came, they prevented people from approaching instead of stopping the demolition, while an anonymous government officer alleged that after a small clash they sealed the area to prevent violence from spreading. One of the assailants affirmed that the Interior Ministry had authorised the operation after discovering practices of worshipping and "black magic" at the shrine.{{cite news|title=Libya militants bulldoze Sufi mosque|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/26/libya-militants-bulldoze-sufi-mosque|publisher=The Guardian|agency=Reuters|date=26 August 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012|location=London}} According to witnesses, the Sheikh [[Ahmad Zarruq]] mausoleum in the port of Misrata was also destroyed.{{cite news|title=UN to Libya: stop destroying holy sites|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/11544|publisher=[[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Al Akhbar]]|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=13 September 2012}} On 26 August, several Libyan government officials as President of the [[General National Congress]] [[Mohamed Yousef el-Magariaf]], or Supreme Military Council spokesman Abdel Moneim al-Hurr condemned the demolition. [[Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Mustafa Abushagur]] stated on [[Twitter]]: "''The destruction of shrines and mosques is a crime. Those who commit these crimes will be held responsible… I asked the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Defence to intervene yesterday but they did not do their duty to protect these sites.''"{{cite news|title=Tripoli’s Al-Sha’ab shrine demolished|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13205|author=Al Russell|publisher=Libya Herald|date=25 August 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} The Grand Mufti of Libya Sheikh Sadik Al-Ghariani condemned the desecration of graves and holy sites, which he described as "''not religiously permissible''" and "''a violation of the sanctity of the dead''".{{cite news|title=Mufti condemns shrine attacks|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13289|publisher=Libya Herald|date=26 August 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} International non-governmental organizations (like [[HRW]] or [[ANHRI]]) and [[UNESCO]] also denounced the attacks.{{cite news|title=Widespread condemnation of mosque attacks and demands for government action|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13382|author=Hadi Fornaji|publisher=Libya Herald|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=UNESCO Director-General calls for an immediate halt to destruction of Sufi sites in Libya|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/single-view/news/unesco_director_general_calls_for_an_immediate_halt_to_destruction_of_sufi_sites_in_libya/|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} ==== September 2012 ==== {{for|the attack on the USA diplomatic mission in Benghazi|2012 Benghazi attack{{!}}2012 Benghazi attack}} On 2 September, clashes between two rival young men groups in [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]] for the theft of a car resulted in seven killed and thirteen injured, ending with the intervention of local security forces.{{cite news|title=Deadly clash in Zawia: reports|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13632|publisher=Libya Herald|date=2 September 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} The same day, the [[joint venture]] between [[Arabian Gulf Oil Company|AGOCO]] and [[Repsol]] announced a halt on oil production at the [[Akakus]] fields in the [[Murzuq]] basin, following an attack on some company personnel by the guards of the complex.{{cite news|title=Attack leads to major oil production cut|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13623|author=Hadi Fornaji|publisher=Libya Herald|date=2 September 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} In Benghazi, a car bomb exploded in [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] street, at the center of the city, killing a Colonel of the former government security services and wounding the other passenger. While at first Supreme Security Committee spokesman Abdel Moneim al-Hurr said that the driver was carrying the bombing device, he later affirmed that the two men, both intelligence officers, had been the target of the explosion.{{cite news|title=Libyan intelligence officer dies in Benghazi car bomb|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20120902-libyan-intelligence-officer-dies-benghazi-car-bomb|publisher=France 24|agency=Reuters|date=2 September 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}}{{cite news|title=Un agent du renseignement de l'ancien régime meurt dans un attentat à Benghazi|url=http://www.france24.com/fr/20120902-agent-renseignement-meurt-attentat-voiture-piegee-benghazi-libye|publisher=France 24|agency=AFP|date=3 September 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012|language=fr}} Between 3 and 4 September, a group of Wershifanna tribesmen located a fake [[Security checkpoint|checkpoint]] at the Zahra bridge, in the road between Tripoli and [[Aziziya]], killing between one and three travellers and kidnapping seven others from the Nafusa mountains. On Tuesday 4, an agreement was made with the group fleeing the checkpoint and releasing the hostages in exchange for the liberation of a Wershifanna man accused of car theft.{{cite news|title=Armed group commits murder at fake checkpoint near Tripoli airport|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13767|publisher=Libya Herald|date=5 September 2012|accessdate=12 September 2012}} On 7 September, a Salafist militia attacked the Sidi Al-Lafi mausoleum in [[Ar Rajma|Rajma]]. In the clashes with local residents that followed, three militiamen were killed and seven people were injured, according to Interior Ministry sources. Finally, the Libya Shield Brigade was deployed to stop the violence.{{cite news|title=Three Salafists reported dead following clashes with locals defending Sufi shrines|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=13919|author=Maha Ellawati|publisher=Libya Herald|date=8 September 2012|accessdate=13 September 2012}} Wisam Bin Hamid, leader of the Libya Shield Force in Cirenaica raised later the injured toll to thirteen, and denied reports that his forces were involved in the attack.{{cite news|title=Libya Shield forces did not join in Salafist attack says commander|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=14042|author=Ashraf Abdul Wahab|publisher=Libya Herald|date=10 September 2012|accessdate=16 September 2012}} On 10 September, Air Defense Colonel Badr Khamis Al-Obeidi was killed by unknown gunmen in a [[drive-by shooting]] when he was leaving the Saida Aisha mosque in Benghazi.{{cite news|title=Air defense colonel killed in Benghazi|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=14013|author=Nihal Zaroug|publisher=Libya Herald|date=10 September 2012|accessdate=16 October 2012}} On 11 September (eleventh anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks]]), heavy armed Islamist militiamen attacked all the night with rocket-propelled grenades, hand grenades, assault rifles and mortars the US consulate building in Benghazi and a [[CIA]] annex, killing four United States citizens, including Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]].{{cite news|title=Chris Stevens, US ambassador to Libya, killed in Benghazi attack|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/12/chris-stevens-us-ambassador-libya-killed|publisher=The Guardian|date=12 September 2012|accessdate=4 February 2013|location=London|first1=Luke|last1=Harding}} In Benghazi, in late September, mass protests forced the Islamist militia [[Ansar al-Sharia (Benghazi, Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]] to withdraw from their barracks and flee. People in the crowd waved swords and even a meat cleaver, shouting "No more al-Qaeda!" and "The blood we shed for freedom shall not go in vain!" They tore down the banner of group while chanting "no no to the brigades".[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/09/201292205259561409.html Libyans storm militia bases in Benghazi]. Aljazeera.com (2012-9-22). Retrieved on 2012-09-30.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19680785 Libya: Islamist militia bases stormed in Benghazi]. Bbc.co.uk (2012-09-22). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. 11 people were killed during the clashes in Benghazi,[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19708084 Libyan army removes heads of Benghazi militias]. Bbc.co.uk (2012-09-24). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. including six government soldiers who were found executed outside the city. Militias were blamed for the soldier's deaths. A colonel was also reported missing and feared kidnapped.[https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2012/09/22/libya-2-killed-in-protester-militia-clashes Anti-militia protests show frailty of Libyan state]. Usnews.com (2012-09-22). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. At the same time, Essam al Katous, a senior security official reported that Gaddafi loyalists killed 20 militiamen and abducted 30 other from a bus in the southern town of [[Brak, Libya|Barek al-Shati]] where they clashed for several days with a pro-government militia. On 14 September, Benghazis airport closed because of heavy [[anti-aircraft]] fire from Islamist militias aimed to hit United States [[Unmanned combat air vehicle|drones]] who were flying over the city.{{cite news|title=U.S. drones fly over Benghazi; cause airport to shut|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/14/us-protests-libya-airport-idUSBRE88D0PJ20120914|author=Hadeel Al Shalchi|publisher=Reuters|date=14 September 2012|accessdate=5 November 2012}} On 17 September, the head of Sabhas military council, Colonel Ali Dallah Gaidi survived an assassination attempt in [[Ubari]], but his wife was killed in the attack.{{cite news|title=Wife killed in failed assassination attempt on leader of Sebha Military Council; other attacks reported|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=14706|publisher=Libya Herald|date=19 September 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}} On 23 September, Libyan Prime Minister-elect [[Mustafa A.G. Abushagur]] office ordered, after meetings with representatives of Libyan political parties and security forces, all militias to either disband or come under army command in 48 hours.Grant, George (2012-09-23). [http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=14963 All Benghazi militia to be put under National Army control, others to be disbanded: official]. Libyaherald.com. Retrieved on 2012-09-30. On 25 September, Omran Shabaan died from his wounds in France. He was among the men who captured Gaddafi before his death. He was later allegedly captured and tortured in Bani Walid before being released when the prime minister visited the city earlier in the month.[http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15089 Libyan revolutionary who captured Qaddafi dies in Paris]. Libya Herald (2011-10-20). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. The [[General National Congress]] of Libya, which was evacuated that day following a firefight on a protest by disgruntled former NTC fighters,{{cite news|title=Update: National Congress evacuated following firefight outside |url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15080|publisher=Libya Herald|date=25 September 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}} hailed Shabaan as a "brave hero" and called for inquires into the circumstances of his death in order to find and punish those responsible.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/26/omran-shaban-dead_n_1915680.html Omran Shaban Dead: Rebel Who Helped Catch Gaddafi Dies After Being Captured And Tortured]. Huffingtonpost.com (2012-09-26). Retrieved on 2012-09-30. ==== October 2012 ==== {{main|Siege of Bani Walid (2012)}} On 2 October, clashes erupted between pro-government militias from Misrata and local militiamen in Bani Walid, with a result of one death and between five and ten wounded.{{cite news|title=Fatal clashes reported outside Bani Walid as forces muster for possible assault|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15547|publisher=Libya Herald|date=2 October 2012|accessdate=7 October 2012}}{{cite news|title=Clashes near Libya's Bani Walid kill one, raise tensions |url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/505861 |publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun Daily]] (AFP) |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007094122/http://www.thesundaily.my/news/505861 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |df=dmy }} On 3 October, three policemen were killed on a checkpoint in [[Susa, Libya|Susa]], with a fourth injured in a critical condition, who died days later.{{cite news|title=Fourth Sousa policeman dies|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15606|publisher=Libya Herald|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=7 October 2012}} [[Jabal al Akhdar]] district police chief Nasser Zayed blamed hardline Islamists for the attack.{{cite news|title=Libyan police 'killed by Islamists'|url=http://rthk.hk/rthk/news/englishnews/20121004/news_20121004_56_873919.htm|publisher=[[Radio Television Hong Kong]]|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}}{{cite news|title=Three policemen killed in Libya coastal town|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/libya/three-policemen-killed-in-libya-coastal-town-1.1085037#.UG1aSFDB6dY.twitter|publisher=[[Gulf News]] (AFP)|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}} By 8 October, thousands of soldiers surrounded Bani Walid and gave a deadline of 10 October to surrender the men who had tortured Omran Shaban to death, or face the town being stormed. Shelling of the town was reported, but the Misratan commanders denied they had any artillery that they could use against the town.{{cite news|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=15794 |title=Renewed clashes near Bani Walid |publisher=Libya Herald |date= |accessdate=25 January 2013}} On 9 October, Misratan fighters, who besieged Bani Walid since the beginning of the month, killed three residents, including a child, and injured seven others during an artillery attack on the town, according to Colonel Salem Waer, who was leading the Bani Walid fighters. In a counter-attack, nine Misratan fighters were wounded.{{cite news|last=Shuaib |first=Ali |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/08/us-libya-tensions-baniwalid-idUSBRE89715B20121008 |title=Libya's Bani Walid is shelled in standoff over rebel's death |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=25 January 2013}} On 12 October, a night-time curfew was imposed in Sirte by the local SSC, due to clashes between [[Warfalla]] tribesmen and Misratans fueled by the situation in Bani Walid. On the first night of the curfew, two members of the armed forces were injured by gunfire.{{cite news|title=Curfew enforced in Sirte after clashes over Bani Walid siege|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=16141|author=Mathieu Galtier|publisher=Libya Herald|date=13 October 2012|accessdate=16 October 2012}} On 16 October, [[Captain (OF-2)|Captain]] Adel Baqramawi was killed when unknown assailants threw a bomb from a pick-up truck to his car, marking at least the 15th military official to be murdered in Benghazi in 2012.{{cite news|title=Another military assassination in Benghazi|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/?p=16261|author=Maha Ellawati|publisher=Libya Herald|date=16 October 2012|accessdate=16 October 2012}} On 26 October, a masked man entered a café in Benghazi and shot twice in the face Haitham Warfali, killing him instantly. A friend of the murdered was also wounded in the leg by the attacker. Friends of the victim linked the execution with his involvement in organising demonstrations in the city to protest the blockade of Bani Walid.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/10/28/murder-in-benghazi/ Murder in Benghazi] Libya Herald, 28 October 2012 On 28 October a Gambian migrant was shot dead by militiamen in Tripoli, according to eyewitnesses.{{cite news|title=Gambian shot dead in Libya. Is there a Gambian representative in Libya?|url=http://www.foroyaa.gm/index.php/burning-issues/11626-gambian-shot-dead-in-libya-is-there-a-gambian-representative-in-libya|author=Fabakary B. Ceesay|publisher=[[Foroyaa]]|date=5 November 2012|accessdate=6 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130213173349/http://www.foroyaa.gm/index.php/burning-issues/11626-gambian-shot-dead-in-libya-is-there-a-gambian-representative-in-libya|archivedate=13 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==== November 2012 ==== On 4 November, the head of Cyrenaica Transitional Council’s military wing, Hamid Al-Hassi, narrowly survived an assassination attempt that left one of his bodyguards killed and two injured.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/05/cyrenaica-military-council-chief-escapes-assassination-attempt-report/ Cyrenaica military council chief escapes assassination attempt: report] Libya Herald, 5 November 2012 In Tripoli, the arrest attempt on Mohamed Al-Warfali, leader of a ministry of Interior SSC brigade, started clashes in Sidi Khalifa district. Warfali was arrested in October after what he was accused of supplying Bani Walid militia with weapons during [[Siege of Bani Walid (2012)|battle]] and escaped under unclear circumstances. Militiamen set on fire the SSC headquarters, damaging also a nearby hospital, and looting shops on Zawiya street{{cite news|title=Libyan militiamen set Tripoli security HQ on fire, loot shops|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/04/libya-attack-looting-idUSL5E8M449020121104|publisher=Reuters|date=4 November 2012|accessdate=4 November 2012}} Fighting lasted for much of the day, until army reinforcements arrived and Warfalli, together with 11 of his men, surrendered. Fighting allegedly killed at least 11 people, with some sources putting number up to 18, but there was no confirmation of the deaths. Angry residents also set ablaze Warfali house in the district.{{cite news|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/04/locals-reported-killed-in-central-tripoli-gun-battle-with-rogue-ssc-brigade/ |title=Locals reported killed in central Tripoli gun battle with rogue SSC brigade |publisher=Libyaherald.com |date= |accessdate=25 January 2013}} Meanwhile, a protest at Zawiyas refinery caused petrol shortage in the Libyan capital.{{cite news|title=Refinery protest causes petrol shortage in Libyan capital|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/05/us-libya-refinery-protest-idUSBRE8A40CY20121105|publisher=Reuters|date=5 November 2012|accessdate=5 November 2012}} On 5 November, the corpse of former NTC Tarhuna's representative Abdel Basset Abu Naama was found on a locked car at the town. He had been kidnapped the day before, with his body allegedly showing torture signs and a fatal gunshot into the head.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/07/former-tarhouna-ntc-representative-tortured-and-killed/ Former Tarhouna NTC representative tortured and killed] Libya Herald, 7 November 2012 In [[Khoms, Libya|Khoms]], one person was reported killed and four others injured in clashes between the SSC forces and a local militia named Katibat Nusur Al-Sahel ("The Coast Eagles").[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/06/deadly-clashes-in-khoms/ Deadly clashes in Khoms] Libya Herald, 6 November 2012 On 6 November, the dead body of a retired colonel who had supported the NTC during the war was found in his farm in Benghazi, with shots in the head and chest.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/06/retired-colonel-found-dead-in-benghazi/ Retired colonel found dead in Benghazi] Libya Herald, 6 November 2012 On 10 November, armed clashes took place in Tiji ([[Nafusa Mountains]]) between local troops and a [[Kabaw]]-based militia, when the latter tried to take weapons and ammunition from a military base in the neighbour town. One Kabaw militiamen was killed and several wounded in both sides.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/11/armed-clashes-take-place-in-nafusa-mountains/ Armed clashes take place in Nafusa Mountains] Libya Herald, 11 November 2012 On 12 November, the secretary of Sirte local council was killed by unknown gunmen outside the town’s medical institute, allegedly because his support to the NTC during the war.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/14/secretary-of-sirte-local-council-assassinated-for-pro-revolutionary-loyalties/ Secretary of Sirte Local Council assassinated for "pro-revolutionary" loyalties] Libya Herald, 14 November 2012 On 21 November, unidentified gunmen shot and killed [[Benghazi]]'s police chief Faraj al-Deirsy in front of his home in the latest attack against security officials in [[Libya]]'s second largest city.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/11/2012112173121714516.html|title=Police chief killed in Libya's Benghazi|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=21 November 2012|accessdate=21 November 2012}} ==== December 2012 ==== On 15 December, three Libyan soldiers, including two Captains, were killed in Bani Walid when they were ambushed by gunmen who were then reported to have taken full control of the Darha area.{{cite news|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/16/fresh-fighting-breaks-out-in-bani-walid/ |title=Fresh fighting breaks out in Bani Walid |publisher=Libya Herald |date=16 December 2012 |accessdate=25 January 2013}} The next day, four policemen were killed in two attacks by Islamist gunmen in Benghazi.{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20121216-libya-attacks-kill-four-policemen-two-soldiers |title=Libya attacks kill four policemen, two soldiers |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=16 December 2012 |accessdate=25 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://web.archive.bibalex.org/web/20130130164509/http://www.france24.com/en/20121216-libya-attacks-kill-four-policemen-two-soldiers |archivedate=30 January 2013 |df= }} In Tripoli, the GNC announced the temporary closure of the borders with [[Algeria]], [[Niger]], [[Chad]] and [[Sudan]], and declared southern Libya as a "closed military zone".[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/17/gnc-announces-temporary-closure-of-southern-borders-and-declares-south-a-closed-military-zone/ GNC announces temporary closure of southern borders and declares south a "closed military zone"] Libya Herald, 17 December 2012 In [[Traghan]], the head of the local council was killed and two members of his family wounded by unknown assailants.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/12/19631/ Police station in Darj attacked] Libya Herald, 12 December 2012 On 20 December, during a demonstration calling for the release of a prisoner at the Security Directorate in Benghazi, clashes erupted between protesters and security forces, leaving at least one policemen, one soldier, two armed attackers and three civilians killed, as well as 16 wounded (8 civilians and 8 from the security forces).[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/21/army-calls-for-calm-in-benghazi-as-details-of-attack-emerge/ Army calls for calm in Benghazi as details of attack emerge] Libya Herald, 21 December 2012 On 27 December, an unknown gunman killed [[Lieutenant]] Awad Mohamed Al-Fakhri and injured his mother, in their family house at [[Abyar, Libya|Al-Abyar]], near Benghazi.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/27/police-officer-shot-dead-in-al-abiar/ Police officer shot dead in Al-Abiar] Libya Herald, 27 December 2012 On 29 December, unknown assailants attacked with home-made [[dynamite]] or a grenade the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic]] church of Mar Girgis in [[Dafniya]], near Misrata, killing two Egyptians and injuring another two.{{cite news|title=Libya Coptic church blast kills two Egyptians|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20872613|publisher=BBC|date=30 December 2012|accessdate=1 January 2013}} Both Egyptian Foreign Affairs Minister [[Mohamed Kamel Amr]] and the Head of Libya’s Copts, Father Timothaus Bishara Adla condemned the attack.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/01/head-of-libyas-copts-speaks-out-on-misrata-killing/ Head of Libya’s Copts speaks out on Misrata killing] Libya Herald, 31 December 2012 Meanwhile, in Tripoli, units of the local SSC and police officers clashed again because the detention of a SSC member.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/30/incident-between-ssc-and-police-to-be-investigated/ Incident between SSC and police to be investigated] Libya Herald, 29 December 2012 In Ubari, at least two Libya Shield militiamen were killed and an unknown number injured in armed clashes.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/12/30/two-brigadesmen-die-in-local-incident-near-ubari/ Two brigadesmen die in local incident near Obari] Libya Herald, 30 December 2012 === 2013 === ==== January 2013==== On 6 January, GNC president Mohamed Magarief announced that he had been the target of an assassination attempt at the hotel in Sabha where he was staying with his delegation on a visit. He told the Libyan state television that gunmen attacked the hotel with heavy gun-fire. An ongoing battle between Magarief's personal bodyguards and the gunmen lasted for three hours and left three of his guards wounded.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2013/01/06/258878.html Head of Libya’s GNC escapes assassination attempt] Al Arabiya (AFP), 6 January 2013 Although, a spokesman for the Defense Ministry said that he believed the shooting in Sebha had not been specifically aimed at the GNC President, but linked to the intertribal clashes of the precedent days in the town.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/06/reports-emerge-of-magarief-assassination-attempt-in-sebha/ Details emerge of attack on Magarief in Sebha] Libya Herald, 6 January 2013 On 8 January, clashes erupted at the university campus in Kufra, leaving two or three killed, with the local council claiming they were unknown armed militants shot by troops, while the Toubou community claimed they were Toubou civilians assassinated by Zway militiamen.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/08/new-fatal-clashes-in-kufra/ New fatal clashes in Kufra] Libya Herald, 8 January 2013 On 10 January, angry protesters tried to storm the Nawasi brigade headquarters at Mitiga Airport, in retaliation for the killing of Najmi Ibrahim Al-Abani. The clashes that continued in Tripoli since 7 January cost the life of at least five other people, with several wounded.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/12/fashloum-youth-demand-government-action-against-nawasi-brigade-others-support-it/ Fashloum youth demand government action against Nawasi brigade; others support it] Libya Herald, 12 January 2013 {{wikinews|'Imminent threat' as Foreign Office urges Britons to leave Benghazi}} On 19 January, gunfire erupted between militiamen and the bodyguards of the Libyan Defence Minister while the latter was visiting an Air Force base in [[Tobruk]]. Mohammed Mahmoud Al-Bargati accused later his former deputy Siddiq Al-Ghaith of inciting an attempt to kill him, rejecting Al-Ghaith claims that the incident had been only a "tribal matter".[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/20/mystery-gunfire-during-ministers-tobruk-visit/ Mystery of gunfire during minister’s Tobruk visit] Libya Herald, 19 January 2013[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/20/defence-minister-says-former-deputy-behind-assassination-attempt/ Defence minister says former deputy behind assassination attempt] Libya Herald, 20 January 2013 In Ghadames, the local council denounced that the town was besieged by Zintan border guards, who had clashed with local militiamen, with no serious injuries.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/20/ghadames-local-council-says-town-is-besieged/ Ghadames local council says town is besieged] Libya Herald, 19 January 2013[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/20/ghadames-clashe-with-zintanis-report/ Ghadames clashes with Zintanis: report] Libya Herald, 20 January 2013 ==== February–May 2013==== On the weekend of 23–24 February, at least two people were killed and one wounded in Kufra, in renewed deadly clashes between Zway and Tebu tribesmen.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/02/26/army-says-it-will-impose-order-in-kufra-following-new-deadly-clashes/ Army says it will impose order in Kufra following new deadly clashes] Libya Herald, 26 February 2013 A car bomb exploded outside the French embassy injuring two French guards. While Libya called it a "terrorist attack," French President [[François Hollande]] called on the Libyans to bring the perpetrators "to justice." French Foreign Minister [[Laurent Fabius]] also said: "This was a terrorist act ... aimed at killing. The terrorists who wanted to attack France and Libya and undermine the friendship between them will pay." He then flew to Tripoli where he inspected the site of the attack with host Prime Minister [[Ali Zeidan]]. Though no one claimed responsibility for the attack, [[AQIM]] had threatened to retaliate for the [[Tuareg Rebellion (2012)|French intervention in Mali]] just a week before the incident.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/04/201342355231592873.html|title=France vows to punish Libya embassy attackers|newspaper=Al Jazeera English|date=28 April 2013|accessdate=29 April 2013}} The British Council in Tripoli was targeted by a car bomb simultaneously with the attack on the French Embassy in Tripoli.{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/libya-france-embassy-bomb-terrorist-attack-tripoli-car|title=French embassy targeted in Libyan car bomb attack|work=Channel 4 News|accessdate=22 May 2016}} It was reported that "the bombers were foiled as they were preparing to park a rigged vehicle in front of the compound gate, diplomatic sources say".{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/04/30/tripoli-on-edge-as-fears-of-additional-bombings-in-libya-escalate.html|title=Tripoli on Edge as Fears of Additional Bombings in Libya Escalate|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=22 May 2016}} On 27 April, Chadian President [[Idriss Deby]] accused Libya of not doing enough to stop Chadian mercenaries from training at a camp set up near Benghazi. He said: "Libya is now infested with mercenaries. Camps are set up [for] them in Benghazi where Chadians are assembled and recruited. I know who is directing and commanding those mercenaries. I call on Libyan authorities to take every possible measure to spare Chad from new plot being originates in their country." Libyan Ambassador to the UN [[Ibrahim Dabbashi]] said Deby's claims were not credible: "The president of Chad used to be a good friend of [Muammar] Gaddafi. He [Deby] was blackmailing Gaddafi in the past to get the money to support the regime ... Maybe [Deby] now is looking for a kind of support outside his country."{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/04/2013427173751845270.html|title=Chad says Libya not tackling 'mercenaries'|newspaper=Al Jazeera English|date=28 April 2013|accessdate=29 April 2013}} The next day about 200 heavily armed, including anti-aircraft weapons, surrounded the foreign ministry building demanding an end to former government officials from the old regime getting leadership positions in the new regime. The commander of the group surrounding the building said that it had been targeted as officials from the former regime worked there. He added: "The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will remain closed until the political isolation law is implemented."{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/04/2013428102159904364.html|title=Libya fighters surround foreign ministry|newspaper=Al Jazeera English|date=28 April 2013|accessdate=29 April 2013}} On 30 April, armed men surrounded the Justice Ministry for the same reason.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/04/2013430114328160960.html|title=Armed men surround Libya's justice ministry|author=|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2016}} On 3 May, several hundred people protested in Tripoli's Algeria Square against those who laid siege to the aforementioned ministries. They carried placards that read: "The era of the militias is over," "Attacks on the ministries are attacks on the Libyan people" and "No to weapons, yes to dialogue." As they marched to Martyrs' Square they were attacked by others who supported the adoption of a law to ban members of the previous regime for partaking in the incumbent regime.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/05/20135319178873795.html|title=Pro-government protest attacked in Libya|author=|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2016}} As a result of the continued influence of militias Defence Minister [[Mohammed al-Baragthi]] announced his resignation. However, Prime Minister{{who|date=May 2013}} convinced him to rescind his resignation. ''Al Jazeera'' quoted him as saying that he "can't be a part of this, either by being silent and taking no action, or by taking any action because he can't be part of the shedding of Libyan blood if he takes any action as a responsible official or as a minister of defence."{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/05/201357101344978698.html|title=Libya defence minister cancels resignation|author=|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2016}} On 13 May, 17 people were killed in car bomb incident in Benghazi, according to the Libyan Defense Ministry.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/benghazi-hospital-blast-204/|title=Massive blast outside hospital in Benghazi, Libya, up to 17 dead (PHOTOS)|work=RT International|accessdate=22 May 2016}} ====June–July 2013==== On 4 June, in the intertribal clashes in the village at the city of Sabha, located in the south of Libya, at least six people were killed.[https://archive.is/20130616031853/http://french.irib.ir/info/afrique2/item/259808-libye-6-morts-dans-des-affrontements-tribaux-dans-le-sud Libye : 6 morts dans des affrontements tribaux dans le Sud] ;Benghazi clashes {{main|2013 Benghazi conflict}} On 8 June, at least 31 people were killed and 100 wounded in clashes in Benghazi between protesters and a militia operating with Defence Ministry approval. Five of the dead were soldiers{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Jun-09/219807-28-dead-as-protesters-attack-ex-libya-rebel-hq-medics.ashx#axzz2Vj6Oc07H|title=Death toll from Libyan clashes rises to 31: doctor|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=23 October 2014}} and one was a militiaman.{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2013/6/9/reutersworld/1306090849-medics-28-dead-as-protesters-attack-exl&sec=reutersworld |title=Medics: 28 dead as protesters attack ex-Libya rebel HQ |publisher= |accessdate=23 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611004454/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2013%2F6%2F9%2Freutersworld%2F1306090849-medics-28-dead-as-protesters-attack-exl&sec=reutersworld |archivedate=11 June 2013 |df= }} On 14 June, six soldiers were killed in Benghazi in clashes between Libyan special forces and armed protesters.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/15/us-libya-attack-benghazi-idUSBRE95E04Y20130615|title=Six Libyan soldiers killed in Benghazi violence|work=Reuters|accessdate=23 October 2014}} The previous night, an Army convoy transporting military vehicles from Tripoli to Sabha was ambushed resulting in the deaths of three of the attackers and an Army brigade commander.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/06/14/libyan-army-brigade-says-head-unit-killed-in-ambush-in-south/|title=Libyan army brigade says head of unit killed in ambush in south|work=Fox News|accessdate=23 October 2014}} On 26–27 June, 10 people were killed in clashes in Tripoli. Minister of Defence Mohammed al-Bargathi resigned after that. Two people were also killed and 17 injured in three car bomb explosions in Sabha.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/06/27/uk-libya-clashes-minister-idUKBRE95Q0OO20130627|title=Libya defence minister removed after Tripoli clashes|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}} On 26 July, Muslim Brotherhood critic Abdelsalam al-Mosmary was fatally shot after leaving a mosque following Friday prayers during Ramadan. In the aftermath protesters attacked Muslim Brotherhood property in both Benghazi and the capital Tripoli. Violence continued for the next few days.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/07/2013729163050948443.html|title=Fresh wave of unrest flares in Libya|author=|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2016}} ====August 2013==== On 14 August, Armed group seize Tripoli psychiatric hospital staff. An armed group were reported to have yesterday kidnapped the head of Tripoli’s psychiatric hospital and three members of staff, according to Solidarity Press.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/08/14/armed-group-seize-tripoli-psychiatric-hospital-staff-report/ Armed group seize Tripoli psychiatric hospital staff | Libya Herald] ====September 2013==== On 2 September, two soldiers were killed and another injured when the military vehicle they were travelling in was [[ambush]]ed by unknown armed men yesterday near Sirte.The soldiers were on the coastal road, around 40 kilometres east of Sirte, when their vehicle came under fire, Military Commander for the Sirte area, Salah Abu Hligha, told the Libya Herald. The soldiers were on their way home to Benghazi from a military mission in Tripoli. [http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/09/09/two-soldiers-killed-in-armed-ambush-near-sirte/#ixzz2gqN7nIO0 Two soldiers killed in armed ambush near Sirte | Libya Herald] On 25 September, The son of the Libya’s Defence Minister, Abdullah Al-Thini, was abducted yesterday afternoon, a source close to the Ministry of Defence told the Libya Herald under the condition of anonymity.He was kidnapped in Janzour, but the reasons behind the abduction are still unknown.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/09/25/defence-ministers-son-abducted/#ixzz2gqI2xAGD Defence Minister’s son abducted | Libya Herald] On 27 September, One man was reported killed and two others injured when the police station in Gubba was damaged in a massive car bomb attack early this morning, around sunrise.The dead man and the two injured – all said to be Egyptians – were in a house next door to the police headquarters.The reasons for the attack are unclear. The complex also houses the National Security Directorate, the town’s court, the prosecutor’s offices and the local registration and licensing authorities.The size of the bomb was such that parts of the buildings were destroyed. There were only charred parts left of the vehicle used in the bombing.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/09/27/bomb-attack-in-gubba/#ixzz2gqHPKXNd Bombers target police station in Gubba: 1 man killed | Libya Herald] A group of tribal elders in southern Libya are reported to have held a preparatory meeting in Obari on Thursday to discuss the possibility of setting up a "Fezzan Supreme Council" similar to the Cyrenaica Transitional Council set up last year by Cyrenaica federalists.However, reports that the meeting declared Fezzan, one of the three Libyan historic provinces, a federal state within Libya have been denied by a local source. He said that a meeting to decide on the future of the Fezzan would be held next week. "Yesterday’s meeting was like an advertisement for the main meeting next week in Obari," the source said.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/09/27/fezzan-federalists-plan-in-obari/#ixzz2gqHpxlbm Fezzan federalists plan in Obari | Libya Herald] On 29 September, Three security officials were murdered in separate attacks in Benghazi today, according to the spokesman for Benghazi Joint Security Room, Abdullah Al-Zaidi. Colonel Abdulkadir Mohamed Ahmed Al-Madani, Associate Director of Intelligence in the eastern region was seven shots by unknown assailants in a black Jeep in front of his home in the city’s Laithi district. He died instantly, Zaidi told the Libya Herald. One of his sons who was with him was also shot and was taken to hospital.Helicopter pilot Ali Adam Aldgara died when a bomb blew up under his car in the Suq Zamzam area.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/09/29/three-security-officials-murdered-in-benghazi/#axzz2gq6hSr5k Three security officials murdered in Benghazi | Libya Herald] ====October 2013==== In October a United Nations report said that torture and ill-treatment, sometimes resulting in death, was "widespread" in Libyan jails. This torture was most frequently used "immediately after arrest and during the first days of interrogation" according to the report. The UN estimates about 8,000 people are still being held in relation to the 2011 conflict. The United Nations Support Mission in Libya said it has recorded 27 deaths in custody since late 2011 "where there is significant information to suggest that torture was the cause", with 11 of the cases occurring in 2013. The report did note however that the use of torture was happening "despite the efforts of the Libyan authorities which are committed at the highest level to ending torture and to ensuring the proper functioning of the criminal justice system" and recommended that detainees held by brigades be handed over to "effective state control".{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24356037 | work=BBC News | title=Torture 'widespread' in Libyan jails - UN report | date=1 October 2013}} On 2 October, a group of locals attacked and torched the police station in Suq Al-Juma following the death of a local resident.The man, who has not been named, was shot dead by the Quwat Al-Rada, the special deterrence force in Tripoli. It claims the man, originally from Ajilat, southwest of Sabratha, was drunk and resisted arrest.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/10/04/police-stations-in-benghazi-attacked/#axzz2gq6hSr5k Police stations in Benghazi attacked | Libya Herald] Also on 2 October, [[2013 attack on the Russian Embassy in Tripoli|gunmen attacked the Russian embassy in Tripoli]].{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/libya-russian-embassy-attack-651/|title=Gunmen attack Russian embassy in Libya's Tripoli|work=RT International|accessdate=22 May 2016}} The attack on Russia’s embassy in Tripoli came as retaliation after a Russian woman killed a local officer and injured his mother, the Foreign Ministry confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/russian-embassy-libya-attack-693/|title=Tripoli embassy attack sparked after Libyan officer killed by Russian woman - FM|work=RT International|accessdate=22 May 2016}} Jebel Nafusa towns united over road attacks and closures. Responding to the closure of the main road linking towns in the Nafusa mountains to Tripoli and attacks on people who were using it, local councils in the region decided to set up a joint committee to coordinate on the region’s affairs and problems. The towns taking part were Zintan, Jadu, Mizdah, Ghariyan, Nalut, Qala and Rujban. At a meeting in Nalut, representatives of the towns’ local councils said that a safer alternative route to the capital had to be found to the one passing through Warshefana territory.[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/10/02/jebel-nafusa-towns-unite-over-road-attacks-and-closures/#ixzz2gqEAdpIc Jebel Nafusa towns unite over road attacks and closures | Libya Herald] On 4 October, police stations in Benghazi were attacked. Two police stations were bombed in Benghazi in what was being seen as a linked attack. Sabri police station was attacked at around 4.30 am. Three and a half hours later, a bomber went off at Birkah police station – the fifth time it has been attacked this year. In both cases, there was damage to the buildings but no casualties. On 5 October, gunmen killed at least 12 Libyan soldiers in an attack on a checkpoint near the city of Bani Walid, a former stronghold of supporters of Muammar Gadhafi, security officials said. "The ambush happened on the road between Bani Walid and the town of Tarhouna, where the army had a checkpoint. They came under heavy gunfire. Between 12 and 15 soldiers were killed," said Ali Sheikhi, a spokesman for the army joint chief of staff. Army Capt. Hassan al-Saidah said 15 soldiers had been killed and five wounded in the attack, which forced officials to close the main road to Bani Walid.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Oct-05/233676-gunmen-attack-libyan-military-kill-15-soldiers-libya-news-agency.ashx#ixzz2gqOpwt7W |title=Libyan checkpoint ambush kills at least 12 soldiers | News , Middle East |publisher=The Daily Star |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} On 10 October Prime Minister Ali Zeidan was [[2013 Libyan coup d'état attempt|kidnapped]] for several hours in what he later referred to as an attempted coup.{{cite news |title=Libya PM Zeidan's brief kidnap was 'attempted coup' |author= |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24496357 |newspaper=BBC News |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=13 October 2013}} ====November 2013==== On 16 November, militias from Misrata clashed in Tajoura, an eastern Tripoli suburb where checkpoints were set up to keep outside militia from entering the city. The news followed imams calling for an end to the militias, which in turn led to violence that erupted at an anti-militia protest that also called for resignation of the government the previous day in Tripoli and occurred during mourning for the dead at that protest. At least 45 people were killed and 400 wounded, according to Justice Minister [[Salah al-Marghani]] said.{{cite news |title=Libya: Misrata militias besiege Tripoli suburb |author= |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/11/16/Libya-Misrata-militias-besiege-Tripoli-suburb.html |newspaper=Al Arabia News |date=16 November 2013 |accessdate=16 November 2013}} The next day another person was killed and dozens others were wounded as clashes continued and a 48-hour [[state of emergency]] was declared, while Prime Minister Ali Zeidan called for those from outside the city to withdraw. He said: "The armed manifestations and bullying on the state with the weapons that were seized during the revolution (against Muammar Gaddafi) is unaccepted by the people" and the violence by outside militias "would have negative and catastrophic consequences."{{cite news |title= State of emergency declared in Libyan capital |author=|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/11/state-emergency-declared-libyan-capital-20131116221716364104.html|newspaper=Al Jazeera |date=17 November 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2013}} On 17 November the deputy intelligence chief, Mustafa Noah, was also kidnapped outside Tripoli airport.{{cite news |title= Libya's deputy spy chief kidnapped at airport|author=|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/17/us-libya-militias-idUSBRE9AG04A20131117|newspaper=Reuters |date=17 November 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2013}} The same day, the head of Tripoli's municipal council, Al-Sadat al-Badri, said that a strike being carried out on the day (Sunday is a working day in the Middle East) would go on for three days if the demands of a majority of public and private sectors' demands for the militiamen to leave was not met. He said: "We have declared a strike for three days from today, but if our demands are not met we will continue. We will not negotiate with them. Things are as clear as the sun, we want a decision." The call for a strike was to allow "the government, the police and the army." Businesses and schools were closed but essential services like pharmacies, hospitals and petrol pumps were open. Residents were also armed as they set up checkpoints and barricades of metal, wood and tires to protect the various neighbourhoods amid fears of renewed violence. The Misrata militia was reported to have abandoned its headquarters in south Tripoli's Gharghour, according to [[state media]]. Late the previous day the government-affiliated militia, the Libya Shield-Central Command, said it was in control of Gharghour and that it would hand it over to the government.{{cite news |title= Libya's capital goes on strike over violence |author= |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/11/libya-capital-goes-strike-over-violence-2013111713829474224.html|newspaper=Al Jazeera |date=17 November 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2013}} The next day, Benghazi's military governor Colonel [[Abdallah al-Saati]] survived an assassination attempts that killed one other person and wounded another in his motorcade. According to a parliamentary security committee official, Noah was also released.{{cite news |title=Libya regional official escapes assassination |author= |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/11/libya-regional-official-escapes-assassination-2013111810205876630.html|newspaper=Al Jazeera |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}} The Misrata militia also began withdrawing as the army moved to secure the sites."{{cite news |title= Libya militia starts Tripoli withdrawal after clashes |author=|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/18/uk-libya-security-idUKBRE9AH0BA20131118|newspaper=Reuters |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}} Withdrawal of Misrati militias was soon followed by withdrawal of militias from cities of [[Jadu, Libya|Jadu]]{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/11/19/jadu-brigade-gives-up-tripoli-base/#axzz2l77R4zs8 |title=Jadu brigade gives up Tripoli base |publisher=Libya Herald |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} and [[Gharyan]],{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/11/19/ghariyan-militia-quits-tripoli/#axzz2l77R4zs8 |title=Ghariyan militia quits Tripoli |publisher=Libya Herald |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} and also powerful Tripoli Nawasi brigade.{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90777/8461218.html |title=Libya moves main armed militia group out of capital - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.peopledaily.com.cn |date=2013-11-20 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} Other militias also withdrew from the capital.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/21/uk-libya-security-idUKBRE9AK0OA20131121 |title=More rival militias withdraw from Libyan capital | Reuters |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} Yet protesters gatheres again on 22 November to urge the other militias in the capital to withdraw.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/11/libyans-renew-pressure-militias-vacate-20131122153440975308.html |title=Libyans renew pressure on militias to vacate - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} On 25 November in the Benghazi neighborhood of Birkah, fighting between the army special forces Thunderbolt Brigade and the militant Islamist group Ansar al-Sharia started after the Islamists first attacked a military position. The Thunderbolt Brigade was soon reinforced by armed locals, and after a day of heavy fighting the Ansar al-Sharia bases within the city were destroyed and all of its militiamen seemed to have somehow simply "vanished" from the city. The heavy fighting on this day left at least 6 soldiers and 1 civilian dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/11/25/benghazi-fighting-subsides-as-ansar-al-sharia-disappears/|title=Benghazi fighting subsides as Ansar Al-Sharia "disappears"|work=Libya Herald|accessdate=23 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/25/world/meast/libya-violence/|title=Nine killed in clashes between army, Islamist group in Benghazi, Libya|date=25 November 2013|work=CNN|accessdate=23 October 2014}} On 28 November, 3 soldiers were killed and 3 others wounded in clashes with militants in the Sidi Khalifa district of Benghazi after they stopped a car loaded with weapons, explosives, and large sums of money that was trying to enter the city from the east. Another soldier was shot dead when militants in a van fired a volley at two soldiers as they got into a car. According to a medic at Benghazi's Al-jala hospital, "the soldier died after being shot in the head". Special Forces defending the hospital were shot at later in the night though no casualties were reported.{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/28/us-libya-security-idUSBRE9AR0M020131128 |title=Four Libyan soldiers killed in new violence in Benghazi |publisher=Reuters |date=2013-11-28 |accessdate=2013-12-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spacewar.com/reports/Three_Libyan_soldiers_killed_in_Benghazi_clash_medic_999.html |title=Three Libyan soldiers killed in Benghazi clash: medic |publisher=Spacewar.com |date=2013-11-28 |accessdate=2013-12-07}} ====December 2013==== On 5 December, an American teacher was gunned down while out on a morning jog in the al-Fwihet neighborhood of Eastern Benghazi.{{cite web|author= |url=https://news.yahoo.com/us-teacher-shot-dead-libya-39-benghazi-130747218.html |title=No responsibility claimed in American teacher's death in Benghazi - Yahoo News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}} ===2014=== ====January 2014==== On 18 January, the Libyan air force attacked targets in the south of Libya because of unrest blamed on forces loyal to ousted leader Muammar Gaddafi.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/libya-air-force-south-834/|title=Libyan air force attacks targets in south after gunmen storm airbase|publisher=|accessdate=23 October 2014}} The government also declared a state of emergency after Gaddafi loyalists took over the Tamahind air force base near the southern city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]].{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/01/18/346409/libya-declares-state-of-emergency/ |title=PressTV |publisher= |accessdate=22 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227101642/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/01/18/346409/libya-declares-state-of-emergency/ |archivedate=27 February 2014 |df= }} On 22 January ''[[Voice of Russia]]'' featured a report with Libyans who claimed that much of the southern half of the country as well as Bani Walid had fallen under the control of the "Green" Gaddafi loyalists, and that some foreign Libyan embassies were flying the Gaddafi-era green flag in support. The interviewed Libyans claimed to be fighting against a Western-backed "puppet government" with ties to [[Al-Qaeda]], and charged that [[Qatar]] was paying [[Sudan]]ese pilots to bomb their positions.[http://voiceofrussia.com/2014_01_22/Green-Libyan-flags-are-waving-once-again-Interview-7710/ Green Libyan flags are waving once again - Interview]. ''The Voice of Russia''. 2014-01-22. On the other hand, the more government-friendly ''[[Libya Herald]]'' newspaper reported that a large contingent of Gaddafi-friendly fighters were scattered near Ajilat as they tried to aid other Gaddafi-loyalists in Sabha, with five of them killed. The report claimed that if the events were part of a coordinated movement, "it does not appear to be well organised, let alone have any significant or measurable support."Wahab, Ashraf Abdul. [http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/01/22/qaddafi-supporters-heading-to-ajilat-killed-in-sabratha-report/ Qaddafi supporters heading to Ajilat killed in Sabratha: report]. ''Libya Herald''. 2014-01-22. On 24 January, nine soldiers were killed and 27 injured near Tripoli in clashes with Gaddafi loyalists.[http://www.afriquejet.com/news/730-army-9-soldiers-killed-in-clashes-with-gunmen.html Army: 9 soldiers killed in clashes with gunmen] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130052152/http://www.afriquejet.com/news/730-army-9-soldiers-killed-in-clashes-with-gunmen.html# |date=30 January 2014 }}. ''Afrique en Ligne''. 2014-01-24. ==== Escalation of conflict ==== {{main|2014 Libyan Civil War}} A significant escalation of the conflict began in May 2014. On 18 May 2014, the parliament building was reported to have been stormed by troops loyal to General [[Khalifa Haftar]],{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1264043/rogue-generals-troops-storm-libyan-parliament|title=Rogue General's Troops Storm Libyan Parliament|publisher=Sky News|date=18 May 2014}} reportedly including the [[Zintan Brigade]],{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/gunfire-erupts-outside-libyan-parliament-2014518141318644382.html|title=Gunfire erupts outside Libyan parliament|author=|date=18 May 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera}} in what the Libyan government described as an attempted coup.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/libya-rogue-general-khalifa-haftar-storms-parliament-attempted-coup-1449045|title=Libya: Rogue General Khalifa Haftar Storms Parliament in Attempted 'Coup'|author=Fiona Keating|date=18 May 2014|publisher=International Business Times}} ==See also== * [[Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War]] * [[Gaddafi loyalism after the Libyan Civil War]] * [[Reactions to Innocence of Muslims]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/documents/world/security-incidents-in-libya-since-june-2011/66/ Security incidents in Libya since June 2011 – U.S. Embassy Tripoli, Libya. Regional Security Office] [[Washington Post]] {{2011 Libyan Civil War}} {{Arab Spring}} {{Post-Cold War African conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Factional violence in Libya (2011-14)}} [[Category:Wars involving Libya]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Libyan Crisis (2011–present)]] [[Category:Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in Libya]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2011|Libya]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2012|Libya]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2013|Libya]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014|Libya]] [[Category:2011 in Libya]] [[Category:2012 in Libya]] [[Category:2013 in Libya]] [[Category:2014 in Libya]] [[Category:Arab Winter in Libya]]
