{{EngvarB|date=August 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} [[File:EdinburghNYE.jpg|thumb|right|Fireworks for [[Edinburgh's Hogmanay]]]] {{Culture of Scotland}}'''Hogmanay''' ({{IPA-sco|ˌhɔɡməˈneː|lang}};<ref>''The Concise Scots Dictionary'' Cambers (1985) {{ISBN|0-08-028491-4}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|lang|ˌ|h|ɒ|ɡ|m|ə|ˈ|n|eɪ}} {{respell|HOG|mə|NAY|'}}<ref>{{Cite Oxford Dictionaries|Hogmanay}}</ref>) is the [[Scots language|Scots]] word for the last day of the year and is synonymous with the celebration of the [[New Year]] ([[Gregorian calendar]]) in the Scottish manner. It is normally followed by further celebration on the morning of [[New Year's Day]] (1 January) or, in some cases, 2 January—a [[Bank holidays in Scotland|Scottish bank holiday]].
The origins of Hogmanay are unclear, but it may be derived from [[Norse activity in the British Isles|Norse]] and [[Gaels|Gaelic]] observances. Customs vary throughout Scotland, and usually include [[gift-giving]] and visiting the homes of friends and neighbours, with special attention given to the [[first-foot]], the first guest of the new year.
==Etymology== The [[etymology]] of the word is obscure. The earliest proposed etymology comes from the 1693 ''Scotch Presbyterian Eloquence'', which held that the term was a corruption of the [[Greek language|Greek]] ''{{transl|el|agía mína}}'' ({{lang|el|αγία μήνα}}), or "holy month".<ref name="SPE">{{cite book |title=Scotch Presbyterian eloquence display'd |publisher=J. Johnson |location=Rotterdam |last1=Crokatt |first1=Gilbert |last2=Monroe |first2=John |date=1738 |orig-year=First published 1693 |page=120 |quote=It is ordinary among some plebeians in the South of Scotland to go about from door to door upon New-years Eve, crying Hagmane, a corrupted Word from the Greek {{lang|el|αγια μηνη}}, which signifies the Holy Month. |url=https://archive.org/stream/scotchpresbyteri00crok#page/120/}}</ref> The three main modern theories derive it from a French, [[Norse language|Norse]] or [[Goidelic languages|Gaelic]] root.
The word is first recorded in a Latin entry in 1443 annals as ''hagnonayse''.<ref name="OED">"hogmanay, n.". OED Online. December 2014. Oxford University Press. (accessed 22 December 2014).</ref> The first appearance in English came in 1604 in the records of [[Elgin, Moray|Elgin]], as ''hagmonay''.<ref>"delatit to haue been singand hagmonayis on Satirday"</ref> Subsequent 17th-century spellings include ''Hagmena'' (1677),<ref name="OED"/> ''Hogmynae night'' (1681),<ref name="OED"/> and ''Hagmane'' (1693) in an entry of the ''Scotch Presbyterian Eloquence''.<ref name="SPE"/><ref name=DSL>{{cite web|url=http://www.dsl.ac.uk/entry/snd/hogmanay |title=Hagmane |author= |date= |work=Dictionary of the Scots Language |publisher= |accessdate=21 December 2011 }}</ref>
Although "Hogmanay" is currently the predominant spelling and pronunciation, a number of variant spellings and pronunciations have been recorded, including:<ref name=CSD>Robinson, Mairi (ed) ''The Concise Scots Dictionary'' (1985) The Scottish National Dictionary Association {{ISBN|0-08-028491-4}}</ref> {{div col}} *Hoghmanay<ref name=DSL/> *Hagman(a)e<ref name=CSD/> *Hagmonay<ref name=CSD/> *Hagmonick<ref name=DSL/> *Hanginay (Roxburghshire)<ref name=DSL/> *Hangmanay<ref name=CSD/> *Hogernoany (Shetland)<ref name=DSL/> *Hogminay/Hogmenay/Hogmynae<ref name=DSL/> *Hoguemennay<ref name=DSL/> *Huggeranohni (Shetland)<ref name=DSL/> *Hu(i)gmanay<ref name=CSD/> {{div col end}} with the first syllable variously being {{IPA|/hɔg/}}, {{IPA|/hog/}}, {{IPA|/hʌg/}}, {{IPA|/hʌug/}} or {{IPA|/haŋ/}}.
===Possible French etymologies=== It may have been introduced to [[Middle Scots]] via French. The most commonly cited explanation is a derivation from the northern French dialectal word ''hoguinané'', or variants such as ''hoginane'', ''hoginono'' and ''hoguinettes'', those being derived from 16th century [[Middle French]] ''aguillanneuf'' meaning either a gift given at New Year, a children's cry for such a gift, or New Year's Eve itself.<ref name=CSD/><ref name="Campbell">[[John Gregorson Campbell|Campbell, John Gregorson]] (1900, 1902, 2005) ''The Gaelic Otherworld''. Edited by Ronald Black. Edinburgh, Birlinn Ltd. {{ISBN|1-84158-207-7}} p. 575: "'Hogmanay' is French in origin. In northern French dialect it was ''hoguinané'', going back to Middle French ''aguillaneuf'', meaning a gift given on New Year's eve or the word cried out in soliciting it."</ref> Compare also the apparent Spanish cognate ''aguinaldo/aguilando'', with a suggested Latin derivation of ''{{lang|la|hoc in anno}}'' "in this year."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://buscon.rae.es/drae/srv/search?val=aguilando |title=Aguilando |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=www.rae.es |publisher=Real Academia Española |access-date=21 September 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
This explanation is supported by a children's tradition, observed up to the 1960s in some parts of Scotland at least, of visiting houses in their locality on New Year's Eve and requesting and receiving small treats such as sweets or fruit. The second element would appear to be ''{{lang|fr|l'an neuf}}'' (the New Year), with some sources suggesting a druidical origin of the practice overall.<ref>''Encyclopædia Britannica Vol I'' (1823) 6th Edition</ref> Compare those to [[Norman language|Norman]] ''hoguinané'' and the obsolete customs in [[Jersey]] of crying ''ma hodgîngnole'', and in [[Guernsey]] of asking for an ''oguinane'', for a New Year gift (see also [[La Guiannee]]). In Québec, "la guignolée" was a door-to-door collection for the poor.<ref>Roy, Pierre-Georges [http://www.uquebec.ca/~uss1083/ssvdp/Texte%20de%20Pierre%20Georges%20ROY.pdf Les petites choses de notre histoire] Garneau (1944)</ref>
Other suggestions include ''au [[wikt:gui#French|gui]] mener'' ("lead to the [[mistletoe]]"),<ref name = Chambers>Chambers, R. ''Popular Rhymes of Scotland'' Chambers (1841) 3rd Edition</ref> ''à {{linktext|gueux}} mener'' ('bring to the beggars'),<ref name=Chambers/> ''au gui l'an neuf'' ('at the mistletoe the new year', or ''(l')homme est né'' ('(the) man is born').<ref name="scotland.org">[http://www.scotland.org/whats-on/hogmanay/ "Hogmanay", Scotland.org]. Retrieved 14 May 2009.</ref>
===Possible Goidelic etymologies=== The word may have come from the [[Goidelic languages]]. [[James George Frazer|Frazer]] and Kelley report a [[Manx language|Manx]] new-year song that begins with the line ''To-night is New Year's Night, Hogunnaa'' but did not record the full text in Manx.<ref>Frazer, Sir James George ''The Golden Bough'' 1922</ref><ref>Kelley, Ruth ''The Book of Hallowe'en'' (1919)</ref> Kelley himself uses the spelling ''Og-u-naa... Tro-la-la''<ref>Y Kelley, Yuan ''Fockleyr Gailckagh as Baarlagh'' (1866) The Manx Society</ref> whereas other sources parse this as ''hog-un-naa'' and give the modern Manx form as ''Hob dy naa''.<ref name = Folklore>''Folk-lore – A Quarterly Review of Myth, Tradition, Institution and Custom Vol II'' (1891) The Folk-lore Society</ref> Manx dictionaries though give ''[[Hop-tu-Naa]]'' ({{IPA-gv|hopʰ tθu neː}}), generally glossing it as "Hallowe'en",<ref name=Brod>Broderick, G. ''A Handbook of Late Spoken Manx'' Niemeyer (1984) {{ISBN|3-484-42904-6}}</ref><ref>Fargher, Douglas ''Fockleyr Baarle-Gaelg'' (1979) Shearwater Press {{ISBN|0-904980-23-5}}</ref> same as many of the more Manx-specific folklore collections.<ref>Moore, A.W. ''Manx Ballads & Music'' (1896) G R Johnson</ref>
In this context it is also recorded that in the south of Scotland (for example [[Roxburghshire]]), there is no {{angbr|m}}, the word thus being ''Hunganay'', which could suggest the {{angbr|m}} is intrusive.<ref name = Folklore/>
Another theory occasionally encountered is a derivation from the phrase ''thog mi an èigh/eugh'' ({{IPA-gd|hok mi ˈɲeː|}}, "I raised the cry"), which resembles ''Hogmanay'' in pronunciation and was part of the rhymes traditionally recited at New Year<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article62422547 |title=Origin of Hogmanay |author= |date=5 January 1940 |work=Townsville Daily Bulletin |publisher= |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> but it is unclear if this is simply a case of [[folk etymology]].
Overall, Gaelic consistently refers to the New Year's Eve as ''Oidhche na Bliadhn(a) Ùir(e)'' ("the Night of the New Year") and ''Oidhche Challainn'' ("the Night of the [[Calends]]").<ref>MacBain, A. ''Etymological Dictionary of the Gaelic Language'' (1896)</ref><ref>Dwelly, E. ''The Illustrated Gaelic-English Dictionary'' (1941)</ref><ref>Mark, Colin ''The Gaelic-English Dictionary'' (2004) Routledge {{ISBN|0-415-29761-3}}</ref>
===Possible Norse etymologies=== Some authors reject both the French and Goidelic theories, and instead suggest that the ultimate source both for the Norman French, Scots, and Goidelic variants of this word have a common Norse root.<ref name = Harrison>Harrison, W. ''Mona Miscellany'' (1869) Manx Society</ref> It is suggested that the full forms * "Hoginanaye-Trollalay/Hogman aye, Troll a lay" (with a Manx cognate ''Hop-tu-Naa, Trolla-laa'') * "Hogmanay, Trollolay, give us of your white bread and none of your gray"<ref>Chambers, R. ''Popular Rhymes of Scotland'' (1841) W&R Chambers p. 165</ref> invoke the hill-men ([[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] ''haugmenn'', cf [[Old English|Anglo-Saxon]] ''hoghmen'') or "elves" and banishes the [[troll]]s into the sea (Norse ''á læ'' "into the sea").<ref name = Harrison/><ref name=Repp>Repp, Thorl ''On the Scottish Formula of Congratulation on New Year's Eve – "Hogmanay, Trollalay" (1831) Transactions of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland Vol IV''</ref> Repp furthermore makes a link between "Trollalay/Trolla-laa" and the rhyme recorded in ''[[Percy's Relics]]'': "Trolle on away, trolle on awaye. Synge heave and howe rombelowe trolle on away", which he reads as a straightforward invocation of troll-banning.<ref name = Repp/><ref>Percy, Thomas ''Percy's Reliques'' (1765)</ref>
==Origins== The roots of Hogmanay perhaps reach back to the celebration of the [[winter solstice]] among the [[Norsemen|Norse]],<ref name=Johnson>[http://www.historic-uk.com/HistoryUK/HistoryofScotland/The-History-of-Hogmanay/ Johnson, Ben. "The History of Hogmanay", Historic UK]</ref> as well as incorporating customs from the [[Gaels|Gaelic]] celebration of [[Samhain]]. The [[Viking]]s celebrated [[Yule]],<ref name=Johnson/> which later contributed to the [[Twelve Days of Christmas]], or the "Daft Days" as they were sometimes called in Scotland. Christmas was not celebrated as a festival and Hogmanay was the more traditional celebration in Scotland.<ref name="scotland.org" /> This may have been a result of the [[Protestant Reformation]] after which Christmas was seen as "too [[Papist]]".<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/12/1230_021231_hogmanay.html Bogle, Lara Suziedelis. "Scots Mark New Year With Fiery Ancient Rites", ''National Geographic News'', 31 December 2002]</ref>
==Customs== There are many customs, both national and local, associated with Hogmanay. The most widespread national custom is the practice of [[first-footing]], which starts immediately after midnight. This involves being the first person to cross the threshold of a friend or neighbour and often involves the giving of symbolic gifts such as [[salt]] (less common today), [[coal]], [[shortbread]], [[whisky]], and [[black bun]] (a rich [[fruit cake]]), intended to bring different kinds of luck to the householder. Food and drink (as the gifts) are then given to the guests. This may go on throughout the early hours of the morning and well into the next day (although modern days see people visiting houses well into the middle of January). The first-foot is supposed to set the luck for the rest of the year. Traditionally, tall, dark-haired men are preferred as the first-foot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/highlandsandislands/hi/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_8434000/8434760.stm|title=Hogmanay traditions, old and new|publisher=BBC|date=30 December 2015}}</ref>
===Local customs=== {{refimprove section|date=January 2017}} [[File:Stonehave fireballs 2003.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Stonehaven Fireballs Ceremony 2003|[[Stonehaven]] Fireballs Ceremony 2003]][[File:Catalonian Sun Goddess.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Catalan Sun Goddess from the Hogmanay Street Party, [[Edinburgh]] 2005]] An example of a local Hogmanay custom is the fireball swinging that takes place in [[Stonehaven]], [[Aberdeenshire]], in northeast Scotland. This involves local people making up "balls" of chicken wire filled with old newspaper, sticks, rags, and other dry flammable material up to a diameter of {{convert|2|ft}}, each attached to about {{convert|3|ft}} of wire, chain or nonflammable rope. As the Old Town House bell sounds to mark the new year, the balls are set alight and the swingers set off up the High Street from the Mercat Cross to the Cannon and back, swinging the burning balls around their heads as they go.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
At the end of the ceremony, any fireballs that are still burning are cast into the harbour. Many people enjoy this display, and large crowds flock to see it,<ref name= "StonehavenFireballs">[http://www.stonehavenfireballs.co.uk/ Stonehaven Fireball Association] photos and videos of festivities. Retrieved 31 December 2007.</ref> with 12,000 attending the 2007/2008 event.<ref name="pandj">[http://www.thisisaberdeen.co.uk/displayNode.jsp?nodeId=148760&command=displayContent&sourceNode=148586&contentPK=19422957&folderPk=85349&pNodeId=148317 Aberdeen Press and Journal] 2 January 2008. "around 12,000 turned out in Stonehaven to watch the town's traditional fireball ceremony." Retrieved 3 January 2008.</ref> In recent years, additional attractions have been added to entertain the crowds as they wait for midnight, such as [[Fire dancing|fire poi]], a [[pipe band]], street drumming and a firework display after the last fireball is cast into the sea. The festivities are now [[livestreaming|streamed live]] over the Internet.<ref name="StonehavenFireballs" /> Another example of a pagan fire festival is the [[burning the clavie]] in the town of [[Burghead]] in [[Moray]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In the east coast fishing communities and [[Dundee]], first-footers once carried a decorated [[herring]]. And in [[Falkland, Fife|Falkland]] in [[Fife]], local men marched in torchlight procession to the top of the [[Lomond Hills]] as midnight approached. Bakers in [[St Andrews]] baked special cakes for their Hogmanay celebration (known as "Cake Day") and distributed them to local children.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
Institutions also had their own traditions. For example, amongst the Scottish regiments, officers waited on the men at special dinners while at the bells, the Old Year is piped out of barrack gates. The sentry then challenges the new escort outside the gates: "Who goes there?" The answer is "The New Year, all's well."<ref name="visitscotland">'[http://www.visitscotland.com/library/hogmanaytraditions Hogmanay Traditions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217033654/http://www.visitscotland.com/library/hogmanaytraditions |date=17 December 2007 }}' at ''[http://www.visitscotland.com Scotland's Tourism Board]''. Retrieved 21 December 2007.</ref>
An old custom in the Highlands – which has survived to a small extent and seen some degree of revival{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} – is to celebrate Hogmanay with the ''[[saining]]'' ([[Scots language|Scots]] for 'protecting, blessing') of the household and livestock. Early on New Year's morning, householders drink and then sprinkle 'magic water' from 'a dead and living [[Ford (crossing)|ford]]' around the house (a 'dead and living ford' refers to a river ford that is routinely crossed by both the living and the dead). After the sprinkling of the water in every room, on the beds and all the inhabitants, the house is sealed up tight and branches of juniper are set on fire and carried throughout the house and byre. The juniper smoke is allowed to thoroughly fumigate the buildings until it causes sneezing and coughing among the inhabitants. Then all the doors and windows are flung open to let in the cold, fresh air of the new year. The woman of the house then administers 'a restorative' from the whisky bottle, and the household sits down to its New Year breakfast.<ref>{{Cite book| first =F. Marian | last =McNeill | authorlink = F. Marian McNeill | year =1961 | title =The Silver Bough, Vol.3: A Calendar of Scottish National Festivals, Halloween to Yule | chapter =X Hogmany Rites and Superstitions | page =113 | publisher =William MacLellan | location =Glasgow| isbn =0-948474-04-1 | url = }}</ref>
=== "Auld Lang Syne"=== {{main|Auld Lang Syne}} [[File:John Masey Wright - John Rogers - Robert Burns - Auld Lang Syne.jpg|thumb|upright|[[John Masey Wright]] and John Rogers' c. 1841 illustration of ''[[Auld Lang Syne]]''.]] The Hogmanay custom of singing "Auld Lang Syne" has become common in many countries. "Auld Lang Syne" is a Scots poem by [[Robert Burns]], based on traditional and other earlier sources. It is now common to sing this in a circle of linked arms that are crossed over one another as the clock strikes midnight for New Year's Day, though it is only intended that participants link arms at the beginning of the final verse, co-ordinating with the lines of the song that contain the lyrics to do so.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
Auld Lang Syne is now sung regularly at "[[The Proms#Last Night of the Proms|The Last Night of the Proms]]" in London by the full audience with their arms crossed over one another.
==In the media== Between 1957 and 1968, a New Year's Eve television programme, ''[[The White Heather Club]]'', was presented to herald in the Hogmanay celebrations. The show was presented by [[Andy Stewart (musician)|Andy Stewart]] who always began by singing "Come in, come in, it's nice to see you...." The show always ended with Andy Stewart and the cast singing, "Haste ye Back":
{{quote|<poem>Haste ye back, we loue you dearly, Call again you're welcome here. May your days be free from sorrow, And your friends be ever near.
May the paths o'er which you wander, Be to you a joy each day. Haste ye back we loue you dearly, Haste ye back on friendship's way.</poem>}}
The performers were [[Jimmy Shand]] and band, [[Ian Powrie]] and his band, Scottish country dancers: Dixie Ingram and the Dixie Ingram Dancers, Joe Gordon Folk Four, James Urquhart, Ann & Laura Brand, [[Moira Anderson]] & [[Kenneth McKellar (singer)|Kenneth McKellar]]. All the male dancers and Andy Stewart wore kilts, and the female dancers wore long white dresses with tartan sashes. Following the demise of the ''White Heather Club'', Andy Stewart continued to feature regularly in TV Hogmanay shows until his retirement.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/a-funny-wee-idea-for-a-show-ian-jack-misses-andy-stewart-and-the-whole-white-heather-club-crowd-1511360.html|title=A funny wee idea for a show: Ian Jack misses Andy Stewart and the whole 'White Heather Club' crowd|publisher=The Independent|date=16 October 1993}}</ref> His last appearance was in 1992.
In the 1980s comedian [[Andy Cameron]] presented the ''Hogmanay Show'' (on STV in 1983 and 1984 and from 1985 to 1990 on [[BBC Scotland]]) while Peter Morrison presented the show ''A Highland Hogmanay'' on STV/Grampian, axed in 1993.
For many years, a staple of New Year's Eve television programming in Scotland was the [[comedy sketch]] show ''[[Scotch and Wry]]'', featuring the comedian [[Rikki Fulton]], which invariably included a hilarious monologue from him as the preternaturally gloomy Reverend I.M. Jolly.
Since 1993, the programmes that have been mainstays on BBC Scotland on Hogmanay have been ''[[Hogmanay Live]]'' and [[Jonathan Watson]]'s football-themed sketch comedy show, ''[[Only an Excuse?]]''.
==Presbyterian influence== The 1693 ''Scotch Presbyterian Eloquence'' contained one of the first mentions of the holiday in official church records.<ref name="SPE"/> Hogmanay was treated with general disapproval. Still, in Scotland Hogmanay and New Year's Day are as important as [[Christmas Eve]] and [[Christmas Day]].
Although Christmas Day held its normal religious nature in Scotland amongst its [[Catholic Church in Scotland|Catholic]] and Episcopalian communities, the Presbyterian national church, the [[Church of Scotland]], discouraged the celebration of Christmas for nearly 400 years; it only became a public holiday in Scotland in 1958. Conversely, 1 and 2 January are public holidays and Hogmanay still is associated with as much celebration as Christmas in Scotland. Most Scots still celebrate New Year's Day with a special dinner, usually [[steak pie]].<ref name="aberdeen">'[http://www.aboutaberdeen.com/hogmanaycustoms.php Scottish Hogmanay Customs and Traditions at New Year]' at ''[http://www.aboutaberdeen.com About Aberdeen]''. Retrieved 21 December 2007.</ref>
[[File:Edinburgh Hogmanay Longship.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Viking longship]] is burnt during Edinburgh's annual Hogmanay celebrations (though Edinburgh has no historical connection with those [[Norse in Scotland|Norse who invaded]] Scotland).]]
==Major celebrations== As in much of the world, the largest Scottish cities – [[Glasgow]], [[Edinburgh]] and [[Aberdeen]] – hold all-night celebrations, as do [[Stirling]] and [[Inverness]]. The [[Edinburgh Hogmanay]] celebrations are among the largest in the world. Celebrations in Edinburgh in 1996–97 were recognised by the ''[[Guinness Book of Records]]'' as the world's largest New Years party, with approximately 400,000 people in attendance. Numbers have since been restricted due to safety concerns.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In 2003-4 most of the organised events were cancelled at short notice due to very high winds. The Stonehaven Fireballs went ahead as planned, however, with some 6,000 people braving the stormy weather to watch 42 fireball swingers process along the High Street.<ref name="sfa">'[http://stonehavenfireballs.co.uk/history History of the Stonehaven Fireballs Ceremony]', 3 January 2008, at ''Stonehaven Fireballs Association''. Retrieved 3 January 2008.</ref> Similarly, the 2006–07 celebrations in Edinburgh, Glasgow and Stirling were all cancelled on the day, again due to high winds and heavy rain.<ref name="bbc">'[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/6221557.stm Weather spoils Hogmanay parties]', 1 January 2007, at ''BBC News, Scotland''. Retrieved 21 December 2007.</ref> The Aberdeen celebration, however, went ahead, and was opened by the pop music group, [[Wet Wet Wet]].
==Handsel Day== {{main|Handsel Day}} Historically, presents were given in Scotland on the first Monday of the New Year. A roast dinner would be eaten to celebrate the festival. ''[[wikt:handsel|Handsel]]'' was a word for gift and hence "Handsel Day".<ref>{{OED|Handsel}} "A gift or present (expressive of good wishes)".</ref> In modern Scotland this practice has died out.

{{infobox music festival |music_festival_name = Hove Festival |image = [[Image:Hove Festival logo.jpg]] |location = [[Tromøya]], [[Arendal]], Norway |years_active= 2007 - 2014 |founders = Toffen Gunnufsen (2007 - 2008) Melvin Benn 2009 - |dates = 2 – 5 July (2013) |genre = [[Independent music|Indie]], [[Rock music|pop]], [[Heavy metal music|metal]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[electronic music]] |website = {{URL|http://www.hovefestival.com/}} |owner = Melvin Benn }} The '''Hove Festival''' ({{lang-no|Hovefestivalen}}) was a [[music festival]] held on the island [[Tromøya]] outside of [[Arendal]] in southern [[Norway]].<ref>[http://www.crackintheroad.com/music/2002-review-hove-festival-norway "Review: Hove Festival (Norway)"] ''Crack In The Road''</ref> It was held for the first time from 26 – 30 June 2007. Running for eight years and at one time the largest festival music festival in Norway<ref>[http://www.last.fm/event/79571 Last FM Calendar]</ref>, Hove Festival was discontinued after its 2014 show due to negative profits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tnp.no/norway/culture/4627-traditional-hove-festival-is-shut-down-norway-music|title=Traditional Hove Festival is Shut Down|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Hove Festival was acquired by [[Festival Republic]] in 2008 after going bankrupt. As with other [[Festival Republic]] events, there were no age restrictions, and children under the age of 12 were admitted free of charge.<ref>[http://www.hovefestivalen.no/Default.aspx?articleID=50 Hove Festival official website in Norwegian]</ref>
Hove strove to be an environmentally neutral festival<ref>[http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/2185591 Hove Festival 2007: the DiS review]. ''Drowned in Sound''.</ref>, both buying carbon offset quotes for all power and transportation used during and prior to the festival, and sorting and recycling all trash produced by the event. Preparation for the festival relied heavily on volunteer work. In 2010 there were a total of 2,500 people volunteering for security, stage hand, drivers, kitchen duty and post-festival cleanup.
Hove consisted of several different areas such as the camp area, festival area and "zero" area. The camp held up to 10,000 campers and was open throughout the festival. The festival area, including the shopping street, was open to everyone who had a day bracelet or festival bracelet. The zero area, which has several fast-food shops, was open to everyone with or without bracelet.
The festival had three main performance stages: ''Hovescenen'', ''Amfiscenen'' and ''Teltscenen'' (tent stage), with ''Hovescenen'' being the largest. One of the more prominent acts at Hovescenen was [[Muse (band)|Muse]] in 2010.

In 2007 there were 72,000 visitors and 53,000 sold tickets, which included 7,700 week passes, making this Norway's largest music festival of the year.<ref>[http://www.hovefestivalen.no/Default.aspx?articleID=49 Hove Festival official website in Norwegian]</ref>

[[File:Infinity Hall.JPG|thumb|Infinity Hall in 2012]] '''Infinity Hall''' is an American performing arts venue located in [[Norfolk, Connecticut]], located in a historic building from 1883. Another venue also named Infinity Hall is operated by the same company in [[Hartford, Connecticut]].
==Infinity Hall, Norfolk== ===History=== The venue was constructed in 1883 and originally functioned as a combination [[opera house]], barber shop and saloon.<ref name=NYT>Minor, E. Kyle (July 18, 1999). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03EED9173FF93BA25754C0A96F958260 "The View From/Norfolk; Raising the Curtain on an Old Jewel"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved July 3, 2016.</ref> The building was chartered as the '''Norfolk Village Hall''', although it was commonly known as the '''Norfolk Opera House'''. It was designed by the architect George Palliser, from Bridgeport, Connecticut, who published its design in his book, ''Palliser's Court Houses, Village, Town and City Halls, Jails and Plans of Other Public Buildings'' (1889).
The Norfolk Opera House hosted [[vaudeville]] and theatrical presentations until the late 1940s. For the following four decades, it was used as a [[restaurant]] and a [[grocery store]]. The building was closed in 1994 and remained vacant for four years.<ref name=NYT /> In 1998 Kimberly Gelvin-Melville (now Kimberly Gelvin-Wilks) was given "right to first refusal" to try to get the townspeople or someone else to buy and restore the old opera house as a theater and not apartments or offices. She then produced a theater play in the dead of winter to try to draw public awareness of this glorious opera house she wished to run her own theater company in with the help of Trustees. '''The Four Poster''' was produced at '''The White Hart Inn''' in Salisbury and the Smithies saw the article in the tristate paper, Litchfield Times, about the building and Kimberly Gelvin-Melville's desire to save it. She gave the Smithies permission to purchase it because they liked all of her ideas to turn it back into a theater and run shops downstairs to help finance it. In 1998, the building was purchased by playwrights and theater producers Maura Cavanaugh and Richard Smithies for US$50,000, who undertook a US$650,000 restoration that included the rebuilding of an observation tower that was part of the original structure.<ref name=NYT /> Cavanaugh and Smithies renamed the venue the '''Greenwoods Theater''' and brought dramatic and musical productions to its stage. Mr. Smithie had asked Kimberly to play Cleopatra in a future production but sadly Mrs. Cavanaugh Smithie decided she did not wish to include Kimberly as a director or actress for fear of her getting the credit for their restorations. The theater was restored and Kimberly attended the opening but then returned to live in Australia with her former husband and daughter.
Cavanaugh and Smithies operated the Greenwoods Theater until early 2007, when financial difficulties forced them to close the venue.<ref>{{dead link|date=July 2016}} [http://www.courant.com/news/opinion/commentary/hc-plchosley.artjan04,0,5658414.story "A Pitch-Perfect Vision for Opera House"]. ''[[Hartford Courant]]''. January 4, 2009.</ref>
===Rebirth as Infinity Hall=== The venue was purchased by Dan Hincks for US $240,000 in a tax auction on February 3, 2007.<ref name=FW>{{dead link|date=July 2016}} [http://www.fairfieldweekly.com/article_print.cfm?aid=10062 "The New Guys"]. ''[[Fairfield Weekly]]''. October 16, 2008.</ref> Hincks, the chief executive officer of the [[Farmington, Connecticut]]-based printing and publishing business Data Management, undertook further interior and exterior restorations of the venue, including substantial structural improvements, a new restaurant named Infinity Bistro, a Meyer sound system, modern [[green room]] facilities, cabaret mezzanine seating, new wood finishing and expansion of the lower level. The resulting renovation created a 300-seat performing arts theater and restaurant destination. Hincks renamed the venue as Infinity Hall, telling an interviewer: "I called it Infinity because the sky is the limit when it comes to bringing people together with music."<ref name=FW />
Infinity Hall's opening night was October 17, 2008, with a concert by singer [[Kenny Rankin]]. Subsequent concerts featuring [[Melissa Manchester]], [[Spyro Gyra]], [[Richie Havens]] and [[Todd Rundgren]].<ref>{{dead link|date=July 2016}} [http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=20200890&BRD=1666&PAG=461&dept_id=553674&rfi=6 "Center Stage – Music Hall Ready to Put on a Show"]. ''[[Farmington Post]]''. November 18, 2008.</ref> In May 2009, an in-house bistro was opened.<ref name=FW /> In its first two years, Infinity Hall hosted more than 400 concerts attracting in excess of 80,000 patrons. In 2010, Infinity Music Hall was voted Best Music Hall in New England by ''[[Yankee (magazine)|Yankee]]'' magazine.
Infinity Bistro, which opened May 1, 2009, was voted Best New Restaurant in [[Litchfield County, Connecticut|Litchfield County]] and runner-up statewide in 2010 by a readers poll for ''[[Connecticut Magazine]]''.
Beginning in 2012, [[Connecticut Public Television]] and [[American Public Television]] began a series of live musical performances at Infinity Hall by well-known artists as part of their ''Infinity Hall Live'' television series.<ref>[http://ihlive.org/ "Infinity Hall Live"]. Television series, [[Connecticut Public Television]].</ref>
==Infinity Hall, Hartford== Infinity Hall, Hartford is located in a modern building on 32 Front Street, in the Front Street Entertainment District, near the [[Connecticut Convention Center]]. It seats about 500 total – 415 on the stage level plus 90 in the mezzanine. The mezzanine offers full wait service for dining before and during shows.

'''Jaspal Singh Atwal''' (born 1955) is a convicted attempted murderer, Indo-Canadian businessman, a [[Khalistan]]i sympathizer, and a member of the now-banned [[Sikhism]] extremist group [[International Sikh Youth Federation]]. He is known for being among four [[Sikhism in Canada|Canadian Sikhs]] who attempted to assassinate [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] minister [[Malkiat Singh Sidhu]] in 1986.<ref name=NationalPost /> He was involved in the 1985 attack of [[List of premiers of British Columbia|33rd]] [[Premier of British Columbia]] [[Ujjal Dosanjh]], a strong opposer of the [[Khalistan]]i movement.<ref name=NationalPost /> In 2010, he was accused of being part of in an automobile fraud case but was ruled out by the Supreme Court of Canada.<ref name=NationalPost /> In February 2018, Atwal gained attention when he was invited by [[Canada]] prime minister [[Justin Trudeau]] to a reception during a visit to [[India]] and would eventually have his invitation revoked the next day. That same year, he was arrested for issuing death threats to a local radio in [[British Columbia]].
== Background == Jaspal Atwal was originally from [[Pharala]] near a [[Phagwara]] district in [[Punjab, India]].<ref name=ThePrint>https://theprint.in/security/terrorist-centre-trudeau-reception-row-chequered-past/37512/</ref> He left for [[Canada]] at a young age and claimed to study at [[British Columbia Institute of Technology]].<ref name=TheHindu>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/khalistan-separatist-jaspal-atwal-migrated-to-canada-at-a-young-age/article22828217.ece|title=Khalistan separatist Jaspal Atwal migrated to Canada at a young age|date=22 February 2018|publisher=|via=www.thehindu.com}}</ref> He visited [[India]] once in the past few years, with a [[Facebook]] post of him visiting the [[Taj Mahal]].<ref name=ThePrint /> He is involved in construction business and is currently associated with Media Wave Communications, which runs a Surrey-based online radio station.<ref name=TheHindu /> He was also involved in numerous liberal campaigns and was seen taking pictures with hockey star [[Wayne Gretzky]] and other liberal politicians such as [[Sukh Dhaliwal]], [[Justin Trudeau]], and [[Michael Ignatieff]].<ref name=TheStar />
== Controversies == === Assassination attempts === In 1985, Atwal was charged in an attack [[Ujjal Dosanjh]], a strong opposer of the Khalistan movement, but was later acquitted.<ref name=NationalPost /> Dosanjh stated that Atwal attacked him with an iron bar over his opposition to Sikh extremism.<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/trudeau-says-sikh-extremist-should-not-have-been-invitation-to-reception/article38062142/|title=Former B.C. premier ‘speechless’ about invite to Sikh extremist Atwal|publisher=|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref> The attack left Dosanjh severely injured with 80 stitches and a broken hand.<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail /> Senior Punjab journalist Baljit Singh Balli, who met Atwal, claimed that Atwal was not involved in any attack and that he was being wrongly charged.<ref name="ThePrint" /> Dosanjh would go on to be the 33rd [[Premier of British Columbia]].<ref name=ThePrint /> On May 25, 1986, Atwal was among four men involved in attempting to assassinate Punjib minister [[Malkiat Singh Sidhu]].<ref name=NationalPost /> He was convicted for murderer and was sentenced to 20 years in jail, where he served 5 years before being paroled.<ref name=TheStar /> At the time of the attempted assassin, Sidhu was visiting [[Vancouver]] for a wedding and was forced off an isolated road near [[Gold River, British Columbia|Gold River]] when Atwal arrived.<ref name="Vancouver Sun">{{cite web|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/national/man-convicted-in-1986-shooting-poses-with-trudeaus-wife-cabinet-minister-in-india|title=Surrey man convicted in 1986 B.C. terrorist shooting poses with Trudeau's wife, cabinet minister in India|date=22 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Sidhu was struck twice and survived the shooting, however, he was assassinated in 1991 five years later at his home.<ref name="Vancouver Sun" /> At the parole, Atwal admitted he was the shooter that day.<ref name="Vancouver Sun" />
=== Justin Trudeau visit to India === Atwal sparked controversy when he was invited by [[Justin Trudeau]] to a reception during a visit to [[India]].<ref name=NationalPost>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/what-we-know-about-jaspal-atwal|title=What we know about Jaspal Atwal, the attempted murderer invited to dine with Trudeau|date=22 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref> He was seen photographed with [[Sophie Grégoire Trudeau]] and [[Minister of Infrastructure and Communities|Infrastructure Minister]] [[Amarjeet Sohi]] at an event in [[Mumbai]] and was invited to the event by [[Randeep Sarai]].<ref name=NationalPost /> Ujjal Dosanjh criticized Trudeau for inviting Atwal by stating "Do you have no shame?" and stated that the [[Canada–India relations|relations]] between Canada and India were rock bottom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/asithappens/as-it-happens-thursday-edition-1.4547153/former-liberal-cabinet-minister-blasts-trudeau-over-attempted-murderer-s-delhi-dinner-invite-1.4547156|title=Former Liberal cabinet minister blasts Trudeau over attempted murderer's Delhi dinner invite - CBC Radio|publisher=}}</ref><ref name=TheStar>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/02/22/trudeau-faces-more-trouble-on-india-trip-after-invitation-error-reports-of-snub-by-indian-pm-modi.html|title=India-Canada relations at ‘rock bottom’ after Trudeau invitation error, ex-Liberal cabinet minister says - The Star|publisher=}}</ref> Atwal's invitation was rescinded the next day and Trudeau stated that he should have never been invited.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-43154358|title=Trudeau cancels invite to Sikh separatist|date=22 February 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/khalistani-terrorist-atwal-should-never-have-been-invited-justin-trudeau-118022200718_1.html|title=Khalistani terrorist Atwal should never have been invited: Justin Trudeau|first=|last=ANI|date=22 February 2018|publisher=|via=Business Standard}}</ref> He was removed from India's travel blacklist several months ago, while the Indian government stated that he wasn't a security threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/02/22/trudeau-says-convicted-sikh-extremist-should-not-have-been-invited-to-event-in-india.html|title=Convicted Sikh extremist had been removed from India’s travel blacklist, Star told - The Star|publisher=}}</ref> Conservative Leader [[Andrew Scheer]] accused Trudeau of "wining and dining" with an attempted murderer in a Thursday tweet.<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail /> Atwal stated that he has a "friendly relationship" with Trudeau and that he "stayed away" from him to avoid embarrassment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/02/25/jaspal-atwal-says-he-stayed-away-from-trudeau-event-in-india-to-avoid-embarrassing-pm.html|title=Jaspal Atwal says he stayed away from Trudeau event in India to avoid embarrassing PM - The Star|publisher=}}</ref> On March 8, 2018, he apologized for the "embarrassment" he caused when he attended the event and told reporters that he took full responsibility for his past actions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/03/08/jaspal-atwal-says-he-has-renounced-terrorism-asked-to-attend-trudeau-event-in-india.html|title=Jaspal Atwal apologizes for ‘embarrassment’ of his presence at Trudeau event in India - The Star|publisher=}}</ref> A new committee of reporters and senators delivered its first classified report regarding the affair with 18 findings and 6 recommendations concerning allegations of foreign interference in [[List of political scandals in Canada|Canadian political affairs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/politics/new-security-oversight-committee-delivers-its-atwal-affair-report-to-trudeau/wcm/eac8d356-8d62-487f-a97c-dbe1001c41d8|title=New security oversight committee delivers its Atwal affair report to Trudeau|date=31 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Death threats against a British Columbia host === On April 25, 2018, Atwal was arrested at his home and charged for making threats to a local [[British Columbia]] host.<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail2>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-jaspal-atwal-charged-with-uttering-threats-against-bc-radio-host/|title=Jaspal Atwal charged with uttering threats against B.C. radio host|publisher=|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref> According to documents, he faces charges for "uttering threats to cause death or bodily harm".<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail2 /> His lawyer Marvin Stern stated that he made threats outside a [[Media in Vancouver|Punjabi]] radio station in the [[Vancouver]] suburb of [[Surrey, British Columbia]].<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail2 /> The day after his arrest, he made an appearance in provincial court, but was released without cash or surety.<ref name=TheGlobeAndMail2 /> He is expected to face trail on June 7 and appear at the Surrey Provincial Court to plead not guilty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/jaspal-atwal-case-date-for-trial-to-be-set-on-june-7/story-DqircjTbo45LWoZNWyTLoM.html|title=Jaspal Atwal case: Date for trial to be set on June 7|date=26 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4256684/jaspal-atwal-arraignment-threats/|title=Jaspal Atwal to plead not guilty to charges of threatening radio host in B.C.|publisher=}}</ref>
== Involvement in Canadian politics == In 2012, Atwal was invited to a budget speech of [[List of premiers of British Columbia|35th]] [[Premier of British Columbia]] [[Christy Clark]] as a guest.<ref name=ThePrint /> In addition, he backed her leadership and was among supporters who accorded her a welcome in Surrey.<ref name=Straight /> His presence in the legislature caused embarrassment and a complaint was made to the speaker.<ref name=Straight>{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/news/gurpreet-singh-jaspal-atwal-episode-reveals-why-canadian-political-establishment-should-look-hard-itself|title=Gurpreet Singh: Jaspal Atwal episode reveals why Canadian political establishment should look hard at itself|date=4 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> Clark's reaction was similar to [[Wai Young]] when she received help from Ripudaman Singh Malik, who was acquitted in the [[Air India Flight 182]] bombing.<ref name=Straight /> Clark insisted that she didn't know who Atwal was, even though he was invited to her budget speech and shook her hand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/canada/christy-clark-insists-she-doesnt-know-attempted-murderer-jaspal-atwal|title=Christy Clark insists she doesn’t know attempted-murderer Jaspal Atwal|date=5 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> After the controversy, liberal party director Tariq Ghuman resigned.<ref name=ThePrint /> Atwal was also a member of the Surrey Fleetwood-Port Kells Liberal riding association of the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Federal Liberal Party]].<ref name=NewIndianExpress>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2018/feb/22/who-is-jaspal-atwal-here-are-5-facts-about-the-khalistani-terrorist-in-stir-over-justin-trudeau-eve-1777261.html|title=Who is Jaspal Atwal? Here are 5 facts about the Khalistani Terrorist in stir over Justin Trudeau event invite|publisher=}}</ref> In a January 14, 2013 post on Facebook, Atwal was seen in a photo with a young Justin Trudeau.<ref name=ThePrint /> Atwal is a long-time supporter of the liberal party and a former donor to the federal gifts with deep ties to the party that pre-date Trudeau's tenure as prime minister.<ref name=TorontoSun>{{cite web|url=http://torontosun.com/opinion/columnists/malcolm-would-be-assassin-has-longtime-ties-to-liberals|title=MALCOLM: Would-be assassin has longtime ties to Liberals|date=23 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Official records showed that he donated $500 to the liberal party on April 9, 2011.<ref name=TorontoSun /> In May 2015, the [[Toronto Sun]] obtained two photos of him with Trudeau, with one at a campaign event in [[Vancouver]] and another one outside a house or restraint.<ref name=TorontoSun /> He was also seen taking pictures with former liberal leader [[Michael Ignatieff]] and interim leader [[Bob Rae]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Coyne|first1=Andrew|title=Coyne: The novelty of L'affaire Atwal is only that they did it on Indian soil|url=http://montrealgazette.com/opinion/andrew-coyne-laffaire-atwal-the-novelty-is-only-that-they-did-it-on-indian-soil/wcm/dbca8403-15ca-41be-81e0-8eb4e8f45379|date=February 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Gunman+part+federal+Surrey+riding+executive/6244170/story.html|title=Gunman part of federal Surrey riding executive|first=,Kim|last=Bolan|publisher=}}</ref>

{{flagicon image|Fighting Peacock Flag.png}} 200{{cite web|title=All Burma Students' Democratic Front (ABSDF) {{!}} Myanmar Peace Monitor|url=http://mmpeacemonitor.org/stakeholders/stakeholders-overview/154-absdf|website=mmpeacemonitor.org|publisher=Myanmar Peace Monitor|accessdate=12 March 2018|language=en-gb}} | casualties1 = Unknown | casualties2 = 280+ killed {{small|(2011–2014)}}{{Ref label|GOV|b}} | casualties3 = 100,000+ civilians displaced (since 2011){{cite news|title=Myanmar Soldiers Sentenced for Killing 3 Civilians in Kachin|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/20/world/asia/myanmar-soldiers-sentenced-kachin.html|accessdate=12 March 2018|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The New York Times|date=2018}}{{cite news|title=EU: Democracy fails to bring peace in Kachin|url=https://www.mmtimes.com/news/eu-democracy-fails-bring-peace-kachin.html|accessdate=12 March 2018|work=The Myanmar Times|language=en}} | notes = {{Notelist}} {{Note label|CPB|a}} Briefly clashed with the KIA from 1971 to 1972. {{Note label|GOV|b}} Burmese government claim in November 2014.{{cite news|title=Kachin rebels say 23 cadets killed by Myanmar army shell|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-kachin-casualties/kachin-rebels-say-23-cadets-killed-by-myanmar-army-shell-idUSKCN0J404020141120|accessdate=12 March 2018|work=Reuters|date=19 November 2014}} | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Myanmar conflict}} }} The '''Kachin conflict''' or '''Kachin War''' is one of the multiple conflicts collectively referred to as the [[internal conflict in Myanmar]]. [[Kachin people|Kachin]] [[Insurgency|insurgents]] have been fighting [[Tatmadaw|government soldiers]] since 1961, with only one [[ceasefire]] being brokered between them, which lasted for 17 years from 1994 to 2011. Since the resumption of hostilities in 2011, thousands of civilians have been killed, whilst over 100,000 have been displaced. Widespread use of [[landmines]],{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/burma0312ForUpload_1_0.pdf|format=PDF|title=Untold Miseries|publisher=Hrw.org|accessdate=19 February 2015}} [[child soldiers]],{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/investigation/327559/no-end-in-sight-amid-season-of-slaughter |title=No end in sight amid season of slaughter | Bangkok Post: news |publisher=Bangkok Post |date=23 December 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} systematic [[rape]] and [[torture]] have been alleged by both sides.{{cite web|url=http://oxmofm.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Pattison-FINAL.pdf|format=PDF|title=Barriers to Reform in Myanmar: Displacement of Civilians in Kachin State|publisher=Oxmofm.com|accessdate=19 February 2015}} == Background == {{further|Kachin people}} The [[Kachin people]] (or Jingpo) are a confederation of six [[ethnic group]]s whose homeland encompasses territory in the [[Kachin Hills]] of northern [[Myanmar]], in southern [[China]] ([[Yunnan]]) and in [[Northeast India|northeastern India]]. Following Burmese independence from the [[United Kingdom]], many ethnic minorities, including the Kachins, campaigned for [[self-determination]] and independence. The [[Kachin Independence Organisation]] (KIO) was founded in 1960 by dissidents as a result of the grievances between the majority-[[Bamar people|Bamar]] union government and the Kachin people. The [[Kachin Independence Army]] (KIA) was established as its armed wing in 1961, acting as a private army with 27 members. In the early 1960s the KIA began expanding and increasing in numbers, especially after the [[1962 Burmese coup d'état]] and its perceived threat by ethnic minorities. == First conflict (1961–1994) == {{further|Kachin Independence Army#History}} Following the unilateral abrogation of the [[Post-independence Burma, 1948–62|Union of Burma]]'s constitution by General [[Ne Win]] and his regime in 1962, many Kachin soldiers in the [[Tatmadaw]] (armed forces) defected and joined the [[Kachin Independence Army]] (KIA). The KIA did not only fight government soldiers, but occasionally clashed with [[Communism|communists]] outside and inside their own ranks. The [[Communist Party of Burma]] (CPB) had periodically been the KIA's ally and enemy during different years, and a communist-backed faction split from the KIA in 1989, becoming the [[New Democratic Army - Kachin]] (NDA-K). Aside from its major towns and railway corridor, KIA-controlled areas in [[Kachin State]] remained virtually independent and isolated from the rest of Myanmar from the mid-1960s through 1994, with an economy based on cross-border [[Jade trade in Myanmar|jade trade]] with [[China]] and [[Illegal drug trade|narcotics trafficking]]. After a military offensive by the [[Myanmar Army]] in 1994 seized most of the jade mines in Kachin State, the KIA signed a ceasefire agreement with the then-ruling [[State Peace and Development Council|SLORC military junta]] on 24 February 1994, which resulted in an end to large-scale fighting that lasted until June 2011. == Second conflict (2011–present) == === 2011 === Armed clashes erupted between the [[Kachin Independence Army]] (KIA) and the [[Myanmar Army]] on 9 June 2011, when government forces broke the ceasefire and attacked KIA positions along the [[Taping River]] east of [[Bhamo]], [[Kachin State]], near the ''Taping [[hydroelectric plant]]''.{{citation | title = More war than peace in Myanmar | first = Bertil | last = Lintner | newspaper = Asian Times | date = 18 December 2012}} Fighting occurred throughout Kachin State, as well as northwestern parts of [[Shan State]].{{cite web |url= http://www.kachinnews.com/news/2269-burma-army-buildup-near-laiza-suggests-push-for-kio-capital.html |title=Burma army buildup near Laiza suggests push for KIO capital |publisher= Kachin news | accessdate=19 February 2015}} On 14 June 2014, KIA insurgents captured two hydroelectric plants and took six government soldiers and several Chinese workers hostage for several hours, before the Myanmar Army stormed the buildings. A total of six people were killed and four others were wounded in the incident.{{cite web|url= https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/13/1353385_myanmar-instability-in-kachin-and-a-powerful-neighbor-to-the.html|title=Myanmar: Instability in Kachin and a Powerful Neighbor to the East |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=5 December 2014}} According to news reports, the recent fighting broke out as a result of the Burmese government's attempts to seize KIA-controlled areas, which are located around lucrative energy projects in Kachin and Shan State [[China and the Kachin State|backed by the Chinese government]].{{cite web|url= http://www.dvb.no/news/kachin-army-ambush-leaves-30-dead/16494 |title=Kachin army ambush leaves 30 dead | publisher = DVB Multimedia Group |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate= 19 February 2015}} Despite a December 2011 statement by Myanmar's President [[Thein Sein]] that he had ordered the Myanmar Army to cease its offensive in Kachin State, the conflict continued into 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/suu-kyi-should-help-with-kachin/story-fn3dxix6-1226548136647 |title= Suu Kyi 'should' help with Kachin | work =The Australian |accessdate=19 February 2015 |date=5 January 2013}} === 2012 === In 2012, the largest battles of the reignited conflict occurred in March, along the [[Myitkyina]]–[[Bhamo]] road. In April, the battle for Pangwa in [[Chipwi Township]] near [[Luchang]] was fought between the KIA and the government soldiers. Clashes erupted again in late April, when the KIA launched an offensive to capture Burmese military posts around [[Pangwa]]. The KIA offensive succeeded and the Myanmar Army retreated from the area by the end of April.{{cite web|url=http://www.kachinnews.com/~kngenmvs/news/2487-fighting-between-kio-and-army-continues-in-chipwe-pangwa.html |title=Fighting between KIO and army continues in Chipwe, Pangwa |publisher=Kachinnews.com |date=2013-02-25 |accessdate=2018-03-12}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kachinnews.com/news/2285-kio-tightens-grip-on-former-nda-k-stronghold-pangwa.html |title=KIO tightens grip on former NDA-K stronghold Pangwa |publisher=Kachinnews.com |date= |accessdate=2018-03-12}}{{cite web|url=https://conflictsinburma.crowdmap.com/reports/view/821 |title=Kachin rebel forces seize Pangwa |publisher=Conflictsinburma.crowdmap.com |accessdate=19 February 2015}} In August, the KIA claimed that 140 government troops were killed when they exploded mines buried inside the ''Myauk Phyu'' ("White Monkey") jade mine, which was owned by the ''Wai Aung Kaba Company''.{{cite news|title=KIA says 211 army soldiers die in two-month fighting in Hpakant|url=http://www.kachinnews.com/news/2418-kia-says-211-army-soldiers-die-in-two-month-fighting-in-hpakant.html|accessdate=12 March 2018|work=www.kachinnews.com|date=10 October 2012|language=en-gb}} === 2013–2014 === Fortified KIA positions were heavily damaged by airstrikes and artillery launched by the Myanmar Army from December 2012 to January 2013.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} On 19 November 2014, government soldiers attacked the KIA's headquarters near [[Laiza]], killing at least 22 insurgents.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/myanmars-kachin-rebels-22-dead-attack-27023038|title=Myanmar's Kachin Rebels Say 22 Dead in Fighting|date=19 November 2014|accessdate=29 November 2014}} === 2018 === In March 2018, the Tatmadaw (Myanmar Armed Forces) launched [[airstrike]]s against the KIA in [[Tanai Township]], which is part of a large mining region.{{cite news|last1=Mark|first1=Eugene|title=The 'Resource War' in Kachin State|url=https://thediplomat.com/2018/03/the-resource-war-in-kachin-state/|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=The Diplomat|date=16 March 2018}} Between 1 to 6 April 2018, Tatmadaw soldiers allegedly attacked KIA positions in the KIA-controlled [[Mansi Township]], though no reports of fighting emerged from the region. The KIA later raided the Tatmadaw's Battalion 86 military base in [[Hpakant Township]] on 6 April 2018, killing eight government soldiers and capturing 13.{{cite news|last1=Weng|first1=Lawi|title=KIA Raids Tatmadaw Base, Claims to Detain More than a Dozen Troops|url=https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/kia-raids-tatmadaw-base-claims-detain-dozen-troops.html|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=The Irrawaddy|date=9 April 2018}} By 10 April 2018, locals claimed that 18 Tatmadaw soldiers and three KIA insurgents had been killed in the clashes.{{cite news|last1=Thar|first1=Chan|title=UN appeals to fighters to spare civilians|url=https://www.mmtimes.com/news/un-appeals-fighters-spare-civilians.html|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=The Myanmar Times|date=10 April 2018|language=en}} Accusations of abuses perpetrated by the Tatmadaw against civilians emerged in March and April 2018,{{cite news|last1=Hay|first1=Wayne|title='I feel helpless': Abuses plague Myanmar's Kachin conflict|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/03/i-feel-helpless-abuses-plague-myanmars-kachin-conflict-180327090110375.html|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=www.aljazeera.com|date=27 March 2018}} which included allegations that Tatmadaw soldiers specifically targeted and killed two [[Kachin people|Kachin]]{{cite news|last1=Lwin|first1=Nan|last2=Pwint|first2=Hnin|title=Army Brings Case Against Relative of 2 Kachin Villagers Allegedly Killed by Soldiers|url=https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/army-brings-case-relative-2-kachin-villagers-allegedly-killed-soldiers.html|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=The Irrawaddy|date=29 March 2018}} and six [[Shan people#Other Tai Shan groups|Shanni]] farmers.{{cite news|title=Six Shan Ni farmers missing after clashes in Kachin State|url=http://www.mizzima.com/news-domestic/six-shan-ni-farmers-missing-after-clashes-kachin-state|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=Mizzima|date=13 April 2018|language=en}} Several civilians were also wounded in the crossfire.{{cite news|title=Myanmar villagers caught in crossfire as Kachin conflict flares|url=http://www.unhcr.org/news/latest/2018/4/5acb37464/myanmar-villagers-caught-crossfire-kachin-conflict-flares.html|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=UNHCR|language=en}} By May 2018, 6,000 [[Internally displaced person|IDPs]] had fled armed clashes and shelling by the Myanmar Army, whilst hundreds more remained trapped in villages caught between the crossfire. Hunger became a prevalent issue for IDPs, with some resorting to eating [[banana]] stems.{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Simon|last2=Moon|first2=Sam Aung|title=Myanmar's northern offensive against rebels sparks youthful revolt|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-kachin/myanmars-northern-offensive-against-rebels-sparks-youthful-revolt-idUSKBN1IC1LV|accessdate=11 May 2018|work=Reuters|date=11 May 2018}} === Ceasefire attempts === Numerous rounds of ceasefire talks have taken place between the [[Kachin Independence Army]] and the government of Myanmar since fighting resumed in June 2011. According to a 18 December 2012 report by Swedish journalist [[Bertil Lintner]] in the [[Hong Kong]]-based ''[[Asia Times Online]]'', many people have criticised the foreign backed ceasefire efforts for "avoiding discussions of political issues and only emphasizing ceasefires, disarmament and economic development, those interlocutors—including a 'Peace Support Initiative' sponsored by the [[Norwegian government]] and in a separate initiative the [[Switzerland]]-based [[Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue]]—are essentially promoting the government's view". ''The Australian'' reported that some Kachin Business leaders were calling on [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] to help mediate the dispute and on 6 January 2012, Aung San Suu Kyi said that she could not step into the negotiations without an official invitation from the government to do so, which she had not received.[http://www.mizzima.com/special/kachin-battle-report/8695-suu-kyi-refuses-to-intervene-in-kachin-conflict.html]{{dead link|date=March 2018}} ==== 2013 ceasefire talks ==== On 18 January 2013, immediately prior to an international donors conference in Myanmar, President [[Thein Sein]] announced a unilateral ceasefire in the war between the army and the KIO.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/burma/kachin-01192013175226.html |title=Kachin Ceasefire Ignored |publisher=Rfa.org |date= |accessdate=19 February 2015}} The ceasefire was said to take effect the following day, on 19 January, but light fighting was also reported the following day{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/20/world/asia/cease-fire-in-myanmar-with-kachin-rebels-fails-to-take-hold.html?_r=0|title=A Cease-Fire With Rebels in Myanmar Doesn’t Hold|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=19 February 2015|first=Thomas|last=Fuller|date=19 January 2013}} and a full-scale government assault was reportedly launched on 20 January and included "sustained mortar and artillery fire" followed by "hundreds of Burmese troops" storming a KIA base on the outskirts of rebel-held town of [[Laiza]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21107440 |title=BBC News - Burma attack breaks Kachin truce near China border |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=20 January 2013 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} The government of [[Thein Sein]] was reported to be under pressure from "political and business circles" who believed the "escalating conflict would undermine Myanmar’s emergence from decades of diplomatic isolation" and had passed a resolution in parliament calling on [[Min Aung Hlaing]], the military’s commander-in-chief, to scale down the war.{{cite web|last=Robinson |first=Gwen |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121183737/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/458cdcba-618d-11e2-82cd-00144feab49a.html |title=Myanmar’s military to end Kachin attacks - FT.com |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2013-01-18 |accessdate=2018-03-12}} Min Aung Hlaing responded by stating that the military would only carry out attacks only in "self-defense"—the rationale it has consistently given since December 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2012/01/13/Hope-and-suspicion-dog-Myanmar-cease-fire/UPI-22521326469272/#ixzz2IZEDRwWR |title=Hope and suspicion dog Myanmar cease-fire |publisher=UPI.com |date=13 January 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} for prosecuting a war against the KIA and the rationale it gave for allowing [[airstrike]]s on rebel positions starting on 26 December 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvb.no/news/govt-says-kachin-air-strikes-self-defence/25551 |title=Govt says Kachin air strikes 'self-defence' - DVB Multimedia Group |publisher=Dvb.no |date=4 January 2013 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} On 4 February, Burmese government and the Kachin Independence Army met in [[Ruili]], [[China]] and agreed to reduce military tension in Kachin State and hold further peace talks later in February.{{cite web|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/4014-myanmar-govt-kio-agree-to-reduce-tension-hold-more-talks.html |title=Myanmar govt, KIO agree to reduce ‘tension’, hold more talks |publisher=Mmtimes.com |date= |accessdate=29 April 2014}} However no talks took place later in February but almost no armed clash reportedly happened in Kachin State after the peace talks.{{cite news|title=Myanmar military denies scaling up operations in conflict areas|url=http://elevenmyanmar.com/politics/2764-myanmar-military-denies-scaling-up-operations-in-conflict-areas|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=Eleven|date=12 March 2013}} According to Mizzima news, on 26 February a KIO central committee member claimed that they would not be meeting with the government in February because they needed more time to consult with the "Kachin people" regarding the negotiations.{{cite web|url=http://www.mizzima.com/special/kachin-battle-report/8966-kio-postpones-talks-with-govt-peace-committee.html |accessdate=6 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226120711/http://mizzima.com/special/kachin-battle-report/8966-kio-postpones-talks-with-govt-peace-committee.html |archivedate=26 February 2013 }} Burmese government and KIA renewed peace talks in Ruili, China on 11 March 2013.{{cite news|title=Myanmar government and Kachin rebels renew talks|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/1259176/1/.html|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=Channel News Asia|date=11 March 2013}} The Chinese government’s refusal to allow observers from western countries at peace talks had delayed negotiations, despite the Chinese rejecting the allegations.{{cite news|last=Toe Lwin|first=Ei Ei|title=Questions over China’s role after delay in talks|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/in-depth/6463-questions-over-china-s-role-after-delay-in-talks.html|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=The Myanmar Times|date=22 April 2013}}{{cite news|last=McLaughlin|first=Tim McLaughlin|title=Blame game over Kachin peace talk delays|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/6520-kachin-peace-talks-face-delays.html|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=The Myanmar Times|date=25 April 2013}} On 30 May, Burmese government and Kachin Independence Army signed a preliminary ceasefire agreement that would lead to further progress towards reaching a peace deal. The parties however, failed to reach an official ceasefire agreement. [[United Nations]] special adviser on Myanmar, [[Vijay Nambiar]], also joined the meeting as an observer, along with representatives of [[China]] and other ethnic minorities.{{cite news|title=Preliminary ceasefire reached through Kachin talks|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/6928-preliminary-ceasefire-reached-through-kachin-talks.html|accessdate=30 May 2013|newspaper=The Myanmar Times|date=30 May 2013}}{{cite news|last=Nyein Nyein|title=KIO, Govt Sign Preliminary Agreement, Hopeful of Reaching Ceasefire|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/36003|accessdate=30 May 2013|newspaper=The irrawaddt|date=30 May 2013}} However, the Burmese government and Kachin Independence Army failed to reach a permanent ceasefire agreement after several peace talks in 2013, but agreed to work together towards permanent ceasefire agreement and reduce hostilities.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/kachin-10102013192125.html |title=Kachin Peace Talks Close Without Cease-Fire Pact |publisher=Rfa.org |date= |accessdate=29 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://mmpeacemonitor.org/images/images/20131008-10_mpc_released_a_statement_for_kio_and_govt_talks.jpg |format=JPG |title=Myanmar Peace Center : Media Release |publisher=Mmpeacemonitor.org |accessdate=19 February 2015}} ==== 2014 ceasefire talks ==== Renewed fighting broke out in April 2014 when the Burmese army attacked various KIA positions around [[Mansi Township]], [[Kachin State]] and northern [[Shan State]] to eradicate timber smuggling and to control strategic routes around their strongholds.{{cite web|url=http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5811:kachin-conflict-damaging-trust-in-peace-talks&catid=32:politics&Itemid=354 |title=Kachin conflict damaging trust in peace talks |publisher=Eleven Myanmar |date=23 April 2014 |accessdate=29 April 2014}} The Kachin Independence Army requested a meeting in [[Myitkyina]] on 10 May to lessen tensions between the sides.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/burma/kachin-rebels-requests-ceasefire-meeting-recent-clashes.html |title=Kachin Rebels Requests Ceasefire Meeting After Recent Clashes |publisher=Irrawaddy.org |date= |accessdate=29 April 2014}} Negotiations aimed at drafting a nationwide ceasefire agreement began in April 2014 at the [[Myanmar Peace Centre]] between representatives of various ethnic armed groups and the Burmese government, but the KIA and Ta'ang National Liberation Army (TNLA) were not among the negotiators.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvb.no/news/rangoon-ceasefire-talks-a-historic-situation-says-gun-maw-burma-myanmar/39373 |title=Rangoon ceasefire talks a ‘historic situation’, says Gun Maw | DVB Multimedia Group |publisher=Dvb.no |date=6 April 2014 |accessdate=29 April 2014}} The KIA's deputy commander-in-chief [[Gun Maw]] urged the [[United States]] to get involved in the peace process in April 2014.{{cite web|last=Pennington |first=Matthew |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/04/22/3801662/myanmar-rebel-leader-urges-us.html |title=WASHINGTON: Myanmar rebel leader urges US role in peace talks | National Politics |publisher=NewsObserver.com |date=22 April 2014 |accessdate=29 April 2014}} === Airstrikes === On 2 January 2013, the Burmese government confirmed that it carried out [[airstrike]]s a few days earlier against the ethnic rebels in northern Kachin, in response to attacks by the Kachin Independence Army.{{cite news|title=Burma Admits Air Strikes Targeted Kachin Rebels|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/burma-admits-air-strikes-targeted-kachin-rebels/1576299.html|accessdate=3 January 2013|newspaper=Voice of America|date=2 January 2013}} The US government stated that it would "be formally expressing our concern" over the escalation of force used by Myanmar government.{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/dpb/2013/01/202436.htm#BURMA |title=Daily Press Briefing - January 2, 2013 |publisher=State.gov |date=2 January 2013 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} On 3 January 2013, the KIA alleged that air-strikes had continued to occur for the sixth consecutive day in the area around [[Laiza]] and there were allegations that the [[Myanmar Armed Forces]] was also using [[chemical weapons]]{{cite web|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/22883 |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140410072040/http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/22883 |archivedate=10 April 2014 }} [[UN Secretary General]] [[Ban Ki Moon]] stated following the incidents that Burma's authorities should "desist from any action that could endanger the lives of civilians living in the area or further intensify conflict in the region".{{cite news|author=Lindsay Murdoch |url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/burmese-military-admits-air-strike-on-rebels-20130103-2c77a.html |title=Burmese military admits air strike on rebels |publisher=Theage.com.au |date= |accessdate=19 February 2015 |location=Melbourne}} === Civilians and refugees === Civilians have also been killed in fighting as well as having been specifically targeted. Civilians were often displaced by fighting and faced dangers such as landmines which were frequently laid by government and rebel forces without regard for civilians. Although some civilians had crossed the border with China most remained in northern Burma as of December 2012. Refugees were being forced by the Chinese government back into [[Myanmar]] in August 2012 despite the continued fighting there and the illegality of forcibly returning civilians to war zones under international law.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19365075 |title=BBC News - China 'forcing Kachin refugees back to Burma' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=24 August 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015}}{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/08/24/china-refugees-forcibly-returned-burma |title=China: Refugees Forcibly Returned to Burma | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=24 August 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} Women have played a significant role in the conflict as both combatants and victims. ''[[Time Magazine]]'' documented the presence of many female KIA soldiers in 2012.{{cite news|url=http://lightbox.time.com/2012/04/19/kia/#ixzz2FgswYz5J |title=On the Front Lines with the Kachin Independence Army - LightBox |publisher=Lightbox.time.com |date= 19 April 2012|accessdate=19 February 2015 |first=Joe |last=Jackson}} In February 2013 the NGO Kachin Women's Association Thailand (KWAT) reported that the fighting had created over 100,000 refugees and that 364 villages had been wholly or partially abandoned since 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.kachinwomen.com/publications/reports/105-state-terror-in-the-kachin-hills-.html |title=Kachin Women's Association Thailand - State terror in the Kachin hills |publisher=Kachinwomen.com |date= |accessdate=19 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411051706/http://www.kachinwomen.com/publications/reports/105-state-terror-in-the-kachin-hills-.html |archivedate=11 April 2013 |df= }} The organisation's report also stated that the Burmese Army deliberately attacked refugee camps and villages as well as committed alleged "war crimes" such as the rape and murder of civilians. The [[United Nations]] stated on 28 April 2018 that more than 4,000 people were displaced since armed clashes resumed earlier in the month.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43933332|title=Myanmar violence: Thousands flee fresh fighting in Kachin state|publisher=BBC}} === Child soldiers === Child soldiers are a major part of the Myanmar Army's and insurgent groups' soldiers. ''The Independent'' reported in June 2012 that children were being sold to the Burmese military for "as little as $40 and a bag of rice or a can of petrol".{{cite news|author=Jerome Taylor |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/two-burmese-children-a-week-conscripted-into-military-7858858.html |title=Two Burmese children a week conscripted into military - Asia - World |publisher=The Independent |date=19 June 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015 |location=London}} The UN's Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, [[Radhika Coomaraswamy]], who stepped down from her position a week later, met representatives of the [[Government of Myanmar]] on 5 July 2012, and stated that she hoped the government's signing of an action plan would "signal a transformation".{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/briefings/docs/2012/120705_Guest.doc.htm |title=Press Conference on Action Plan to End Recruitment of Child Soldiers in Myanmar | Meetings Coverage and Press Releases |publisher=Un.org |date=5 July 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} In September 2012, the [[Tatmadaw]] (armed forces) released 42 child soldiers and the [[International Labour Organization]] met with representatives of the government as well as the [[Kachin Independence Army]] to secure the release of more child soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/13354 |accessdate=5 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105023630/http://www.irrawaddy.org/archives/13354 |archivedate=5 January 2013 }} According to [[Samantha Power]], a US delegation raised the issue of child soldiers with the government in October 2012, however, she did not comment on the government's progress towards reform in this area.{{cite web|author=Samantha Power |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2012/11/09/supporting-human-rights-burma |title=Supporting Human Rights in Burma | The White House |publisher=Whitehouse.gov |date= |accessdate=19 February 2015}} A ''[[Bangkok Post]]'' article on 23 December 2012, reported that the [[Myanmar Armed Forces]] continued to use child soldiers including during the army's large offensive against the KIA.{{unreliable source?|date=August 2013}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Ongoing military conflicts}} {{Post-Cold War Asian conflicts}} [[Category:Internal conflict in Myanmar]] [[Category:Wars involving Myanmar]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2013]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]]
