half-hour format) | list_episodes = List of Thunderbirds episodes | executive_producer = Gerry Anderson <small>(Series Two)</small> | producer = {{ubl |Gerry Anderson <small>(Series One)</small> |[[Reg Hill]] <small>(Series Two)</small>}} | cinematography = [[John Read (producer)|John Read]] | runtime = {{ubl |50 minutes |25 minutes (half-hour format)}} | company = [[AP Films]] | distributor = [[ITC Entertainment]] | network = [[Associated Television|ATV]] | picture_format = [[35 mm film]] ([[VistaVision]])<ref name="Bignell, 76"/> | audio_format = [[Monaural|Mono]] | first_aired = {{Start date|1965|09|30|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{End date|1966|12|25|df=yes}} | preceded_by = ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' | followed_by = {{Nowrap|''[[Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons]]''}} | related = {{ubl |''[[Thunderbirds 2086]]'' |''[[Works based on Thunderbirds#US re-edits|Turbocharged Thunderbirds]]'' |''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go]]''}} | website = hide }} '''''Thunderbirds''''' is a British science-fiction television series created by [[Gerry Anderson|Gerry]] and [[Sylvia Anderson]], filmed by their production company [[AP Films]] (APF) and distributed by [[ITC Entertainment]]. It was produced between 1964 and 1966 using a form of electronic [[marionette]] puppetry (dubbed "[[Supermarionation]]") combined with [[scale model]] special effects sequences. Two series were filmed, comprising a total of thirty-two 50-minute episodes; production ceased following the completion of the second series' sixth episode when [[Lew Grade]], the Andersons' financial backer, failed in his efforts to sell the programme to American network television.
Set in the mid-2060s, ''Thunderbirds'' is a follow-up to the earlier Supermarionation productions ''[[Four Feather Falls]]'', ''[[Supercar (TV series)|Supercar]]'', ''[[Fireball XL5]]'' and ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]''. It follows the exploits of International Rescue (IR), a life-saving organisation equipped with technologically-advanced land, sea, air and space rescue craft; these are headed by a fleet of five vehicles named the [[Thunderbirds machines|''Thunderbirds'']] and launched from IR's secret base in the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The main characters are ex-astronaut [[Jeff Tracy]], the founder of IR, and his five adult sons, who pilot the ''Thunderbird'' machines.
''Thunderbirds'' began its first run in the United Kingdom on the [[ITV network]] in 1965 and has since been broadcast in at least 66 other countries.<ref name="Mitchell"/> Periodically repeated, it was adapted for radio in the early 1990s and has influenced many TV programmes and other media. As well as inspiring [[Thunderbirds merchandise|various merchandising campaigns]], the series has been followed by two feature-length film sequels (''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'' and ''[[Thunderbird 6]]'', released in 1966 and 1968 respectively), [[Thunderbirds (2004 film)|a 2004 live-action film adaptation]] and a mimed stage show tribute. The second of two TV remakes, the computer-animated ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go]]'', premiered in 2015, in honour of the original show's 50th anniversary.<ref name="TBAG Premiere"/>
Widely considered to be the Andersons' most popular and commercially successful series,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/442090/|title=''Thunderbirds'' (1965–66)|author=Clark, Anthony|work=[[Screenonline]]|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530232412/http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/442090|archivedate=30 May 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="Taylor and Trim, 71"/> ''Thunderbirds'' has received particular praise for its effects (directed by [[Derek Meddings]]) and musical score (composed by [[Barry Gray]]).<ref name="Sangster and Condon"/><ref name="Thomas, 24"/> It is also well remembered for its [[title sequence]], which opens with an often-quoted countdown by actor [[Peter Dyneley]] (who voiced the character of Jeff): "5, 4, 3, 2, 1: ''Thunderbirds'' Are Go!"<ref name="O'Brien, 83"/><ref name="Knowles"/> A real-life rescue service, the [[International Rescue Corps]], is named after the organisation featured in the series.
==Premise== {{Main article|List of Thunderbirds episodes}} Set between 2065 and 2067,<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 42 and 95.</ref> ''Thunderbirds'' follows the exploits of the Tracy family, headed by American ex-astronaut turned multi-millionaire philanthropist [[Jeff Tracy]]. He is a widower with five adult sons: [[Scott Tracy|Scott]], [[John Tracy (Thunderbirds)|John]], [[Virgil Tracy|Virgil]], [[Gordon Tracy|Gordon]] and [[Alan Tracy|Alan]].<ref group="Note">Listed by age, in descending order, as stated in Bentley 2005, pp. 53–57. According to Marriott 1993, pp. 116–117, Virgil is the second-oldest son and John the third-oldest.</ref> The Tracys form International Rescue (IR), a secret organisation dedicated to saving human life. They are aided in this mission by technologically advanced land, sea, air and space vehicles, which are called into service when conventional rescue techniques prove ineffective. The most important of these are five machines named the "''Thunderbirds''", each assigned to one of the five Tracy brothers:
*''[[Thunderbird 1]]'': a [[hypersonic]] rocket plane used for fast response and accident zone reconnaissance. Piloted by primary rescue co-ordinator Scott Tracy. *''[[Thunderbird 2]]'': a [[supersonic]] carrier aircraft that transports [[Thunderbird 2 pod vehicles|rescue vehicles and equipment]] to accident zones in detachable capsules known as "pods". Piloted by Virgil. *''[[Thunderbird 3]]'': a [[single-stage-to-orbit]] spacecraft. Piloted alternately by Alan and John, with Scott as co-pilot. *''[[Thunderbird 4]]'': a utility [[submersible]]. Piloted by Gordon and normally launched from ''Thunderbird 2''. *''[[Thunderbird 5]]'': a [[space station]] that relays distress calls from around the world. Manned alternately by "space monitors" John and Alan.<ref>Bentley 2005: vehicle descriptions, pp. 45–49.</ref><ref>{{Cite book|author=Bleathman, Graham|title=Thunderbirds FAB Cross-Sections: Exposing the Secrets of the Craft, Machinery and Headquarters of International Rescue|year=2000|publisher=[[Carlton Books]]|location=London, UK|isbn=978-1-84222-091-7|page=19}}</ref>
With the engineer [[Brains (Thunderbirds)|Brains]] and [[Grandma Tracy|Jeff's elderly mother]],<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95">Bentley 2008, p. 95.</ref> as well as the Malaysian manservant [[Kyrano]] and his daughter [[Tin-Tin Kyrano|Tin-Tin]] (who serves as Brains' assistant), the family reside in a luxurious villa on [[Tracy Island]],<ref group="Note" name="Names">The names "Tracy Island" and "Hood" are not used in the TV series, appearing only in tie-in media.</ref> their hidden base in the [[South Pacific Ocean]].<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 44.</ref> In this location, IR is safe from criminals and spies who envy the organisation's technology and seek to acquire the secrets of its machines.
Despite its humanitarian principles, some of IR's operations are necessitated not by misadventure but deliberate sabotage motivated by greed for power and wealth. For missions that require criminal investigation, the organisation incorporates a network of undercover agents headed by English aristocrat [[Lady Penelope Creighton-Ward]] and her butler [[Aloysius Parker]]. Based at [[Creighton-Ward Mansion]] in Kent, Penelope and Parker's primary mode of transport is [[FAB 1]], a specially-modified [[List of Rolls-Royce motor cars|Rolls-Royce]]. The most persistent of IR's adversaries is the criminal known only as the "[[Hood (Thunderbirds)|Hood]]".<ref group="Note" name="Names"/><ref>Bentley 2005, p. 61.</ref> Operating from a temple in the Malaysian jungle, and possessing abilities of hypnosis and [[dark magic]], he exerts a powerful telepathic control over Kyrano, his estranged half-brother, and manipulates the Tracys into missions that unfold according to his nefarious designs. This allows him to spy on the ''Thunderbird'' machines and, by selling their secrets, make himself rich.
==Production== {{Quote box|quote=I started to think that there really ought to be dumps around the world with rescue gear standing by, so that when a disaster happened, all these items of rescue equipment could be rushed to the disaster zone and used to help to get people out of trouble ... I was thinking, 'Rescue, yes, rescue, but how to make it science fiction? What about an international rescue organisation?'|source=— [[Gerry Anderson]] on the premise<ref name="Bentley, 8-9">Bentley 2005, pp. 8–9.</ref>|align=right|salign=right|width=30%}}
''Thunderbirds'' was the fourth Supermarionation puppet TV series to be produced by APF, which was founded by the husband-and-wife duo of Gerry and Sylvia Anderson (née Thamm) with their business partners [[Arthur Provis]], [[Reg Hill]], and [[John Read (producer)|John Read]]. Pitched in late 1963, the series was commissioned by Lew Grade of ITC, APF's parent company, on the back of the positive audience response to ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]].''<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/><ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 103.</ref>
Gerry Anderson drew inspiration for the series' underlying concept from the [[West German]] mining disaster known as the ''[[Wunder von Lengede]]'' ("Miracle of Lengede"). In October 1963, the collapse of a nearby dam flooded an iron mine in the municipality of [[Lengede]], killing 29 miners and trapping 21 others underground.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 6–7.</ref> Lacking the means to drill an escape shaft, the authorities were forced to requisition a heavy-duty bore from [[Bremen]]; despite the considerable time necessary to transport the bore by rail significantly reducing the chances of a successful rescue, 11 of the trapped miners were eventually saved.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 8.</ref> Recognising the advantages of swifter crisis response, Anderson conceived the idea of an "international rescue" organisation that could use supersonic aircraft to transport specialised rescue equipment quickly over long distances.<ref name="Bentley, 8-9"/>
Seeking to distinguish his 26-episode proposal from APF's earlier productions, Anderson attempted to pitch stories at a level that would appeal to both adults and children. Whereas previous series had been shown during the late afternoon, Anderson wanted ''Thunderbirds'' to be broadcast in a family-friendly [[primetime]] slot.<ref name="Bentley, 12">Bentley 2005, p. 12.</ref> Sylvia remembers that "our market had grown and a 'kidult' show ... was the next step."<ref>Anderson 2007, p. 21.</ref> The Andersons retired to their holiday villa in Portugal to expand the premise, script the pilot episode and compose a [[Bible (writing)|scriptwriters' guide]].<ref name="Bentley, 12"/><ref name="La Rivière, 106"/> According to Sylvia, the writing process depended on a "division of labour", whereby Gerry created the action sequences while she managed [[characterisation]].<ref name="La Rivière, 106">La Rivière, p. 106.</ref> The decision to make a father and his sons the main characters was influenced by the premise of ''[[Bonanza]]'', as well as Sylvia's belief that the use of more than one heroic character would broaden the series' appeal.<ref name="Anderson, 31">Anderson 2007, p. 31.</ref><ref name="Cull: Media, 202">Cull 2006 (August), p. 202.</ref> The Tracy brothers were named after [[Mercury Seven]] astronauts: [[Scott Carpenter]], [[John Glenn]], [[Gus Grissom|Virgil "Gus" Grissom]], [[Gordon Cooper]] and [[Alan Shepard]].<ref name="BentleyCharacterBiographies"/>
The series' title was derived from a letter written by Gerry's brother, Lionel, while he had been serving overseas as an [[RAF]] flight sergeant during [[World War II]].<ref name="Bentley, 13">Bentley 2005, p. 13.</ref> While stationed in Arizona, Lionel had made reference to [[Thunderbird Field No. 1|Thunderbird Field]], a nearby [[United States Army Air Forces]] base.<ref name="Bentley, 13"/><ref name="La Rivière, 111">La Rivière, p. 111.</ref> Drawn to the "punchiness" of "''Thunderbirds''", Anderson dropped his [[working title]] of "''International Rescue''" and renamed both the series and IR's rescue vehicles, which had previously been designated ''Rescues 1'' to ''5''.<ref name="Bentley, 13"/> His inspiration for the launch sequences of ''Thunderbirds 1'', ''2'' and ''3'' originated from contemporary [[United States Air Force]] launch procedure: Anderson had learnt how the [[Strategic Air Command]] would keep its pilots on permanent standby, seated in the cockpits of their aircraft and ready for take-off at a moment's notice.<ref name="Cull: Media, 198">Cull 2006 (August), p. 198.</ref>
In the DVD documentary ''The Thunderbirds Companion'', Anderson explained how a rise in filming costs had made overseas distribution revenue even more important and essentially caused ''Thunderbirds'' to be made "as an American show".<ref name="MakingSecrets">{{Cite AV media|people=Meyers, Simon; Middleton, Guy (producers)|year=2000|title=Thunderbirds: The Making of the Secrets|medium=DVD|publisher=[[Carlton Communications|Carlton International Media]]|location=London, UK|asin=B0002475OI|time=05:22–06:22}}</ref> During the character development and voice casting process, the Andersons' main priority was to ensure that the series had [[Transatlantic relations|transatlantic]] appeal, thus increasing the chances of winning an American network deal and the higher audience figures that this market had to offer.<ref name="Bentley, 12"/><ref name="Bignell, 81">Bignell, p. 81.</ref> Scripts were typed in American English and printed on US-style [[Bookbinding#Terms and techniques|quarto-size]] paper.<ref>O'Brien, p. 82.</ref>
===Filming=== ''Thunderbirds'' was filmed at APF's studios on the [[Slough Trading Estate]] between 1964 and 1966.<ref name="Bentley, 22">Bentley 2005, p. 22.</ref> In preparation, the number of full-time crew was expanded to 100.<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 120.</ref> Shooting began in September 1964 after five months of pre-production.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/><ref name="Bentley, 16">Bentley 2005, p. 16.</ref> Due to the new series' technical complexity, this was a period longer than for any of APF's earlier productions.<ref>La Rivière, pp. 110–111.</ref> To speed up the filming, episodes were shot in pairs, at a rate of one per month, on separate [[soundstage]]s and by separate crews (designated "A" and "B").<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 23 and 36.</ref> By 1964, APF was the UK's largest commercial user of colour film, consuming more than three million feet (570 miles or 910 kilometres) of stock per year.<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 85.</ref>
[[Alan Pattillo]], a longtime scriptwriter and director for APF, was appointed the company's first official [[script editor]] in late 1964.<ref name="Bentley, 24">Bentley 2005, p. 24.</ref> This move was aimed to reduce the burden on Gerry Anderson who, while reserving his producer's right to overall creative control, had grown weary of revising scripts himself.<ref name="Bentley, 25"/><ref>Cull 2006 (August), p. 196.</ref> Direction of episodes was assigned in pairs: veterans Pattillo and [[David Elliott (director)|David Elliott]] alternated with the less-experienced [[Desmond Saunders]] and newcomer [[David Lane (director)|David Lane]] for each month's filming.<ref name="Bentley, 24"/><ref name="La Rivière, 122">La Rivière, p. 122.</ref> Due to the difficulties of setting up takes, progress was slow: even on a productive day, it was rare for the crew to complete more than two minutes of puppet footage.<ref name="La Rivière, 123">La Rivière, p. 123.</ref> In a contemporary interview, Hill noted that ''Thunderbirds'' contained several times as many shots as a typical live-action series.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121">Archer and Hearn, p. 121.</ref> He explained that rapid editing was necessary on account of the characters' lack of facial expression, which made it difficult to sustain the viewer's interest for more than a few seconds per shot.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121"/>
{{Quote box|quote=Lew watched ["Trapped in the Sky"] and at the end he jumped up shouting, 'Fantastic, absolutely fantastic! This isn't a television series – this is a feature film! You've got to make this as an hour!' ... I'm glad we did it, because it made the series much bigger and much more important. But it was still a very, very difficult job.|source=— [[Gerry Anderson]] on the format change<ref name="Bentley, 26"/>|salign=right|width=30%}}
After viewing the completed 25-minute pilot, "[[Trapped in the Sky]]",<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121"/><ref name="Bentley, 26"/> Lew Grade was so impressed by APF's work that he instructed Anderson to double the episode length and increased the series' budget per episode from £25,000 to £38,000.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/><ref name="Bentley, 26"/> As a result, ''Thunderbirds'' became not only the company's longest and highest-budgeted production, but also among the most expensive TV series to have been made up to that point.<ref name="Bentley, 26">Bentley 2005, p. 26.</ref><ref>La Rivière, p. 119.</ref> The crew, who had been filming at a rate of two 25-minute episodes per [[fortnight]], faced significant challenges during the transition to the new format: eight episodes had already been completed,<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 87.</ref> scripts for up to ten more had been written,<ref name="Bentley, 26"/> and substantial rewrites would be necessary to satisfy the longer running time.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 23 and 27.</ref> Anderson lamented: "Our time-scale was far too drawn out. ITC's New York office insisted that they should have one show a fortnight ... Everything had to move at twice the speed."<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 122.</ref> APF spent over seven months extending the existing episodes.<ref name="Bentley, 28">Bentley 2005, p. 28.</ref>
[[Tony Barwick]], who had impressed Pattillo and the Andersons with an unsubmitted script that he had written for ''[[Danger Man]]'', was recruited to assist in the writing of subplots and [[Filler (media)|filler]] material.<ref>La Rivière, p. 121.</ref><ref>Anderson 1991, p. 67.</ref> He found that the longer format created opportunities to strengthen the characterisation.<ref name="Bentley, 26"/><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 153.</ref> Science-fiction writer [[John Peel (writer)|John Peel]] suggests that "small character touches" make the puppet cast of ''Thunderbirds'' "much more rounded" than those of earlier APF series.<ref name="Peel, 14">Peel, p. 14.</ref> He compares the writing favourably to that of live-action drama.<ref name="Peel, 14"/> The new footage proved useful during the development of the first series finale, "Security Hazard": since the previous two episodes ("[[Attack of the Alligators!]]" and "[[The Cham-Cham]]") had overspent their budgets, Pattillo devised a [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]]-dominated [[clip show]] containing only 17 minutes of new material to reduce costs.<ref name="Bentley, 31">Bentley 2005, p. 31.</ref><ref name="La Rivière, 128"/>
Filming of Series One was completed in December 1965.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/> A second series was also commissioned late that year and entered production in March 1966.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 31 and 36.</ref> Barwick became a full-time member of the writing staff and took over the role of script editor from the outgoing Pattillo.<ref>Marriott 1993, p. 264.</ref><ref name="La Rivière, 141">La Rivière, p. 141.</ref> The main puppet cast and vehicles were rebuilt;<ref name="Marriott, 187">Marriott 1993, p. 187.</ref> in addition, the [[art department]] expanded some of the standing sets, including the Tracy Villa lounge and the ''[[Thunderbird 5]]'' control room.<ref>Peel, p. 103.</ref> To accommodate the simultaneous filming of the TV series and ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'', APF purchased two more buildings on the Slough Trading Estate and converted them into new stages.<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 136.</ref><ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 113.</ref> As crew and studio space were divided between the two productions, filming of the TV series progressed at half the previous speed, as APF's B crew produced one episode per month.<ref name="Bentley, 36">Bentley 2005, p. 36.</ref> Filming on ''Thunderbirds Are Go'' was completed by June, allowing A crew to resume work on the series to shoot what would prove to be its penultimate episode, "Ricochet".<ref name="Bentley, 36"/>
Production of ''Thunderbirds'' ended in August 1966 with the completion of the sixth episode of Series Two.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/><ref name="Bentley, 37">Bentley 2005, p. 37.</ref> In February that year, it had been reported that Grade had been unable to sell the series in the United States due to disagreements over timeslots.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 142">Archer and Hearn, p. 142.</ref><ref>La Rivière, p. 145.</ref> In July, he [[Cancellation (television)|cancelled]] ''Thunderbirds'' after failing in his second attempt to secure an American buyer.<ref name="La Rivière, 141"/><ref name="Bentley, 37"/> The three major US networks of the time – [[NBC]], [[CBS]] and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] – had all bid for the series, with Grade repeatedly increasing the price. When NBC withdrew its offer, the other two immediately followed.<ref name="Bentley, 37"/><ref>{{Cite book|author=[[Nicholas J. Cull|Cull, Nicholas J.]]|title=British Science Fiction Television: A Hitchhiker's Guide|editor=Cook, John R. |editor2=Wright, Peter|year=2006|publisher=[[I.B. Tauris]]|location=London, UK|chapter=The Man Who Made ''Thunderbirds'': An Interview with Gerry Anderson|isbn=978-1-84511-048-2|page=126}}</ref>
By the time of its cancellation, ''Thunderbirds'' had become widely popular in the UK and was being distributed extensively overseas.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 125"/><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 202.</ref> Grade, however, believed that without the financial boost of an American network sale, a full second series would fail to recover its production costs.<ref name="La Rivière, 141"/><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 142"/> He therefore asked Anderson to devise a new concept that he hoped would stand a greater chance of winning over the profitable US market.<ref name="La Rivière, 141"/><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 142"/> This became ''[[Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 37"/>
===Casting and characters=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; float: right; margin-right: 0; margin-left: 1em; font-size: 85%" |+ Regular Puppet Cast<ref name="BentleyCharacterBiographies">Bentley 2005: Character biographies, pp. 52–61.</ref> |- ! Name ! Role(s) ! Voiced by |- | [[Jeff Tracy]] | Leader of IR | [[Peter Dyneley]] |- | [[Scott Tracy]] | ''[[Thunderbird 1]]'' pilot<br />''Thunderbird 3'' co-pilot<ref group="Note">It is stated in one episode, "The Uninvited", that Scott occasionally mans ''Thunderbird 5'' (Bentley 2005, p. 53).</ref> | [[Shane Rimmer]] |- | [[Virgil Tracy]] | ''[[Thunderbird 2]]'' pilot | [[David Holliday]]<br />{{small|(Series One)}}<br />[[Jeremy Wilkin]]<br />{{small|(Series Two)}} |- | [[Alan Tracy]] | ''[[Thunderbird 3]]'' astronaut<br />''Thunderbird 5'' Space Monitor | [[Matt Zimmerman (actor)|Matt Zimmerman]]<br /><ref group="Note">Zimmerman was cast after the dialogue recording for the pilot, "Trapped in the Sky", for which Alan was voiced by Ray Barrett (Bentley 2005, p. 63).</ref> |- | [[Gordon Tracy]] | ''[[Thunderbird 4]]'' aquanaut<br />''Thunderbird 2'' co-pilot | [[David Graham (actor)|David Graham]] |- | [[John Tracy (Thunderbirds)|John Tracy]] | ''[[Thunderbird 5]]'' Space Monitor<br />''Thunderbird 3'' astronaut | [[Ray Barrett]] |- | [[Brains (Thunderbirds)|Brains]] | Engineer, scientist, inventor | David Graham |- | [[Tin-Tin Kyrano]] | Maintenance technician, laboratory assistant<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/>. <br />Also assists in some rescue operations where a third party is needed. | [[Christine Finn]] |- | [[Kyrano]] | Manservant, cook | David Graham |- | [[Grandma Tracy]] | Housekeeper, cook<ref name="Bentley: EG, 95"/> | Christine Finn |- | [[Lady Penelope Creighton-Ward|Lady Penelope<br />Creighton-Ward]] | IR's London agent | [[Sylvia Anderson]] |- | [[Aloysius Parker]] | Penelope's butler and chauffeur | David Graham |- | [[Hood (Thunderbirds)|The Hood]] | Criminal, dark magician | Ray Barrett |}
Voice-recording sessions were supervised by Pattillo and the Andersons, with Sylvia Anderson in charge of casting.<ref name="La Rivière, 106"/><ref name="Bentley, 20">Bentley 2005, p. 20.</ref> Dialogue was recorded once per month at a rate of two scripts per session.<ref name="La Rivière, 117">La Rivière, p. 117.</ref> Supporting parts were not pre-assigned, but negotiated by the cast among themselves.<ref name="Bentley, 20"/> Two recordings would be made at each session: one to be converted into electronic pulses for the puppet filming, the other to be added to the soundtrack during post-production.<ref>Peel, p. 17.</ref> The tapes were edited at Gate Recording Theatre in [[Birmingham]].<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 19–20.</ref>
In the interest of transatlantic appeal, it was decided that the main characters would be mostly American and therefore actors capable of producing an appropriate accent were used.<ref name="Bentley, 12"/><ref name="Bignell, 81"/> British, Canadian and Australian actors formed most of the voice cast;<ref name="Bentley, 17">Bentley 2005, p. 17.</ref> the only American involved was stage actor [[David Holliday]], who was noticed in London's [[West End of London|West End]] and given the part of Virgil Tracy.<ref name="La Rivière, 117"/><ref name="Bentley, 18">Bentley 2005, p. 18.</ref> Following the completion of the first series, Holliday returned to the US. The character was voiced by English-Canadian actor [[Jeremy Wilkin]] for ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'', Series Two and ''[[Thunderbird 6]]''.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 33.</ref>
British actor [[David Graham (actor)|David Graham]] was among the first to be cast.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 17–18.</ref> He had previously voiced characters in ''[[Four Feather Falls]]'', ''[[Supercar (TV series)|Supercar]]'', ''[[Fireball XL5]]'' and ''Stingray''.<ref name="Bentley, 18"/> Beyond the APF productions, he had supplied one of the original [[Dalek]] voices on ''[[Doctor Who]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 18"/> Cast alongside Graham was Australian actor [[Ray Barrett]].<ref name="Bentley, 17"/> Like Graham, he had worked for the Andersons before, having voiced Titan and Commander Shore in ''Stingray''.<ref name="La Rivière, 116">La Rivière, p. 116.</ref> A veteran of radio drama, Barrett was skilled at performing a range of voices and accents in quick succession.<ref name="Bentley, 17"/> [[Villains of the week]] would typically be voiced by either Barrett or Graham.<ref name="Bentley, 18"/> Aware of the sensitive political climate of the [[Cold War]] and not wishing to "perpetuate the idea that Russia was the enemy with a whole generation of children watching",<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 94.</ref> Gerry Anderson decided the Hood (voiced by Barrett) should be Oriental and placed his temple hideout in Malaysia to defy the viewer's expectations.<ref name="Cull: Media, 197"/><ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 117.</ref>
Although Lady Penelope and Parker (the latter voiced by Graham) were among the first characters developed, neither was conceived as a major role.<ref name="Anderson, 30">Anderson 2007, p. 30.</ref><ref name="Archer and Nicholls, 92">Archer and Nicholls, p. 92.</ref> Parker's [[Cockney]] manner was based on a waiter at a pub in [[Cookham]] that was sometimes visited by the crew.<ref name="Archer and Nicholls, 92"/> On Gerry Anderson's recommendation, Graham dined there regularly to study the accent.<ref>Marriott 1993, p. 122.</ref> Anderson's first choice for the role of Penelope had been [[Fenella Fielding]], but Sylvia insisted she take the part herself.<ref name="Bentley, 18"/><ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 91.</ref> Her Penelope voice was intended to emulate Fielding and [[Joan Greenwood]].<ref name="Bentley, 18"/> On Penelope and Parker's secondary role as [[comic relief]], Gerry explained, "We British can laugh at ourselves, so therefore we had Penelope and Parker as this comedy team. And in America they love the British aristocracy too.'"<ref name="Bignell, 81"/>
As well as Jeff Tracy, English-Canadian actor [[Peter Dyneley]] voiced the recurring character of Commander Norman, chief of air traffic control at London International Airport. His supporting character voices were typically those of upper-class Englishmen.<ref name="La Rivière, 117"/> [[Shane Rimmer]], the voice of Scott, was cast on the strength of his performance on the BBC soap opera ''[[Compact (TV series)|Compact]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 17"/> Meanwhile, fellow Canadian [[Matt Zimmerman (actor)|Matt Zimmerman]] was selected at a late stage in the process.<ref name="La Rivière, 117"/> The expatriate West End actor was given the role of Alan on the recommendation of his friend, Holliday: "They were having great difficulty casting the part of Alan as they wanted a certain sound for him, being the youngest brother. David, who [was] a bit older than I am, told them that he had this friend, me, who would be great."<ref name="Bentley, 19">Bentley 2005, p. 19.</ref>
[[Christine Finn]], known for her role in the TV serial ''[[Quatermass and the Pit]]'', provided the voices of Tin-Tin Kyrano and [[Grandma Tracy]].<ref name="Bentley, 18"/> With Sylvia Anderson, she was also responsible for voicing most of the female and child supporting characters. Supporting parts were occasionally voiced by [[John Tate (actor)|John Tate]] (the father of ''[[Space: 1999]]'' actor [[Nick Tate]]), [[Paul Maxwell]] and [[Bud Tingwell|Charles Tingwell]]; the latter two joined the cast in Series Two following their contributions to ''Thunderbirds Are Go''. None of these three actors were credited for their performances.<ref name="Bentley, 19"/><ref>Bentley 2008, p. 351.</ref>
===Design and effects=== The puppet stages used for the filming of ''Thunderbirds'' were only one-fifth the size of those used for a standard live-action production, typically measuring {{Convert|12|by|14|by|3|m}} in length, width and height.<ref name="Marriott, 162">Marriott 1993, p. 162.</ref><ref>Archer, p. 75.</ref> Bob Bell, assisted by [[Keith Wilson (production designer)|Keith Wilson]] and Grenville Nott, headed the art department for Series One.<ref name="La Rivière, 114">La Rivière, p. 114.</ref> During the simultaneous filming of Series Two and ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'' in 1966, Bell attended mainly to the film, entrusting [[set design]] for the TV series to Wilson.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 35–36.</ref>
Since it was necessary for the art department's interior sets to conform to the effects department's exterior plans, each team closely monitored the other's work.<ref name="Anderson, 67">Anderson 2007, p. 67.</ref> According to Sylvia Anderson, Bell's challenge was to produce complex interiors on a limited budget while resisting the effects department's push for "more extravagant" design.<ref name="Anderson, 67"/> This task was complicated by the unnatural proportions of the puppets: Bell struggled to decide whether the sets should be built to a scale proportionate to their bodies or their oversized heads and hands.<ref name="Bentley, 14">Bentley 2005, p. 14.</ref> He used the example of FAB 1 to illustrate the problem: "As soon as we positioned [the puppets] standing alongside [the model], they looked ridiculous, as the car towered over them."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111">Archer and Hearn, p. 111.</ref> He ultimately adopted a "mix-and-match" approach, in which smaller items, such as tableware, were scaled to their hands and furniture to their bodies.<ref name="Bentley, 14"/>
While designing the Creighton-Ward Mansion sets, Bell and his staff strove for authenticity, ordering miniature [[Tudor period|Tudor]] paintings, {{Frac|1|3}}-scale [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]]- and [[Regency architecture|Regency]]-style furniture and carpeting in the shape of a polar bear skin.<ref name="Bentley, 14"/><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111"/> This realism was enhanced by adding scrap items acquired from household waste and electronics shops.<ref name="La Rivière, 114"/> For example, a vacuum cleaner pipe serves as Virgil Tracy's launch chute.<ref>Archer, p. 41.</ref>
====Puppets==== The head puppet sculptor was [[Christine Glanville]], who also served as the lead puppeteer.<ref name="Bentley, 24"/><ref name="La Rivière, 115">La Rivière, p. 115.</ref> Glanville's four-person team built the 13 members of the main cast in six months at a cost of between £250 and £300 per puppet (approximately £{{Inflation|UK|250|1964|fmt=c|r=-2}} and £{{Inflation|UK|300|1964|fmt=c|r=-2}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}).<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111"/><ref name="Bentley, 15">Bentley 2005, p. 15.</ref> Since pairs of episodes were being filmed simultaneously on separate stages, the characters needed to be sculpted in duplicate.<ref name="Bentley, 23">Bentley 2005, p. 23.</ref> Facial expressions were diversified by means of replaceable heads: as well as a head with a neutral expression, each main character was given a "smiler", a "frowner" and a "blinker".<ref name="Bentley, 16"/><ref>Archer, p. 92.</ref> The finished puppets were approximately {{Convert|22|in|cm}} tall, or {{Frac|1|3}} adult human height.<ref name="Marriott, 162"/><ref name="Peel, 18">Peel, p. 18.</ref>
The puppets were made up of more than 30 individual components, the most important of which was the [[solenoid]] that synchronised lip movements with the characters' pre-recorded dialogue.<ref>Archer, p. 72.</ref> This device was positioned inside the head unit; consequently, torsos and limbs appeared relatively small.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111"/> The puppets' likenesses and mechanics are remembered favourably by puppeteer Wanda Brown, who preferred the ''Thunderbirds'' marionettes over the accurately-proportioned ones that first appeared in ''Captain Scarlet'': "The puppets were easier to operate and more enjoyable because they had more character to them ... Even some of the more normal-looking faces, such as Scott and Jeff, for me had more character than the puppets in the series that came afterwards."<ref name="Bentley, 15"/> Rimmer speaks positively of the puppets' still being "very much caricatures", since it made them "more lovable and appealing ... There was a naive quality about them and nothing too complex."<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 29.</ref>
The appearances of the main characters were inspired by those of actors and other entertainers, who were typically selected from the show business directory ''[[Spotlight (directory)|Spotlight]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 15"/> According to Glanville, as part of a trend away from the strong caricature of previous series, APF was seeking "more natural faces" for the puppets.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111"/> The face of Jeff Tracy was based on that of [[Lorne Greene]],<ref name="Cull: Media, 202"/><ref name="Bentley, 16"/> Scott on [[Sean Connery]],<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 111"/><ref name="Bentley, 15"/> Alan on [[Robert Reed]],<ref name="Bentley, 16"/> John on [[Adam Faith]] and [[Charlton Heston]],<ref name="Peel, 19">Peel, p. 19.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rhema.co.nz/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=6975:thunderbirds-are-go-%E2%80%93-again |title=''Thunderbirds'' Are Go – Again! |date=5 February 2013 |author=Anderson, Anne |work=rhema.co.nz |publisher=[[Rhema Broadcasting Group]] |location=[[Auckland]], New Zealand |accessdate=14 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131019223058/http://www.rhema.co.nz/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=6975:thunderbirds-are-go-%E2%80%93-again |archivedate=19 October 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Brains on [[Anthony Perkins]]<ref name="La Rivière, 115"/> and Parker on [[Ben Warriss]].<ref name="Bentley, 16"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 49.</ref> Sylvia Anderson brought the character of Penelope to life in likeness as well as voice: after her test moulds were rejected, sculptor Mary Turner decided to use Anderson herself as a template.<ref>La Rivière, pp. 108–109.</ref>
Main character heads were initially sculpted in either [[Plasticine]] or clay. Once the general aspect had been finalised, this served as the template for a [[silicone rubber]] mould.<ref name="Bentley, 16"/> This was coated with Bondaglass ([[fibreglass]] mixed with resin) and enhanced with Bondapaste, a putty-like substance, to accentuate contours.<ref name="La Rivière, 115"/><ref name="Marriott, 171">Marriott 1993, p. 171.</ref> The Bondaglass shell was then fitted with a solenoid, leather mouth parts and plastic eyes, as well as incisor teeth – a first for a Supermarionation production.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 10 and 16.</ref> Puppets known as "revamps", which had plastic heads, portrayed the supporting characters.<ref>Anderson 2007, p. 43.</ref> These marionettes started their working lives with only a mouth and eyes; their faces were remoulded from one episode to the next.<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 113.</ref><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 169.</ref> Particularly striking revamp moulds were retained and, as their numbers increased, photographed to compile an internal casting directory.<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 97.</ref>
Wigs were made of [[mohair]] or, in the case of the Penelope puppet, human hair.<ref name="Bentley, 16"/><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 115">Archer and Hearn, p. 115.</ref> Puppet bodies were built in three sizes: "large male" (specifically for the Tracys and the Hood), "small male" and "small female".<ref name="Bentley, 16"/><ref>Archer, p. 21.</ref> Sylvia Anderson, the head costume designer, devised the main characters' attire.<ref name="La Rivière, 106"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 44.</ref> To give the puppets increased mobility, the costume department generally avoided stiff synthetic materials, instead working with cotton, silk and wool.<ref name="Bentley, 16"/> Between 1964 and 1966, the department's stock numbered more than 700 costumes.<ref>Archer, p. 88.</ref>
Each puppet's head was fitted with about 10 thin [[tungsten steel]] wires.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 115"/><ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 99.</ref> During the filming, dialogue was played into the studio using modified tape recorders that converted the feed into electronic pulses.<ref name="Bentley, 20"/> Two of the wires relayed these pulses to the internal solenoid, completing the Supermarionation process.<ref name="Bentley, 20"/> The wires, which were sprayed black to reduce their visibility,<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 114.</ref> were made even less noticeable through the application of powder paint that matched the background colours of the set.<ref name="Bentley, 23"/> Glanville explained the time-consuming nature of this process: "[The puppeteers] used to spend over half an hour on each shot getting rid of these wires, looking through the camera, puffing a bit more [paint] here, anti-[[Lens flare|flare]] there; and, I mean, it's very depressing when somebody will say to us, 'Of course the wires showed.'"<ref name="La Rivière, 123"/> Positioned on an overhead gantry with a hand-held cruciform, the puppeteers co-ordinated movements with the help of a [[viewfinder]]-powered [[CCTV]] feedback system.<ref name="Bentley, 22"/> As filming progressed, the crew started to dispense with wires and instead manipulate the puppets from the studio floor [[Rod puppet|using rods]].<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 124.</ref><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 41.</ref>
{{Quote box|quote=Since we always tried to minimise walking, we'd show the puppets taking one step only, then promptly cut. Through interspersing the programmes with "meanwhile" scenes – that is, showing what else was going on in the story at the same time – we would then cut back to the puppet who was now already in his craft.|source=— Alan Pattillo on puppet movement<ref>Marriott 1993, p. 179.</ref>|salign=right|width=35%}}
Due to their low weight and the fact that they had only one control wire per leg, the puppets were unable to walk convincingly. Therefore, scenes involving movement were filmed from the waist up, with a puppeteer holding the legs below the level of the camera and using a "bobbing" action to simulate motion.<ref name="La Rivière, 128">La Rivière, p. 128.</ref><ref name="Peel, 19"/> Alternatively, dynamic shots were eliminated altogether: in an interview with ''[[New Scientist]]'', director of photography John Read spoke of the advantages of circumventing the lack of agility so that the puppets "appear, for example, to walk through doors (although the control wires make this impossible) or pick up a coffee cup (although their fingers are not in fact jointed)."<ref>Anderson 2007, p. 39.</ref> Live-action shots of human hands were inserted whenever scripts called for more dexterous actions to be performed.<ref name="Peel, 20">Peel, p. 20.</ref> {{Clear}}
====Special effects==== The effects for all the APF series from ''Supercar'' to ''[[UFO (TV series)|UFO]]'' were directed by [[Derek Meddings]], who later worked on the ''[[James Bond in film|James Bond]]'' and ''[[Superman in film|Superman]]'' films.<ref>Peel, p. 21.</ref> Knowing that ''Thunderbirds'' would be the "biggest project [APF] had worked on", Meddings found himself struggling to manage his workload with the single filming unit that had produced all the effects for ''Stingray''.<ref name="Bentley, 24"/><ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 104.</ref> He therefore established a second unit under technician [[Brian Johncock]], and a third exclusively for filming airborne sequences.<ref name="Bentley, 24 and 28">Bentley 2005, pp. 24 and 28.</ref> This expansion increased the number of APF crews and stages to five each.<ref name="Bentley, 24 and 28"/> A typical episode contained around 100 effects shots;<ref name="Bignell, 76">Bignell, p. 76.</ref><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 40.</ref> Meddings' team completed up to 18 per day.<ref>Archer, p. 63.</ref>
An addition to the effects department was [[Mike Trim]], who served as Meddings' assistant in designing vehicles and buildings.<ref name="Bentley, 24"/><ref>Meddings, p. 60.</ref> Meddings and Trim jointly pioneered an "organic" design technique in which the exteriors of models and sets were customised with parts from model kits and children's toys.<ref>Meddings, p. 59.</ref><ref>Taylor and Trim, p. 15.</ref> Models and sets were also "dirtied down" with powder paint or [[pencil lead]] to create a used look.<ref name="Andersonic9">{{Cite journal|date=Spring 2010|title=Interview: Mike Trim – Designs on the Future|journal=Andersonic|volume=1|issue=9|pages=4–12|editor=Farrell, Richard}}</ref><ref>Peel, p. 22.</ref> Toy cars and vans were used in [[long shot]], while scale vehicles were equipped with basic steering and [[Suspension (vehicle)|suspension]] for added realism.<ref>Meddings, p. 57.</ref><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 107">Archer and Hearn, p. 107.</ref> Miniature fans and [[Jetex]] pellets, which are capable of issuing air jets or chemical exhaust, were attached to the undersides to simulate dust trails.<ref name="Bentley, 25">Bentley 2005, p. 25.</ref><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 107"/> Another of Meddings' inventions was a closed, cyclical effects stage nicknamed the "rolling road": consisting of two or more loops of canvas running at different speeds, this device allowed shots of moving vehicles to be filmed on a static set to make more efficient use of the limited studio space.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 21–22.</ref><ref>Bignell, p. 79.</ref> Airborne aircraft sequences were mounted against a "rolling sky", with smoke fanned across to simulate passing clouds.<ref name="Bentley, 22"/>
[[File:Stourhead House (8349738431).jpg|thumb|Stourhead House, designed in the [[Palladian]] style by [[Colen Campbell]] and completed in 1725, inspired the architecture of [[Creighton-Ward Mansion]].<ref name="La Rivière, 113"/>|alt=A mansion with two adjacent wings, with a gravel drive and lawn in front]]
One of Meddings' first tasks was to shoot [[stock footage]] of the ''Thunderbird'' machines and the series' main locations, Tracy Island and Creighton-Ward Mansion.<ref name="Bentley, 21">Bentley 2005, p. 21.</ref><ref>Peel, p. 24.</ref> The finished island model was a composite of more than a dozen smaller sets that could be detached from the whole and filmed separately.<ref>Meddings, p. 43.</ref> The architecture of the mansion was based on that of Stourhead House, located on the [[Stourhead|Stourhead Estate]] in Wiltshire.<ref name="La Rivière, 113">La Rivière, p. 113.</ref> In the absence of head designer Reg Hill, who was serving as [[associate producer]], Meddings was further tasked with designing the ''Thunderbird'' fleet and FAB 1.<ref name="Bentley, 12"/> Scale models for the six main vehicles were built by a contractor, Master Models of Middlesex.<ref name="Bentley, 13"/><ref name="Taylor and Trim, 12">Taylor and Trim, p. 12.</ref> Models and puppet sets combined, more than 200 versions of the ''Thunderbird'' machines were created for the series.<ref>Archer, p. 42.</ref>
During the designing and filming process, Meddings' first priorities were realism and credibility.<ref>Meddings, p. 44.</ref> With the exception of ''Thunderbird 5'', each vehicle was built in three or four scales.<ref>Archer, p. 93.</ref> Meddings' [[swing-wing]] concept for ''[[Thunderbird 1]]'' was inspired by his wish to create something "more dynamic" than a fixed-wing aircraft.<ref name="Meddings, 45">Meddings, p. 45.</ref> He remained unsatisfied with the prototype of ''[[Thunderbird 2]]'' until he inverted the wings, later commenting, "... at the time, all aircraft had swept-back wings. I only did it to be different."<ref name="Bentley, 13"/> This decision was made out of personal preference and was not informed by any expert knowledge on Meddings' part.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 105">Archer and Hearn, p. 105.</ref><ref name="Meddings, 46">Meddings, p. 46.</ref> He described the ''Thunderbird 2'' launch as "probably the most memorable" sequence that his team devised for an APF production.<ref name="Meddings, 46"/>
The largest model of ''[[Thunderbird 3]]'', whose design was loosely based on the Soviet ''[[Soyuz (rocket)|Soyuz]]'' rocket, was {{Convert|6|ft|spell=in}} tall.<ref name="Bentley, 13"/> ''[[Thunderbird 4]]'' was particularly difficult to film: as the scale of the model did not correspond to the water inside the shooting tank, creative camera angles and rapid editing were used to produce a sense of realistic perspective.<ref>Meddings, p. 52.</ref> ''Thunderbird 5'', the most difficult vehicle for Meddings to visualise, was based on the Tracy Island Round House.<ref name="Bentley, 14"/> Since most of the space station's appearances were provided by stock footage, the model was rarely filmed.<ref>Meddings, p. 58.</ref> Pod Vehicles were designed on an episode-by-episode basis and built from balsa wood, [[Jelutong]] wood or fibreglass.<ref>Meddings, pp. 52 and 54.</ref> To save time and costs, other minor vehicles were built in-house from radio-controlled model kits.<ref name="Bentley, 13"/><ref name="Andersonic9"/>
As the puppets of Lady Penelope and Parker needed to fit inside, the largest of all the models was the seven-foot FAB 1, which cost £2,500 (approximately £{{Inflation|UK|2500|1964|r=-3|fmt=c}} in {{inflation-year|UK}}) to build.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 13–14.</ref> The Rolls-Royce's name and colour were both chosen by Sylvia Anderson.<ref>Anderson 2007, p. 65.</ref> [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls-Royce Ltd.]] supervised the construction of the plywood model and supplied APF with an authentic [[radiator grille]] for close-up shots of the front of the car.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 106"/><ref>La Rivière, p. 112.</ref> In exchange for its cooperation, the company requested that a [[Spirit of Ecstasy]] be fixed to the chassis and that the characters avoid referring to the brand with abbreviations such as "Rolls".<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 106">Archer and Hearn, p. 106.</ref><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 66.</ref>
[[File:Hawker Siddeley Gnat T1, UK - Air Force AN2239232.jpg|thumb|left|Some of the aircraft sound effects were created by recording the RAF's [[Red Arrows]] aerobatics display team in flight.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 119"/>|alt=A squadron of one-man jet aircraft, with their canopies open, lined up at a military airbase.]]
Scale explosions were created using substances such as [[fuller's earth]], [[petrol]] gel, magnesium strips and [[Cordtex]] explosive.<ref name="La Rivière, 123"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 59.</ref> They were originally filmed at up to 120 [[frames per second]] (f.p.s.), so that when slowed down to the regular [[24p|24 f.p.s.]], their apparent magnitude and length would be increased.<ref name="MakingSecrets"/><ref name="Marriott, 173">Marriott 1993, p. 173.</ref> Gunpowder canisters were ignited to create rocket jets.<ref name="Bentley, 28"/> The wires that electronically fired the rockets also allowed a member of the crew, holding a cruciform and positioned on an overhead gantry, to "fly" the model over the set.<ref name="Bentley, 28"/> By far the most unwieldy model was ''Thunderbird 2'', which Meddings remembered as being "awful" to fly.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 105"/><ref name="Marriott, 172">Marriott 1993, p. 172.</ref> A combination of unreliable rockets and weak wiring frequently caused problems: should the former be slow to ignite, the current quickly caused the latter to overheat and snap, potentially damaging the model and even setting fire to the set.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 105"/><ref name="Meddings, 50">Meddings, p. 50.</ref> Conditions above the studio floor were often dangerous due to the heat and smoke.<ref name="La Rivière, 122"/> Although many of the exhaust sound effects used in the series were drawn from an audio library, some were specially recorded during a [[Red Arrows]] display at [[RAF Little Rissington]] in Gloucestershire.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 119">Archer and Hearn, p. 119.</ref><ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 95.</ref>
By 1966, Meddings' commitments were split between Series Two and ''Thunderbirds Are Go''.<ref name="Bentley, 31"/> While Meddings worked on the film, camera operator Jimmy Elliott assumed the responsibility of directing the TV effects.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 35.</ref> By this stage, the basic frame of ''Thunderbird 2'' had been damaged so many times that the model had needed to be rebuilt from scratch.<ref name="La Rivière, 132">La Rivière, p. 132.</ref> Meddings was displeased with the result, reflecting that the replacement was "not only the wrong colour, it was a completely different shape ... I never felt our model-makers managed to recapture the look of the original."<ref name="La Rivière, 132"/>
Critic David Garland suggests that the challenge facing the ''Thunderbirds'' effects department was to strike a balance between the "conventional science-fiction imperative of the 'futuristic'" and the "seeping hyper-realist concerns mandated by the Andersons' approach to the puppets".<ref>Garland, p. 67.</ref> ''Thunderbirds'' has been praised for the quality of its effects. Jim Sangster and Paul Condon, writers of ''Collins Telly Guide'', consider the model work "uniformly impressive".<ref name="Sangster and Condon">{{Cite book|title=Collins Telly Guide|author1=Sangster, Jim |author2=Condon, Paul |year=2005|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-00-719099-7|pages=758–760}}</ref> To [[Paul Cornell]], [[Martin Day]] and [[Keith Topping]], writers of ''The Guinness Book of Classic British TV'', the effects are "way beyond anything seen on TV previously".<ref name="Cornell, Day and Topping">{{Cite book|author=[[Paul Cornell|Cornell, Paul]]; [[Martin Day|Day, Martin]]; [[Keith Topping|Topping, Keith]]|title=The Guinness Book of Classic British TV|editor=Marshall, Anne|year=1996|origyear=1993|edition=2nd|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-85112-628-9}}</ref> Impressed by their work on ''Thunderbirds'', film director [[Stanley Kubrick]] hired several members of Meddings' staff to supervise the effects shooting for ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''.<ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 143.</ref><ref>La Rivière, p. 139.</ref>
====Title sequence==== [[File:Gerry Anderson.jpg|thumb|alt=Gerry Anderson|Series co-creator [[Gerry Anderson]] storyboarded the ''Thunderbirds'' [[title sequence]].]]
The series' [[title sequence]], storyboarded by Gerry Anderson, is made up of two parts. It opens with a countdown of "5, 4, 3, 2, 1: ''Thunderbirds'' Are Go!", provided by Dyneley in character as Jeff Tracy.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121"/> In a departure from the style of ''Stingray'', the ''Thunderbirds'' title sequence varies with each episode: the first part consists of an action montage that serves as a preview of the plot. Simon Archer and Marcus Hearn, biographers of Gerry Anderson, compare this device favourably to a film [[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]].<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121"/>
The second part, accompanied by composer [[Barry Gray]]'s "The ''Thunderbirds'' March", features portraits of the main puppet cast superimposed on various vehicles and settings.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 121"/> Peel describes this as "ostensibly a return to the 'series stars' concept long known in TV",<ref>Peel, p. 241.</ref> while Garland considers such imagery demonstrative of Anderson's commitment to "incremental realism" through a convergence of human and puppet characteristics.<ref>Garland, p. 66.</ref> Essayist Jonathan Bignell suggests that the use of portraits conveys Anderson's partiality to "visual revelation of machines and physical action".<ref name="Bignell, 78">Bignell, p. 78.</ref>
According to Daniel O'Brien, writer of ''SF:UK: How British Science Fiction Changed the World'', the ''Thunderbirds'' title sequence encapsulates the reasons for the series' enduring popularity.<ref name="O'Brien, 83">O'Brien, p. 83.</ref> Dyneley's countdown is particularly well remembered and has been widely quoted.<ref name="Knowles">{{Cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations|author=Knowles, Elizabeth|year=2007|edition=3rd|origyear=1991|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=New York, US|isbn=978-0-19-920895-1}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English: J-Z|series=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|volume=2|author=[[Eric Partridge|Partridge, Eric]]|editor1=Dalzell, Tony|editor2=Victor, Terry|year=2006|publisher=[[Routledge]]|location=[[Abingdon-on-Thames|Abingdon]], UK; New York City, New York|isbn=978-0-415-25938-5|page=1,960}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/thunderbirds-are-go-again-itv-commissions-26-episodes-from-lord-of-the-rings-special-effects-team-8479716.html|title=''Thunderbirds'' Are Go (again)! ITV Commissions 26 Episodes from ''Lord of the Rings'' Special Effects Team|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|author=[[Adam Sherwin|Sherwin, Adam]]|date=4 February 2013|accessdate=21 October 2014|publisher=Independent Print|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802035201/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/thunderbirds-are-go-again-itv-commissions-26-episodes-from-lord-of-the-rings-special-effects-team-8479716.html|archivedate=2 August 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> Dean Newman of the [[Syfy]] channel website ranks ''Thunderbirds'' eighth in a list of "Top 10 TV title sequences",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.syfy.co.uk/blogs/top-ten-tv-title-sequences|title=Top Ten TV Title Sequences|author=Newman, Dean|work=[[Syfy|Syfy.co.uk]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|location=New York City, New York|accessdate=19 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220211730/http://www.syfy.co.uk/blogs/top-ten-tv-title-sequences|archivedate=20 February 2014|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> while [[Den of Geek]]'s Martin Anderson considers the sequence the best of any TV series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/tv/thunderbirds/19272/top-10-tv-title-sequences-of-all-time-the-winner |title=Top 10 TV Title Sequences of All Time: the Winner |author=Anderson, Martin |date=28 September 2007 |work=Den of Geek |publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]] |location=London, UK |accessdate=31 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616195518/http://www.denofgeek.com/tv/thunderbirds/19272/top-10-tv-title-sequences-of-all-time-the-winner |archivedate=16 June 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===Music=== {{See also|Thunderbirds merchandise#Music releases}} The score was composed by Gray, who served as musical director for all of the Anderson productions up to the first series of ''[[Space: 1999]]''. In response to Gerry Anderson's request that the main theme have a "military feel", Gray produced a [[Brass instrument|brass]]-dominated piece titled "The ''Thunderbirds'' March", which was recorded in December 1964 at [[Olympic Studios]] in London.<ref name="Bentley, 26"/><ref name="LampMusic">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lampmusic.co.uk/downloads/barry_gray_biog.pdf |title=Barry Gray Biography |author=Titterton, Ralph; Ford, Cathy; Bentley, Chris; [[Barry Gray|Gray, Barry]] |work=lampmusic.co.uk |format=[[PDF]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rP7v8Ktg?url=http://www.lampmusic.co.uk/downloads/barry_gray_biog.pdf |archivedate=22 July 2010 |accessdate=16 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The end titles were originally to have been accompanied by "Flying High", a lyrical track sung by [[Gary Miller (singer)|Gary Miller]] with backing by [[Ken Barrie]].<ref name="La Rivière, 128"/> Ultimately, a variation of the march was used instead.<ref name="LampMusic"/> [[Incidental music]] was recorded over nine months between March and December 1965.<ref name="LampMusic"/><ref name="TVCentury21">{{Cite web |author=de Klerk, Theo |title=Complete Studio-Recording List of Barry Gray |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67:complete-studio-recording-list-of-barry-gray&catid=116:barry-gray&Itemid=182 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=25 December 2003 |accessdate=16 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m00eATOK?url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67:complete-studio-recording-list-of-barry-gray&catid=116:barry-gray&Itemid=182 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> As most of the music budget was spent on the series' earlier episodes, later instalments drew heavily on APF's ever-expanding music library.<ref name="LampMusic"/><ref name="TVCentury21"/>
Peel considers "The ''Thunderbirds'' March" to be "one of the best TV themes ever written – perfect for the show and catchy when heard alone".<ref>Peel, pp. 29–30.</ref> Morag Reavley of [[BBC Online]] argues that the piece is "up there ... in the quintessential soundtrack of the Sixties" with the ''James Bond'' films and the songs of [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Elvis]] and [[The Beatles]].<ref name="Reavley">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/6hw6|author=Reavley, Morag|title=''Thunderbirds (Original Television Soundtrack) Volume 1''|year=2003|work=[[BBC Online]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|location=London, UK|accessdate=5 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110212184659/http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/6hw6|archivedate=12 February 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> More generally, he praises the series' "catchy, pulse-quickening tunes", as well as Gray's aptitude for "musical nuance" and the mixing of genres.<ref name="Reavley"/> Heather Phares of [[Allmusic]] considers "Thunderbirds Are Go!" – the track accompanying the launch sequences of ''Thunderbirds 1'', ''2'' and ''3'' – to be a reflection of the [[Mod (subculture)|mod]] aspect of 1960s British spy fiction.<ref name="Phares">{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/thunderbirds-original-tv-soundtrack-mw0000593528|author=Phares, Heather|title=''Thunderbirds (Original Television Soundtrack) Volume 1''|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=All Media Network|location=San Francisco, California|accessdate=16 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131122015125/http://www.allmusic.com/album/thunderbirds-original-tv-soundtrack-mw0000593528|archivedate=22 November 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> She also highlights Gray's homage to – and divergence from – musical norms, commenting that his score "sends up the spy and action/adventure conventions of the '60s very stylishly and subtly".<ref name="Phares"/>
David Huckvale identifies [[Wagner]]ian homage in both the theme music and the series' premise.<ref name="Huckvale">{{Cite book|title=A Night in at the Opera: Media Representations of Opera|editor=[[Jeremy Tambling|Tambling, Jeremy]]|year=1994|publisher=John Libbey and Company|location=London, UK|chapter=The Composing Machine: Wagner and Popular Culture|author=Huckvale, David|isbn=978-0-86196-466-6|page=119}}</ref> Noting that the theme's opening string [[ostinato]] is similar in effect to a recurring [[Motif (music)|motif]] in ''[[Ride of the Valkyries]]'', he also likens the ''Thunderbird'' machines to [[Valkyrie]]s themselves: "Their function is more benevolent than those warrior maidens, but they ''do'' hover over danger, death and destruction."<ref name="Huckvale"/> Kevin J. Donnelly of the [[University of Southampton]] acknowledges the series' "big-sounding orchestral score", which he compares to that of a live-action film.<ref name="Donnelly">{{Cite book|title=Music in Science Fiction Television: Tuned to the Future|series=Music and Screen Media|chapter=Television's Musical Imagination: ''Space: 1999''|author=Donnelly, Kevin J.|editor1=Donnelly, Kevin J. |editor2=Hayward, Philip |year=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon, UK; New York City, New York|isbn=978-0-415-64107-4|page=114}}</ref> He also suggests that the music serves partly to draw attention away from the physical imperfections of the puppets.<ref name="Donnelly"/>
==Broadcast== ''Thunderbirds'' premiered on British television on 30 September 1965 on the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] franchises [[ATV Midlands]], [[Westward Television|Westward]] and [[Channel Television|Channel]].<ref name="Bentley: EG, 96">Bentley 2008, p. 96.</ref> Other broadcasters, including [[Associated Television|ATV London]] and [[ITV Granada|Granada]], started transmissions the following month.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 125">Archer and Hearn, p. 125.</ref><ref name="Bentley: EG, 96"/> The Christmas-themed series finale, "[[List of Thunderbirds episodes#Series Two (1966)|Give or Take a Million]]", was first broadcast on 25 December 1966.<ref name="Bentley, 95">Bentley 2005, p. 95.</ref> Despite Grade's decision to extend the running time, the series was also sold in a 25-minute format that effectively doubled the number of episodes; this was the version used by Granada for their original broadcasts.<ref name="Bentley, 26"/><ref>Bentley 2008, p. 13.</ref> In this area, two instalments aired on the same night, separated by the [[ITN Evening News]], and the conclusion would begin with a narration by Shane Rimmer summarising the previous episode's action.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 114">Bentley 2008, p. 114.</ref> In the Midlands, ATV broadcast the complete hour-long versions in a 7.00pm slot for the first 26 episodes. <ref>{{cite journal|title=TV World (Midlands edition)|date=2 October 1965}}</ref> The second series, together with repeats of series one, was shown in the two-part format on consecutive evenings in a 5.25pm slot. <ref>{{cite journal|title=TV World (Midlands edition)|date=18 March 1967}}</ref>
Granada transmitted ''Thunderbirds'' in its original, 50-minute format for the first time with the start of repeats in 1966.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 114"/> In 1968, the franchise briefly aired episodes in three parts due to timeslot restrictions.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 114"/> The availability of repeats during the 1960s and 1970s varied among regions. ATV Midlands screened the series regularly into the early 1970s; by contrast, ''Thunderbirds'' was entirely absent from [[Yorkshire Television]] between 1968 and 1976.<ref name="Bentley, 37"/><ref name="Bentley, 124">Bentley 2005, p. 124.</ref> The series was last transmitted on the ITV franchises in 1981.<ref name="Bentley, 124"/>
In 1990, 8 of the [[List of Thunderbirds episodes#Audio episodes|19 audio episodes released by APF Records]] were converted into radio dramas, which were transmitted on [[BBC Radio 5 (former)|BBC Radio 5]].<ref name="Bentley: EG, 114"/> The success of the radio series encouraged the BBC to acquire the rights to the TV episodes, which it broadcast simultaneously in all regions from September 1991 on [[BBC2]].<ref name="Bentley, 124"/><ref name="Cull: Fifty, 5">Cull 2009, p. 5.</ref>
Since the end of the first network run, which achieved average viewing figures of more than six million,<ref name="Marriott, 187"/><ref>Cull 2006 (August), p. 203.</ref> the BBC has repeated the series six times: between 1992 and 1993 (Series One only), 1994 and 1995 (nine episodes only), and 2000 and 2001 (in remastered form), as well as in 2003, 2005 and 2006.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/><ref name="Bentley, 5"/> Other channels that have shown repeats include [[Gold (UK TV channel)|UK Gold]] (1994–95), [[Bravo (UK TV channel)|Bravo]] (1996–97), [[Cartoon Network (UK & Ireland)|Cartoon Network]] (2001–02), [[Boomerang (UK & Ireland)|Boomerang]] (2001–03) and [[Syfy (UK and Ireland)|Syfy]] (2009).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/thunderbirds-summer-run/1170368.article|title=''Thunderbirds'' Summer Run|date=23 February 2001|author=Rogers, Jon|accessdate=21 October 2014|work=[[Broadcast (magazine)|Broadcast]]|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]]|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021032946/http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/thunderbirds-summer-run/1170368.article|archivedate=21 October 2014|deadurl=no}} {{Subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.syfy.co.uk/shows/thunderbirds|title=''Thunderbirds''|accessdate=21 October 2014|work=Syfy.co.uk|publisher=NBCUniversal|location=New York City, New York|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140803202004/http://www.syfy.co.uk/shows/thunderbirds|archivedate=3 August 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> In Scotland, the BBC screened a [[Scottish Gaelic|Gaelic]] dub, ''Tairnearan Tar As'' ("''Thunderbirds Are Go''") in the early 1990s.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 125.</ref>
Before its UK debut, ''Thunderbirds'' was distributed to 30 other countries including the US, Canada, Australia and Japan.<ref name="Bentley, 31"/> Pre-sales revenue totalled £350,000 (approximately
