==Reception== ''Thunderbirds'' is generally considered the Andersons' most popular series and their greatest critical and commercial success.<ref name="Taylor and Trim, 71">Taylor and Trim, p. 71.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=''Thunderbirds'' Creator's Final Books to be Completed|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23969811|date=5 September 2013|work=[[BBC News Online]]|publisher=BBC|location=London, UK|accessdate=11 October 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905165320/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23969811|archivedate=5 September 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2012|author=Lentz, Harris M.|series=Lentz's Performing Arts Obituaries Series|volume=19|year=2013|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|location=[[Jefferson, North Carolina|Jefferson]], North Carolina|isbn=978-0-7864-7063-1|page=9}}</ref> In 1966, the show received a [[Royal Television Society]] Silver Medal for Outstanding Artistic Achievement and Gerry Anderson received an honorary fellowship of the [[British Kinematograph, Sound and Television Society]].<ref name="Bentley, 37"/> In 2007, ''Thunderbirds'' achieved 19th place in a ''[[Radio Times]]'' magazine reader poll to determine the best science-fiction TV programme of all time.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Sci-Fi Survey Results |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/sci-fi-survey/ |publisher=[[Radio Times|radiotimes.com]] |location=London, UK |year=2007 |accessdate=28 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lzzY1ihB?url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/sci-fi-survey/ |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It is ranked fourth by the 2013 [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] list show ''[[50 Greatest Kids TV Shows|50 Greatest Kids' TV Shows]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.licensing.biz/news/read/channel-5-reveals-greatest-kids-tv-shows-results/039007|title=Channel 5 Reveals ''Greatest Kids' TV Shows'' Results|author=Langsworthy, Billy|date=12 November 2013|work=licensing.biz|publisher=[[NewBay Media|Intent Media]]|location=New York City, New York|accessdate=30 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222212907/http://www.licensing.biz/news/read/channel-5-reveals-greatest-kids-tv-shows-results/039007|archivedate=22 February 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
For Peel, ''Thunderbirds'' is "without a doubt the peak of the Supermarionation achievement".<ref name="Peel, 240">Peel, p. 240.</ref> Suggesting that the series is pitched at a "more adult" level than its predecessors, he adds that its sense of adventure, effective humour and "gripping and convincing" episodes ensured that "everyone in the audience found something to love about it."<ref name="Peel, 242">Peel, p. 242.</ref><ref>Peel, p. 244.</ref> [[Simon Heffer]], a fan of ''Thunderbirds'' in childhood, commented positively on the series for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' in 2011: "All the elements we children discerned in whatever grown-up television we had been allowed to watch were present in ''Thunderbirds'': dramatic theme and incidental music; well-developed plots; goodies and baddies; swaggering Americans, at a time when the whole of Britain was in a [[cultural cringe]] to them; and, of course, glamorous locations ... Then, of course, there was the nail-biting tension of the rescues themselves ..."<ref name="Heffer">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/simonheffer/8261297/Why-Thunderbirds-is-still-FAB.html|title=Why ''Thunderbirds'' is Still FAB|author=[[Simon Heffer|Heffer, Simon]]|date=15 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|location=London, UK|accessdate=16 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119090449/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/simonheffer/8261297/Why-Thunderbirds-is-still-FAB.html|archivedate=19 January 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> Film critic [[Kim Newman]] describes the series as a "television perennial".<ref name="Newman">{{Cite journal|author=[[Kim Newman|Newman, Kim]]|title=''Thunderbirds'' on DVD: Puppet Love|journal=[[Sight and Sound]]|date=February 2001|location=London, UK|publisher=British Film Institute|volume=11|issue=2 [NS]|page=60|issn=0037-4806|oclc=60617057}}</ref>
In his foreword to John Marriott's book, ''Thunderbirds Are Go!'', Anderson put forward several explanations for the series' enduring popularity: it "contains elements that appeal to most children – danger, jeopardy and destruction. But because International Rescue's mission is to save life, there is no gratuitous violence."<ref name="Marriott: Thunderbirds, 7">Marriott 1992, p. 7.</ref> According to Anderson, ''Thunderbirds'' incorporates a "strong family atmosphere, where Dad reigns supreme".<ref name="Marriott: Thunderbirds, 7"/> Both O'Brien and script editor Alan Pattillo have praised the series' positive "family values".<ref>O'Brien, p. 78.</ref><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 180.</ref> In addition, Heffer and others have written of its cross-generational appeal.<ref name="Heffer"/><ref name="Evans">{{Cite book|author=Evans, Jeff|title=The Penguin TV Companion|year=2003|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-14-101221-6|page=721}}</ref> In 2000, shortly before the series' BBC revival, [[Brian Viner]] remarked in ''Radio Times'' that ''Thunderbirds'' was on the point of "captivating yet another generation of viewers".<ref>{{Cite journal|author=[[Brian Viner|Viner, Brian]]|date=2 September 2000|title=New Shows Are Go!|journal=[[Radio Times]]|location=London, UK|publisher=[[BBC Magazines]]|volume=306|issue=3,993|page=16|issn=0033-8060|oclc=1763373}}</ref> [[Stuart Hood]], writing for ''[[The Spectator]]'' in 1965, praised ''Thunderbirds'' as a "modern fairy tale"; adding that it "can sometimes be frightening", he recommended that children watch it accompanied by their parents.<ref name="Hood">{{Cite journal|author=Hood, Stuart|date=31 December 1965|title=Arts and Amusements – Television: ''Funderbirds''|journal=[[The Spectator]]|publisher=[[Press Holdings]]|issue=7,175|page=14|issn=0038-6952|oclc=1766325|url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/31st-december-1965/14/television |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128004555/http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/31st-december-1965/14/television|accessdate=16 October 2014|archivedate=28 January 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Dreamwatch]]'' in 1994, Andrew Thomas described ''Thunderbirds'' as only "nominally" a children's programme: "Its themes are universal and speak as much to the adult in the child as the child in the adult."<ref name="Thomas, 22">Thomas, p. 22.</ref>
[[Jeff Evans]], author of ''The Penguin TV Companion'', argues that the series' 50-minute format allows for stronger character development and "tension-building".<ref name="Evans"/> O'Brien is less positive in his appraisal of the writing, asserting that the plots are often "formulaic" and are sometimes "stretched to snapping point" by the extended running time.<ref name="O'Brien, 83"/> Cornell, Day and Topping are critical: they consider the writing at times "woefully poor" and argue that ''Thunderbirds'' as a whole is "often as clichéd as previous Anderson series".<ref name="Cornell, Day and Topping"/> Peel, despite praising the storylines and characterisation, suggests that the "tongue-in-cheek" humour of ''Stingray'' is less evident.<ref>Peel, pp. 240–248.</ref> Where ''Thunderbirds'' improves on its predecessor, Peel believes, is in its rejection of fantasy plot devices, child and animal characters, comical and stereotyped villains and what he terms the "standard Anderson sexism": female characters, marginalised in earlier series, are more commonly seen to play active and sometimes heroic roles.<ref>Peel, pp. 242–243.</ref>
Noting the attention to detail of the series' launch sequences, Jonathan Bignell argues that part of the motivation for dedicating large amounts of screen time to the ''Thunderbird'' craft is the need to compensate for the limited mobility of the puppet cast.<ref name="Bignell, 78"/> The focus on futuristic machines has also been explored by cultural historian [[Nicholas J. Cull]], who comments that of all the Andersons' series, ''Thunderbirds'' is the most evocative of a recurring theme: the "necessity of the human component of the machine", whereby the failures of new technology are overcome by "brave human beings and technology working together".<ref>Cull 2006 (August), pp. 197–198.</ref><ref name="Cull: Fifty, 6">Cull 2009, p. 6.</ref> This makes the series' vision of the 2060s "wonderfully [[humanistic]] and reassuring".<ref name="Cull: Media, 197"/> O'Brien similarly praises this optimism, comparing the Tracy family to guardian [[Übermensch]].<ref name="O'Brien, 83"/> Writing for ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired UK]]'' magazine, [[Warren Ellis]] asserts that the series' scientific vision could inspire the next generation of "mad and frightening engineers", adding that ''Thunderbirds'' "trades in vast, demented concepts ... immense and very beautiful ideas as solutions to problems."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2009/10/start/thunderbirds-will-grow-a-generation-of-mad-engineers|title=''Thunderbirds'' will Grow a Generation of Mad Engineers|author=[[Warren Ellis|Ellis, Warren]]|journal=[[Wired UK]]|date=2 September 2009|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|location=New York City, New York|accessdate=18 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121153514/http://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2009/10/start/thunderbirds-will-grow-a-generation-of-mad-engineers|archivedate=21 January 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Thomas argues that the world of ''Thunderbirds'' is similar to the 1960s to the extent that contemporary [[capitalism]] and [[class structure]]s appear to have survived mostly intact. He also observes, however, that wealth and high social status are often depicted as character flaws rather than strengths.<ref name="Thomas, 24">Thomas, p. 24.</ref> According to Thomas, a contributing factor to the series' lasting popularity is the realism of IR's machines.<ref name="Thomas, 22"/> Newman, for his part, suggests that "the point isn't realism. The 21st century of ''Thunderbirds'' is detailed ... but also de-populated, a high-tech toyland".<ref name="Newman"/> He is more negative in his comparisons of contemporary and future values, noting the "square, almost 50s" attitudes to race, gender and class.<ref name="Newman"/> With regard to stereotyping, Hood comments that he "would be happier if [villains] didn't seem to be recognisable by their pigmentation".<ref name="Hood"/> Cull, by contrast, considers the series largely progressive on the subject of race, arguing that it rejects negative [[stereotyping]] through the use of "positive non-white characters" such as Kyrano and Tin-Tin.<ref name="Cull: Media, 197">Cull 2006 (August), p. 197.</ref> However, he deems many of the one-off villains derivative, commenting that these characters are typically presented as "corrupt businessmen, [[spiv]]s and gangsters familiar from crime films".<ref name="Cull: Media, 197"/>
Various commentators – including Bignell, Cull and O'Brien – have also discussed ''Thunderbirds'' as a product of the Cold War era. Bignell comments that the Hood's Oriental appearance and mysterious powers draw parallels with ''James Bond'' villains and fears of China operating as "a 'third force' antagonistic to the West".<ref name="O'Brien, 83"/><ref>Bignell, p. 83.</ref> Cull observes that, despite the series' focus on the dangers of nuclear technology, the ''Thunderbird'' machines contradict this particular theme: in their case, "an image of technology associated with the threat of Cold War mass destruction – the rocket emerging from the hidden silo – was appropriated and deployed to ''save'' life rather than to take it."<ref name="Cull: Media, 198"/> He argues that the series adheres more closely to cultural norms by drawing on the "Cold War cult of the secret agent whose skills defend the home from enemies unknown", noting Lady Penelope's role as a spy in addition to two episodes ("[[30 Minutes After Noon]]" and "The Man from MI.5") that are heavily influenced by the ''James Bond'' novels and film adaptations.<ref>Cull 2006 (August), p. 199.</ref>
During a 2001 exhibition dedicated to the series, Masaaki Hirakata, curator at the [[Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography]], likened ''Thunderbirds'' to "a modern sci-fi expression of [[bunraku]], which probably explains why it was accepted so readily [in Japan]".<ref>{{cite news |last=Gilhooly |first=Rob |title=Still F.A.B. After All These Years |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2001/12/26/arts/still-f-a-b-after-all-these-years/#.WO67dlPyutg |accessdate=12 April 2017|work=[[The Japan Times]] |date= 26 December 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170516160851/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2001/12/26/arts/still-f-a-b-after-all-these-years/#.WyMA7CAnbIU |archivedate=16 May 2017 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
The series' presentation of smoking was the subject of a study published in the medical journal ''Tobacco Control'' in 2002. Despite identifying examples in 26 episodes, Kate Hunt of the [[University of Glasgow]] concluded that ''Thunderbirds'' does not actively promote smoking – a view opposed by the [[Roy Castle Lung Cancer Foundation]] (RCLCF) at the time of the series' relaunch on BBC 2.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Hunt, Kate|year=2002|title=Re-Evaluating Smoking and Gender in ''Thunderbirds'' 35 Years On|journal=Tobacco Control|volume=11|issue=2|pages=151–153|location=New York City, New York|publisher=[[BMJ|BMJ Publishing Group]]|format=PDF|issn=1468-3318|oclc=645295997|doi=10.1136/tc.11.2.151|accessdate=15 August 2013|url=http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/11/2/151.full|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718234818/http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/11/2/151.full|archivedate=18 July 2012|deadurl=no|pmc=1763855}}</ref><ref name="BBCSmoking">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1193980.stm|title=Lady Penelope in the Dock|date=28 February 2001|work=BBC News Online|publisher=BBC|location=London, UK|accessdate=7 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517065052/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1193980.stm|archivedate=17 May 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref> Rejecting the RCLCF's proposal that the remastered episodes be edited to digitally erase all visible cigarettes and cigars, the BBC stated that the series "does not glorify or encourage smoking" and described the activity as "incidental to the plot".<ref name="BBCSmoking"/>
==Merchandise== {{Main article|Thunderbirds merchandise}} More than 3,000 ''Thunderbirds''-themed products have been marketed since the series' debut.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/> To accommodate the high demand for [[tie-in]]s, APF established three dedicated subsidiaries: [[Century 21 Merchandising|AP Films Merchandising]], AP Films Music and AP Films Toys.<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 111.</ref><ref>Bignell, p. 80.</ref> Some British commentators dubbed the 1966 end-of-year shopping season "''Thunderbirds'' Christmas" due to the series' popularity.<ref name="Bentley, 37"/> In the early 1990s, [[Matchbox (brand)|Matchbox]] launched a new toy range to coincide with the BBC 2 repeats.<ref name="Bentley, 124"/> Sales figures for Christmas 1992 exceeded those achieved by the ''[[Star Wars]]'' merchandising campaigns of the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name="Cull: Fifty, 5"/><ref name="Marriott, 190">Marriott 1993, p. 190.</ref> Demand for Matchbox's Tracy Island Playset overwhelmed supply, resulting in shop fights and a substantial black market for the toy.<ref name="Bentley, 124"/>
A comic strip featuring the characters of Lady Penelope and Parker debuted in the early issues of APF Publishing's children's title ''[[TV Century 21]]'' in 1965.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 104.</ref><ref name="Peel, 27">Peel, p. 27.</ref> A full-length ''Thunderbirds'' strip appeared a year later, at which point the Lady Penelope adventures were [[Lady Penelope (comic)|given their own comic]].<ref name="Peel, 27"/><ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 135.</ref> ''Thunderbirds'', ''Lady Penelope'' and ''Captain Scarlet and Thunderbirds'' annuals were published in the late 1960s; during the same period, eight original novels were written.<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 108–109.</ref> In 2008, FTL Publications of Minnesota launched a new series of tie-in novels.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/childrens/childrens-book-news/article/18510-licensing-hotline-april-3-2008.html|title=Licensing Hotline: April 2008|newspaper=[[Publishers Weekly]]|author=Raugust, Karen|date=3 April 2008|publisher=PWxyz|location=New York City, New York|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211205102/http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/childrens/childrens-book-news/article/18510-licensing-hotline-april-3-2008.html|archivedate=11 December 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Between 1965 and 1967, APF Records released [[List of Thunderbirds episodes#Audio episodes|19 audio episodes]] in the form of vinyl [[Extended play|EP]]s.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 349">Bentley 2008, p. 349.</ref><ref name="Bentley, 100">Bentley 2005, p. 100.</ref> Three are original stories; the rest are adapted from TV episode soundtracks, with additional narration provided by a member of the voice cast.<ref>Bentley 2008, p. 348.</ref><ref>Peel, p. 28.</ref> The series' first video game tie-in, developed for the [[Commodore 64]] and [[ZX Spectrum]] computers, was released by [[Firebird Software]] in 1985.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/c64/572032-thunderbirds-1985|title=''Thunderbirds'' (1985) for Commodore 64|accessdate=6 December 2014|work=[[GameFAQs]]|publisher=CBS Interactive|location=San Francisco, California|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121112175330/http://www.gamefaqs.com/c64/572032-thunderbirds-1985|archivedate=12 November 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref> Other titles have since been released for the [[Game Boy Color]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/gbc/579068-thunderbirds/images/119108|title=Thunderbirds Box Shot for Game Boy Color - GameFAQs|website=www.gamefaqs.com|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> [[Game Boy Advance]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/gba/565886-thunderbirds-international-rescue/images/16399|title=Thunderbirds: International Rescue Box Shot for Game Boy Advance - GameFAQs|website=www.gamefaqs.com|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> and [[PlayStation 2]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps2/939874-thunderbirds/images/189193 |title=Thunderbirds Box Shot for PlayStation 2 - GameFAQs |website=www.gamefaqs.com |access-date=2016-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918081105/http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps2/939874-thunderbirds/images/189193 |archivedate=18 September 2016 |df= }}</ref> During the late 1980s, the series was issued on home video for the first time by [[PolyGram]] and its subsidiary Channel 5. Following its acquisition by [[Carlton Communications|Carlton International Media]] in 1999, ''Thunderbirds'' was digitally remastered for the release of the first DVD versions in 2000.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/> [[Blu-ray Disc]] editions followed in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://film.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/68937/thunderbirds-uk-bd-in-september.html|title=''Thunderbirds'' (UK BD) in September|author=Foster, Dave|date=17 September 2008|work=thedigitalfix.com|publisher=Poisonous Monkey|accessdate=25 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211232123/http://film.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/68937/thunderbirds-uk-bd-in-september.html|archivedate=11 December 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="BBCTalkingShop"/>
==Later productions== {{Main article|Works based on Thunderbirds}} ''Thunderbirds'' has been followed by two film sequels, a live-action film adaptation, two animated TV remakes and several re-edited presentations for TV broadcast and home video. The second of the remakes, ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go]]'', premiered on ITV in 2015, the 50th anniversary year of the original.<ref name="TBAG Premiere">{{Cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/itvplayer/thunderbirds-are-go/series-1/episode-1-ring-of-fire-part-1-|title=''Thunderbirds Are Go'' Episode 1: ''Ring of Fire'' (Part 1)|date=4 April 2015|work=[[ITV Player]]|publisher=[[ITV plc]]|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817163923/https://www.itv.com/itvplayer/thunderbirds-are-go/series-1/episode-1-ring-of-fire-part-1-|archivedate=17 August 2015|accessdate=17 August 2015|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Film=== The feature-length film sequels ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'' and ''[[Thunderbird 6]]'' were released in 1966 and 1968. The first was [[greenlit]] by Lew Grade before the TV series had started its broadcast run.<ref>Archer and Nicholls, p. 112.</ref> Written and produced by the Andersons and directed by David Lane, both films were distributed by [[United Artists]]. Neither was a critical or commercial success, and [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21 Cinema]]'s plans for further sequels were abandoned.<ref>Bentley 2005, p. 41.</ref><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 159.</ref>
In the early 1980s, episodes of ''Thunderbirds'' and other Supermarionation series were re-edited by ITC's New York offices to create a series of [[compilation film]]s.<ref name="Bentley, 117">Bentley 2005, p. 117.</ref> Branded "Super Space Theater", this format was mostly intended for family viewing on American cable and [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated]] TV.<ref name="Bentley, 117"/> Three ''Thunderbirds'' features were produced: ''Thunderbirds to the Rescue'', ''Thunderbirds in Outer Space'' and ''Countdown to Disaster''.<ref>Bentley 2008, pp. 361–362.</ref>
Plans for a live-action film adaptation were first announced in 1993.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 115">Bentley 2008, p. 115.</ref><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 161.</ref> These eventually culminated in the 2004 film ''[[Thunderbirds (2004 film)|Thunderbirds]]'', directed by [[Jonathan Frakes]] and produced by [[StudioCanal]] and [[Working Title Films]]. It was a critical and commercial failure and was poorly received by fans of the TV series.<ref name="Cull: Fifty, 6"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 163.</ref>
===TV=== The Andersons sold their intellectual and [[Residual (entertainment industry)|profit participation]] rights to ''Thunderbirds'' and their other productions in the 1970s.<ref>Anderson 2007, p. 111.</ref><ref>Archer and Hearn, p. 222.</ref> As a result, they had no developmental control over subsequent adaptations of their works.<ref name="Cull: Fifty, 6"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 88.</ref> ''Thunderbirds'' was first remade for TV in the early 1980s as ''[[Thunderbirds 2086]]''.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117">Bentley 2008, p. 117.</ref><ref name="Cull: Fifty, 6"/> In this [[anime]] re-imagining, set 20 years after the original, the vastly expanded IR is based within an [[arcology]] and operates 17 ''Thunderbird'' machines.<ref name="Bentley, 118">Bentley 2005, p. 118.</ref> It was inspired by ''Thunderhawks'', an updated story concept by Gerry Anderson and Reg Hill that later served as the basis for Anderson's [[Supermarionation#Supermacromation|Supermacromation]] series ''[[Terrahawks]]''.<ref>Bentley 2008, pp. 227 and 363.</ref><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 188.</ref>
Two re-edited series, based on condensed versions of 13 of the original episodes, aired in the US in 1994.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 115"/> The first, ''Thunderbirds USA'', was broadcast as part of the [[Fox Kids]] programming block; the second, ''Turbocharged Thunderbirds'', was syndicated by [[UPN]].<ref>Bentley 2005, pp. 121–122.</ref> Developed as a comedy, ''Turbocharged Thunderbirds'' moved the action to the planet "Thunder-World" and combined the original puppet footage with new live-action scenes featuring a pair of human teenagers.<ref name="Bentley, 122">Bentley 2005, p. 122.</ref><ref>Bentley 2008, p. 116.</ref>
As well as ''Thunderhawks'', Anderson developed other ideas for a remake. A 1976 concept, ''Inter-Galactic Rescue 4'', was to have featured a variable-configuration craft capable of performing rescues on land and sea, in air and in space; Anderson pitched the idea to NBC, who rejected it.<ref name="Bentley, 117"/><ref>Bentley 2008, p. 336.</ref> This was followed in 1984 by another proposed updating, ''T-Force'', which at first could not be pursued owing to a lack of funding.<ref>Bentley 2008, p. 325.</ref> Development resumed in 1993, when it was decided to produce the series, now titled ''GFI'', using [[cel animation]]. But Anderson was disappointed with the results and the production was abandoned.<ref>Bentley 2008, pp. 319–320.</ref>
In 2005, Anderson re-affirmed his wish to remake ''Thunderbirds'' but stated that he had been unable to secure the necessary rights from [[Granada plc|Granada Ventures]].<ref name="Bentley, 5"/> His negotiations with the company and its successor, [[ITV plc]], continued for the next few years.<ref name="Bentley, 5">Bentley 2005: Foreword by Gerry Anderson, p. 5.</ref><ref The project, titled "Thunderbirds 1965", is supported by ITV, Sylvia Anderson and the estate of Gerry Anderson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gerryanderson.co.uk/brand-new-episodes-of-classic-thunderbirds-on-the-way/|author=Anderson, Jamie|date=7 July 2015|title=Brand-New Episodes of Classic ''Thunderbirds'' On The Way!|work=gerryanderson.co.uk|publisher=[[Anderson Entertainment]]|accessdate=14 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150708012724/http://www.gerryanderson.co.uk/brand-new-episodes-of-classic-thunderbirds-on-the-way/|archivedate=8 July 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Influence== [[File:ThunderbirdsFAB (Cropped).jpg|thumb|Billboard for the 1989 production of the stage show tribute ''Thunderbirds: F.A.B.'' at London's [[Apollo Theatre]]|alt=A neon sign for a stage play at the Apollo Theatre reads "Andrew Dawson - Gavin Robertson - Thunderbirds FAB - A Forbidden Planet Production"]] {{See also|Works based on Thunderbirds#References, parodies and imitations}}
''Thunderbirds'' has influenced TV programmes, films and various other media.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/> The puppet comedy of the film ''[[Team America: World Police]]'' was directly inspired by the idiosyncrasies of ''Thunderbirds''-era Supermarionation techniques.<ref name="Cull: Fifty, 7">Cull 2009, p. 7.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.movieweb.com/news/06/5406.php|title=Trey Parker and Matt Stone Talk ''Team America: World Police''|date=4 October 2004|work=[[MovieWeb]]|publisher=WATCHR Media|location=[[Las Vegas]], Nevada|accessdate=19 January 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706155146/http://www.movieweb.com/news/06/5406.php|archivedate=6 July 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Allusion and homage are also evident in ''[[Wallace and Gromit]]: [[A Close Shave]]'', ''[[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]]'' and ''[[Spaced]]'',<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/><ref name="Cull: Fifty, 7"/> as well as the character design of ''[[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008 TV series)|Star Wars: The Clone Wars]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/blog/BC_Beat/10161-George_Lucas_Talks_Clone_Wars_.php|author=Weprin, Alex|title=George Lucas Talks ''Clone Wars''|date=3 April 2008|work=broadcastingcable.com|publisher=[[NewBay Media]]|location=New York City, New York|accessdate=17 August 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127104128/http://www.broadcastingcable.com/blog/BC_Beat/10161-George_Lucas_Talks_Clone_Wars_.php|archivedate=27 November 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref> The BBC sketch comedy ''[[Not Only... But Also]]'' included a segment titled "Superthunderstingcar" – a parody of ''Thunderbirds'', ''Supercar'' and ''Stingray''.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/><ref>Anderson 2007, p. 97.</ref>
IR's life-saving mission inspired the founding of the volunteer [[International Rescue Corps]], originally made up of a group of British firemen who contributed to the humanitarian effort following the [[1980 Irpinia earthquake]].<ref name="Bentley, 117"/> [[Virgin Group]] has used the series in branding its services: [[Virgin Atlantic]] operates a [[Boeing 747-400]] airliner named ''Lady Penelope'', while [[Virgin Trains]] owns a fleet of locomotives that are all named after main characters and vehicles and used specifically to "rescue" broken-down trains.<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/>
A mimed stage show, ''Thunderbirds: F.A.B.'', has toured internationally and popularised a staccato style of movement known colloquially as the "''Thunderbirds'' walk".<ref name="Bentley, 119"/><ref>Marriott 1993, p. 181.</ref> The production has periodically been revived as ''Thunderbirds: F.A.B. – The Next Generation''.<ref name="Bentley, 118"/><ref name="Bentley, 119">Bentley 2005, p. 119.</ref>
Cover versions of "The ''Thunderbirds'' March" have been released by musicians and bands such as [[Billy Cotton]], [[Joe Loss]], [[Frank Sidebottom]], [[The Rezillos]] and [[The Shadows]].<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/> Groups who have written songs inspired by the series include [[We've Got a Fuzzbox and We're Gonna Use It|Fuzzbox]] (with "International Rescue"), [[TISM]] (with "[[Thunderbirds Are Coming Out]]"), [[Busted (band)|Busted]] (with "[[Thunderbirds / 3AM]]") and [[V6 (band)|V6]] (with "Thunderbirds – Your Voice").<ref name="Bentley: EG, 117"/> In 1991, Anderson filmed the music video for the [[Dire Straits]] single "[[Calling Elvis]]" with a collection of ''Thunderbirds''-style puppets.<ref name="Marriott, 190"/><ref name="Bentley, 121">Bentley 2005, p. 121.</ref>
During the 1960s, APF produced themed TV advertisements for [[Lyons Maid]] and [[Kellogg's]].<ref>Bentley 2008, pp. 346–347.</ref> Aspects of ''Thunderbirds'' have since been used in advertising for [[Swinton Insurance]], [[Nestlé]] [[Kit Kat]],<ref>Bentley 2008, p. 360.</ref> [[Specsavers]] and the UK [[Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=Spring 2012|title=Interview: Jan King – Should Have Gone to Specsavers|journal=Andersonic|volume=1|issue=13|pages=34–36|editor=Farrell, Richard}}</ref> {{Clear}}

{{more citations needed|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Wayne's World | image = Waynes world ver2.jpg| | caption = Theatrical poster | alt = | director = [[Penelope Spheeris]] | screenplay = {{Plain list | * [[Mike Myers]] * [[Bonnie and Terry Turner|Bonnie Turner
Terry Turner]] }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[Wayne's World]]''|Mike Myers}} | starring = {{Plain list | * [[Mike Myers]] * [[Dana Carvey]] * [[Rob Lowe]] * [[Tia Carrere]] * [[Lara Flynn Boyle]] * [[Brian Doyle-Murray]] * [[Robert Patrick]] * [[Chris Farley]] * [[Ed O'Neill]] * [[Ione Skye]] * [[Meat Loaf]] * [[Christopher Walken]] * [[Alice Cooper]]}} | producer = [[Lorne Michaels]] | music = [[J. Peter Robinson]] | cinematography = [[Theo van de Sande]] | editing = Malcolm Campbell | studio = [[NBC|NBC Films]] | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1992|2|14}} | runtime = 95 minutes | country = United States | language = [[English language|English]] | budget = $20 million | gross = $183.1 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=waynesworld.htm |title=Wayne's World (1992) – Daily Box Office |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=2016-02-02}} }} '''''Wayne's World''''' is a 1992 American [[comedy film]] directed by [[Penelope Spheeris]], produced by [[Lorne Michaels]], and written by [[Mike Myers]] and [[Bonnie and Terry Turner]]. It stars Myers in his feature film debut as Wayne Campbell and [[Dana Carvey]] as Garth Algar, a pair of rock fans who broadcast a [[public-access television|public-access television show]]. It also features [[Rob Lowe]], [[Tia Carrere]], [[Lara Flynn Boyle]], [[Brian Doyle-Murray]], [[Chris Farley]], [[Ed O'Neill]], [[Ione Skye]], [[Meat Loaf]], and [[Alice Cooper]]. ''Wayne's World'' was released in the US on February 14, 1992. It was the eighth-highest-grossing film of 1992 and it remains the highest-grossing [[List of Saturday Night Live feature films|film based on ''Saturday Night Live'' skits]]. A sequel, ''[[Wayne's World 2]]'', was released on December 10, 1993. ==Plot== In [[Aurora, Illinois]], rock fans Wayne Campbell and Garth Algar host a [[public-access television]] show, ''Wayne's World'', from Wayne's parents' basement. After they sell the rights to the show to television producer Benjamin Oliver for $10,000, they celebrate at a night club, where they avoid Wayne's troubled ex-girlfriend Stacy. Wayne falls for Cassandra Wong, vocalist and bassist of the band performing that night, Crucial Taunt, and impresses her with his [[Cantonese]]. He purchases a 1964 [[Fender Stratocaster]] electric guitar he has long coveted. Benjamin attempts to steal Cassandra from Wayne by using his wealth and good looks. He distracts Wayne and Garth with all-access tickets to an [[Alice Cooper]] concert in Milwaukee, while offering to produce a [[music video]] for Crucial Taunt. At the concert, Wayne and Garth make the acquaintance of a bodyguard to music producer Frankie Sharp, head of Sharp Records. While filming the revamped ''Wayne's World'' under Benjamin's oversight, Wayne and Garth find it difficult to adjust to the professional studio environment. Their contract obliges them to give a promotional interview to their [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]], Noah Vanderhoff, who owns a franchise of [[amusement arcade]]s. After Wayne publicly ridicules Vanderhoff, he is fired from the show, causing a rift in his friendship with Garth. Jealous of the attention Benjamin is giving Cassandra, Wayne attempts to prevent her from participating in the Crucial Taunt music video shoot. She breaks up with him, furious at his lack of trust. Wayne and Garth reunite and hatch a plan to win Cassandra back by having Sharp hear Crucial Taunt play. While Garth and their friends infiltrate a satellite station with the aid of Benjamin's assistant, Wayne goes to Cassandra's video shoot, but embarrasses himself in an attempt to expose Benjamin's ulterior motive. As he leaves, Cassandra changes her mind about Benjamin. Wayne apologizes and they return to Aurora. The ''Wayne's World'' crew hacks into Sharp's satellite television and broadcast the Crucial Taunt performance from Wayne's basement, where Sharp and Benjamin converge. Sharp declines to offer Crucial Taunt a record contract, Cassandra breaks up with Wayne and departs with Benjamin for a tropical resort, Stacy reveals that she is pregnant with Wayne's child, and a fire destroys Wayne's house. Dissatisfied, Wayne and Garth turn to the film's audience and halt proceedings. They restart the scene and unmask Benjamin as "Old Man Withers" in a ''[[Scooby-Doo]]'' parody ending. Still unsatisfied, they start again with a "mega happy ending" in which Cassandra signs a record contract and reunites with Wayne, Garth begins a relationship with a waitress, and Benjamin learns that money and good looks do not necessarily bring happiness. ==Cast== * [[Mike Myers]] as Wayne Campbell, host of ''Wayne's World'' * [[Dana Carvey]] as Garth Algar, Wayne's best friend and co-host * [[Tia Carrere]] as Cassandra Wong, singer and bassist of Crucial Taunt and Wayne's love interest * [[Rob Lowe]] as Benjamin Oliver, a sleazy television producer * [[Lara Flynn Boyle]] as Stacy, Wayne's troubled ex-girlfriend * [[Brian Doyle-Murray]] as Noah Vanderhoff, a video arcade magnate * [[Colleen Camp]] as Mrs. Vanderhoff * [[Kurt Fuller]] as Russell Finley, director of the television shows produced by Benjamin * [[Chris Farley]] as the well-informed security guard at the back of [[Alice Cooper]] concert * [[Meat Loaf]] as Tiny, a doorman at the Gasworks * [[Frank DiLeo]] as rock promoter Frankie 'Mr. Big' Sharp * [[Ed O'Neill]] as Glen, the manager at [[Stan Mikita]]'s Donuts * [[Michael DeLuise]] as Alan, one of Wayne and Garth's crew * [[Lee Tergesen]] as Terry, Wayne and Garth's head cameraman * Dan Bell as Neil, Wayne's and Garth's second cameraman * Sean Gregory Sullivan as Phil, Wayne and Garth's perpetually intoxicated friend who works at an auto repair shop * [[Mike Hagerty]] as Davey, a controller at the Cable 10 television station whom Benjamin and Russell ask for help * [[Frederick Coffin]] as Officer Koharski * [[Donna Dixon]] as Garth's dream woman * [[Ione Skye]] as Elyse, Benjamin's girlfriend, who introduces him to Wayne's World * [[Robin Ruzan]] as a waitress at Stan Mikita's * [[Charles Noland]] as Ron Paxton, who tries to market his invention, the "Suck-Kut", to Garth * [[Carmen Filpi]] as Old Man Withers * [[Robert Patrick]] as [[T-1000]] (reprising his role from ''[[Terminator 2: Judgment Day]]'') * [[Alice Cooper]] with [[Pete Friesen]], [[Derek Sherinian]], Stef Burns,{{cite web|url=http://www.stefburns.com/history.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110117101126/http://www.stefburns.com/history.html |archivedate=2011-01-17 |df= }} and [[Jimmy DeGrasso]] as themselves. ==Production== ''Wayne's World'' was greenlit by [[Paramount Pictures]] in 1991. It was the second [[List of Saturday Night Live feature films|film based on a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch]] following ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]'' in 1980.{{cite news |url=https://nypost.com/2017/02/02/mike-myers-couldnt-drive-during-waynes-world/ |title=Mike Myers couldn't drive during 'Wayne's World' |work=[[New York Post]] |date=2017-02-02 |accessdate=2017-05-17 }} Producer [[Lorne Michaels]] hired [[Penelope Spheeris]] to direct, who had directed several music [[documentary film|documentaries]]. Spheeris said, "I had been just struggling as a female director in this business for many years. I was 45 years old when I got that job. I just kept hanging in there. And ''Wayne's World'' happened, and it sort of flipped my life around."{{cite news |last=Pirnia |first=Garin |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/02/wanyes-world-25th-anniversary-penelope-spheeris-interview |title=How Wayne's World Made—and Broke—Its Director's Career |work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |date=2017-02-06 |accessdate=2017-05-17 }} Spheeris clashed with Myers during filming. She told ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' that Myers was "emotionally needy and got more difficult as the shoot went along. You should have heard him bitching when I was trying to do that 'Bohemian Rhapsody' scene: 'I can't move my neck like that! Why do we have to do this so many times? No one is going to laugh at that!'" She said she attempted to assuage Myers by having her daughter provide him snacks,{{cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2008/06/16/mike-myers-man-mystery/|title=Mike Myers: Man of Mystery|date=2008-06-16|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=2017-05-17}} and on one occasion he stormed off the set, upset that there was no margarine for his bagel. Myers and Spheeris argued over the [[final cut (film editing)|final cut]] of the film, causing Myers to prevent Spheeris from directing ''[[Wayne's World 2|Wayne' World 2]]''.{{cite news |author=Brandon Kirby |agency= |title=Mike Myers, Dana Carvey Set Aside 'Wayne's World' Feud at Academy Screening |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/waynes-world-feud-mike-myers-445044 |quote=Carvey and Spheeris both notoriously fell out with Myers despite the 1992 film's huge success. Myers is said to have blocked Spheeris from directing the 1993 sequel because she'd ignored his edit suggestions on the original. |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=April 24, 2013 |accessdate=2015-07-08 }}{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=How Mike Myers and Dana Carvey Resolved Their 'Wayne's World'-'Austin Powers' Feud |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/waynes-world-how-mike-myers-436879 |quote=Myers blocked Spheeris from directing the 1993 sequel because she'd ignored his edit suggestions on the original (her cut already had tested well). And Carvey felt Myers later stole his Dr. Evil impression for Austin Powers, which supposedly was based on Carvey's goof on Lorne Michaels. |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 11, 2013 |accessdate=2015-07-08 }} ==Reception== ===Box office=== The movie was a box office success, debuting at number one.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-03/entertainment/ca-3323_1_weekend-box-office|title=Weekend Box Office `Wayne's World' Keeps Partyin' On|last=Fox|first=David J.|date=1992-03-03|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2010-11-18}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-17/entertainment/ca-3873_1_weekend-box-office|title=Weekend Box Office `Wayne's World' Gains in Fifth Week|last=Fox|first=David J.|date=1992-03-17|work=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2010-10-26}} The film's final domestic gross was $121,697,323,{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/alphabetical.htm?letter=W&p=.htm|title=Alphabetical Movie Index A-Z|publisher=Amazon.com|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2011-01-17}} making it the eighth-highest-grossing film of 1992{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=1992|title=1992 Yearly Box Office Results - Box Office Mojo|website=Boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=20 August 2017}} and the highest-grossing of the 11 [[List of Saturday Night Live feature films|films based on ''Saturday Night Live'' skits]]. ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an 84% "Certified Fresh" rating based on 50 reviews, with an average rating of 6.8/10, with the critical consensus stating, "An oddball comedy that revels in its silliness and memorable catchphrases, ''Wayne's World'' is also fondly regarded because of its endearing characters."{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/waynes_world/|title=Wayne's World|website=Rottentomatoes.com|accessdate=2017-08-20}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 53 out of 100, based on 13 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/waynes-world |title=Wayne's World Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |date= |accessdate=2016-07-17}} [[Roger Ebert]] said in his review: "I walked into ''Wayne's World'' expecting a lot of dumb, vulgar comedy, and I got plenty, but I also found what I didn't expect: a genuinely amusing, sometimes even intelligent, undercurrent." {{Cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/waynes-world-1992|title=Wayne's World Movie Review & Film Summary (1992) {{!}} Roger Ebert|last=Ebert|first=Roger|website=Rogerebert.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-25}} However, [[Desson Howe]] wrote in the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' that making a movie out of such a "teeny sketch" is "better than you'd expect" but criticized the finale as "an attempt to lampoon movie endings" "and a despair-driven inability to end the movie".{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/waynesworldpg13howe_a0aea2.htm|title=Wayne's World (PG-13)|last=Howe|first=Desson|website=Washingtonpost.com|access-date=2017-03-25}} ===Effect on pop culture=== [[File:WaynesWorldAMCPacer.jpg|thumb|right|Wayne's World AMC Pacer clone at Planet Hollywood in New York City]] Filled with [[pop culture]] references, the sketches and the film started catchphrases such as "''Schwing!''" and "[[Sarcasm|Schyea]]", as well as popularizing "[[That's what she said]]", "Party on!" and the use of "[[Not!]]" after apparently affirmative sentences in order to state the contrary.{{cite web|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2013/schwing-mike-myers-dana-carveys-waynes-world-reunion-recap/ |title=Schwing! Mike Myers & Dana Carvey's 'Wayne's World' Reunion Recap |publisher=FirstShowing.net |date=2013-04-25 |accessdate=2016-07-17}} ===Awards=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} [[American Film Institute]] recognition: * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs]] - Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/laughs500.pdf|format=PDF|title=This is the American Film Institute's list of 500 movies nominated for the top 100 Funniest American Movies|website=Afi.com|accessdate=2017-08-20}} * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]]: ** "Schwing!" - Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/quotes400.pdf|format=PDF|title=ACE VENTURA : All-righty then!|website=Afi.com|accessdate=2017-08-20}} ** "We're not worthy. We're not worthy." - Nominated * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Songs]]: ** [[Bohemian Rhapsody]] - Nominated {{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/songs400.pdf|format=PDF|title=AFI's 100 Years... 100 Songs|website=Afi.com|accessdate=2017-08-20}} ==Music== {{Anchor|Soundtrack}} {{Main|Music from the Motion Picture Wayne's World}} * The [[Wayne's World (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] album reached number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard 200|album chart]]. * The use of [[Queen (band)|Queen]]'s "[[Bohemian Rhapsody]]" in the film propelled the song to number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' singles charts]] 17 years after its first release. {{Infobox flood | name = Winter of 1990–1991 in Western Europe | image location = Snow in Ware, Hertfordshire, February 1991.jpg | alt = | image size = | image name = Snow in Ware, Hertfordshire, February 1991 | image alt text = | date = | duration = December 1990 – February 1991 | total damages = | total fatalities = at least 42 | areas affected = United Kingdom, Ireland and Western Europe }}
The '''winter of 1990–91''' was a particularly cold winter in [[Western Europe]], noted especially for its effect on the [[United Kingdom]], and for two significantly heavy falls of [[snow]] which occurred in December 1990 and February 1991. Sandwiched in between was a period of high winds and heavy rain which caused widespread damage. The winter was the coldest since [[January 1987 Southeast England snowfall|January 1987]], and the snowfall experienced in many parts of the United Kingdom would not be seen again until the [[February 2009 Great Britain and Ireland snowfall|snowfall of February 2009]].<ref name="http1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7864395.stm |title=UK | Heavy snow hits much of Britain |publisher=BBC |work= BBC News |date=2 February 2009 |accessdate=25 November 2009}}</ref>
==December 1990==
The snowfall of early December 1990 was particularly disruptive to large parts of the United Kingdom, although heavy snow was also reported across much of Western Europe.<ref name=http2>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/world/heavy-snow-snarls-much-of-west-europe.html|title= Heavy Snow Snarls Much of West Europe|publisher= |work= New York Times|date= 10 December 1990|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom snow began to fall over the [[English Midlands|Midlands]], [[Wales]] and the [[Pennines]] on the night of 7–8 December 1990 and continued for much of the following day. The rate of snowfall was quite heavy, around {{convert|6|cm}} an hour, and as a result many areas were covered within half an hour of the snow starting to fall. Coupled with this were high winds which reached gale force in many areas leading to blizzard conditions. Many parts of the Midlands reported at least {{convert|20|cm}} of snow while depths reached {{convert|60|cm}} in the [[Derby]] area. On the Welsh Mountains there were drifts of up to {{convert|4|m}}. Snow fell in Western Europe the following day, 9 December.<ref name=http4>{{cite news|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g_YVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OBQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6497,3902250&dq=snow&hl=en|title= Snow blusters through Britain, western Europe|publisher= |work= Morning Star|date= 10 December 1990|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Wildcroft Road in snow,1990 - geograph.org.uk - 1073452.jpg|thumb|left|Snow in [[Canley]], [[Coventry]] on 8 December 1990.]]
Transport was severely disrupted with many people trapped in their cars and all rail services in the Midlands cancelled, while elsewhere in western Europe, roads and airports were closed.<ref name=http2/> In northern Spain traffic officials were forced to shut mountain passes due to heavy snow while rail services in [[Ticino|Tessin]], southern [[Switzerland]] were also severely disrupted. The state's [[Lugano Airport]] was also closed.<ref name=http2/> In France the main highway between [[Lyon]] and [[Grenoble]] was blocked and traffic had to be rerouted, while the [[Mont Blanc tunnel]] linking France and Italy through the Alps was also inaccessible.<ref name=http3>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world/12-dead-and-9-missing-as-europe-digs-out-after-a-heavy-snowfall.html|title= 12 Dead and 9 Missing as Europe Digs Out After a Heavy Snowfall|publisher= |work= New York Times|date= 11 December 1990|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref> Many roads in parts of Austria's [[East Tyrol]] and western [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]] were closed due to avalanche fears. Snow also fell in Italy where [[Turin]] saw its first pre-Christmas snow since 1964.<ref name=http3/> At the same time much of southern Europe experienced high winds and heavy rain,<ref name=http3/> with ferry services suspended in [[Venice]] following floods.<ref name=http5>{{cite news|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hPYVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OBQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4056,4218657&dq=snow&hl=en|title= Snow plagues continent|publisher= |work= Morning Star|date= 11 December 1990|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref>
The harsh weather conditions brought down power lines across England leading to loss of electricity for many areas. Power was also disrupted in parts of France.<ref name=http2/> In the UK some 650,000 people were without power, and about 1.2 million without water supplies for several days. The [[British Army|Army]] was called in to help restore utility supplies to outlying areas.<ref name=http4/> In addition, the adverse weather conditions had a negative economic impact with takings at stores on what was the third Saturday before [[Christmas]] considerably lower than normal.
The severe weather led to the deaths of ten people in the United Kingdom. Three were killed in road accidents in [[Northern Ireland]] which was hit by gale force winds.<ref name=http2/> In Austria a 21 car pile up was caused by ice on the [[Inntal Autobahn|Inntal highway]] injuring several people.<ref name=http3/>
Most of the snow had gone within four days, but its effects were felt for several days afterward. Much of the rest of December was unsettled, and the United Kingdom was hit by heavy storms over the Christmas and New Year period. High winds and heavy rain on Christmas Day caused disruption and power cuts for some parts of the United Kingdom, while the UK and Ireland experienced severe gales on 5 and 6 January 1991. Gusts of up to 70 mph brought down trees and power lines leaving thousands of homes blacked out across Ireland and the southwest of England, resulting in the deaths of 30 people.<ref name=http12>{{cite news|title= Gales claim 30 more lives across Britain and ireland|publisher= Cowles Publishing Company|work= Spokane Chronicle|date= 7 January 1991}}</ref> The dead included 11 crew members who were lost off two merchant vessels, a couple out walking on the beach near [[Brighton]] and 13 people who died in Ireland as a result of falling trees and other accidents.<ref name=http13>{{cite news|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QmcQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y4sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3378,758565&dq=storms+ireland&hl=en|title= Gales kill 30 in Britain, Ireland|publisher= |work= The Free Lance Star|date= 7 January 1991|accessdate= 26 November 2009}}</ref> Seven of the Irish deaths occurred when a tree crashed onto a minibus.
==February 1991== [[File:It did used to snow in Darfield. - geograph.org.uk - 529728.jpg|thumb|right|upright|People sledging in [[Darfield, South Yorkshire|Darfield]], [[South Yorkshire]] in February 1991.]] The second snow event of the winter occurred in early February 1991 and brought the coldest weather since January 1987. Unlike the previous storm it hit much of Europe, freezing rivers and lakes, and even the canals of Venice which froze over for the first time since 1985.<ref name=http6>{{cite news|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qboTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UJADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4853,1925765&dq=snow&hl=en|title= Europe hit by bad winter|publisher= |work= New Straits Times Malaysia|date= 8 February 1991|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref> In France the [[French Riviera]] experienced its heaviest snowfall for five years leading to traffic chaos – many drivers were stranded on the coastal road between [[Nice]] and [[Antibes]],<ref name=http7>{{cite news|url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zk8QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=II8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4092,4049515&dq=snow&hl=en|title= Snow blankets the Riviera|publisher= |work= Ellensburg Daily Record|date= 7 February 1991|accessdate= 25 November 2009}}</ref> while elsewhere two people were killed after becoming exposed to the cold weather,<ref name=http6/> and horse racing at the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] resort of [[Cagnes-sur-Mer]] was cancelled due to snowfall.<ref name=http6/> The southern [[Soviet Union]] which usually experienced fairly mild winters saw temperatures fall to −10C,<ref name=http6/> while [[Spitsbergen]] in Norway enjoyed unseasonably mild weather.<ref name=http6/>
In the United Kingdom the snow was brought in by a cold easterly wind.<ref name=http11/> At first it was mostly concentrated in the eastern counties of England, although it quickly spread inland. By the evening of 6 February many parts of England and Wales were experiencing snow showers, and by the following morning many areas woke to a covering of powdery snow. Along with this came a severe frost coupled with sub-zero temperatures, and heavy snowfalls which continued to fall throughout the day. Temperatures were as low as {{convert|-11.7|C}} and did not exceed {{convert|-5|C}} in many areas. Snow depths were in excess of {{convert|10|cm}} across England and drifted in the easterly wind. On higher ground levels reached {{convert|30|cm}}.<ref name=http11/> Villages on [[Exmoor]] were cut off by drifts approaching {{convert|2|m}}.
Once again the snow brought travel chaos to much of the country, particularly to the railways, with [[British Rail]] making its now infamous excuse that severe delays to services were being caused by [[the wrong type of snow]].<ref name=http8>{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/4434770/Snow-Britain-Wrong-kind-of-snow-strikes-again.html|title= Snow Britain: Wrong kind of snow strikes again|publisher= Telegraph Media Group|work= Daily Telegraph|first= Philip|last= Eden|date= 2 February 2009|accessdate= 26 November 2009}}</ref> [[Heathrow Airport]] was forced to cancel flights, while [[Birmingham Airport, England|Birmingham]] and [[Gatwick Airport|Gatwick]] were closed.<ref name=http10>{{cite news|url= http://www.travelweekly.co.uk/Articles/2009/02/02/30130/timeline-how-snow-has-hit-uk-flights-1991-2009.html|title= Timeline: How snow has hit UK flights, 1991 – 2009|publisher= |work= Travel Weekly|date= 2 February 2009|accessdate= 26 November 2009}} </ref> Cars were abandoned as roads and motorways became impassable, and canals, ponds and even part of the [[Bristol Channel]] froze over.
By 8 February conditions had deteriorated further, with depths of snow approaching {{convert|20|cm}} in many areas. [[London]] recorded {{convert|20|cm}},<ref name=http11>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1138692/More-snow-way-severe-frost-grips-country-throw-decades-ago.html|title= More snow on the way as severe frost grips the country in a throw back to two decades ago|publisher= Associated Newspapers Ltd|work= Mail Online|date= 7 February 2009|accessdate= 26 November 2009}}</ref> with parts of [[Yorkshire]] recording {{convert|51|cm}}.<ref name=http9>{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article5633815.ece|title= Snow storms will be most widespread in 18 years, Met Office warns|publisher= News International|work= Times Online|first= Louise|last= Cohen|date= 1 February 2009|accessdate= 26 November 2009}}</ref> [[Bingley]] in [[West Yorkshire]] had {{convert|47|cm}} and [[Pencelli]] in [[Powys]] {{convert|35|cm}}. After temperatures dropped to {{convert|-10|C}} on the night of 8–9 February, conditions eased slightly the following day and continued to do so on 10 February. However, night-time temperatures remained low, and there was a fresh snowfall on 12 February. After this high pressure began to move across the UK and despite further night time frosts a slow thaw began. On 20 February an Atlantic system arrived bringing mild south westerly winds and rain which escalated the thaw and allowed temperatures to return to double figures.
